PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 2.15 p.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEAZLEY; JONES; KENT; MCMAHON; MORRIS; SCOTT
PETITION.TITLE: Trans-Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Trans-Australia Airlines
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans- Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans-Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in-
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley,Mr Charles Jones,Mr Kent,Mr Les McMahon,Mr Morris and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The hotel industry in Australia is long-established and a valuable part of the community of this nation, providing places where the people may partake of the three basic needs of life: a place to eat, a place to drink, a place to sleep.
2. The hotel industry is accepted throughout the nation as occupying an important place in the social and economic activities of Australia.
3. The hotel industry is almost entirely within the private sector and makes a large contribution to the government in taxes of various kinds.
4. The hotel industry has a need to sustain an appropriate level of turnover and growth, to make profit, and to sustain and improve the level of employment.
5. The hotel industry of Australia is gravely concerned at published reports that the Government intends to increase excise charges on beer in the forthcoming Budget.
6. Sales of beer constitute the major source of income of most of the industry's 5,811 hotels in Australia.
7. The very steep rises in beer excise in 1975 and 1978 severely retarded the growth of the Australian hotel industry.

8. Any further increases in excise on beer in the 1981 Budget would further retard the industry at a time when growth is essential to maintaining economic viability and the ability to serve the constantly growing needs of the community.
9. Such is its significance as a community requirement, beer occupies a place on the Consumer Price Index, and any alteration to its cost to the community would have an inflationary effect.
10. Any increase in excise would result in and force the hotel industry to pass on such increases to the consumer by way of higher prices for beer.

11. Higher excise would be only the starting point for an upward spiral in beer prices because of the presence of other factors, such as State Licence Fee taxes, which are directly linked to excise rates.
12. The hotel industry of Australia already is gravely handicapped by heavy excise and other tax imposts, its growth is at a standstill; and, inevitably must decline if beer excise is increased.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that honourable members of the House of Representatives:
1. Recognise the importance and place of the Australian Hotel industry in the social and economic life of the nation.

2. Accept that the viability of the hotel industry is essential to the maintenance of employment opportunities and stability of the industry is essential to enable it to continue to provide for the hotel needs of the nation in this period of growing population and increasing tourism.
And further, that honourable members of the House of Representatives resist and reject any move to increase excise on beer.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bourchier,Mr Carlton,Mr Fisher and Mr Les McMahon.

PETITION.TITLE: Soviet Passenger Cruise Vessels
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

Owing to an overwhelming and continuous demand by the Australian people for a cruise service within the economic scope of the working man and his family, we request the Government to lift the ban placed on Soviet Passenger Cruise Vessels entering Australian Ports.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Robert Brown and Mr Mountford.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the list of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the island.
3. That the Queensland Government has recently renewed mining leases against the advice of conservationists and a State Government sponsored public inquiry.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling and Mr Humphreys.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The proposal to introduce fees for higher and second degrees will mean that access to post-graduate and recurrent education will be limited to the rich; Australian research and ability to cope with technological change will suffer; this proposal must be seen as a step in the direction of the introduction of fees for all tertiary students.

2. The proposed introduction of a loans scheme for students will mean graduating with a heavy debt or being denied a tertiary education if loans are refused because a student is seen as a 'poor risk' (particularly affecting women and those doing non-vocational courses); only the rich will be able to get a tertiary education without course restrictions and the burden of indebtedness.

3. In regard to the proposal to restrict eligibility for TEAS and the foreshadowing of reviewing TEAS levels only in the light of the availability of loans, it should be noted that any further downgrading of TEAS, which is already inadequate, can only further limit access to education.

4. The proposed restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance to those needing qualifications for employment will severely restrict access to a full high school education and necessary bridging education to tertiary education for those who left school early.

5. The proposal not to fund 30 colleges of advanced education if they are not rationalised is an attack on teacher education. This attack will create teacher shortages in the mid 1980s, restrict access to education now and endanger the future quality of teaching available to Australian children.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(i) post-secondary tuition fees not be introduced for any courses or for any category of students;
(ii) that the TEAS scheme be extended so as to more fully meet the real financial needs of students.
(iii) that a comprehensive loans scheme not be introduced.
(iv) that there be no restriction of Adult Secondary Assistance.
(v) that the proposal not to fund 30 CAEs unless they are rationalised be rescinded.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling and Mr Scholes.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That many Australians will be financially disadvantaged by the health changes proposed by the Federal Government, especially the withdrawal of Commonwealth medical benefits for the uninsured, and the introduction of a means test for free public hospital care;
That the health insurance changes promote inequity, inefficiency and lack of universal coverage;
That the public hospital system and community health programs will be financially disadvantaged by the abdication of Commonwealth responsibility and funding.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will take all steps necessary to reintroduce a system of health care based on ability to pay, and access to health care based on medical need.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Howe and Mr Les McMahon.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

a. Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

b. The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
c. The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Jenkins and Mr Willis.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
A substantial contribution to Australia's economy by the payment of taxation and to the quality of life of fellow Australians is made by parents in the work-force who have pre-school children.
Taxation relief for adequate child care is necessary to enable these parents to avail themselves of child care facilities in order to take paid employment.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that taxpayers who incur child care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Occupational and Vocational Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The decisions of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Government functions to discontinue the professional employment offices, to 'rationalise' and reduce occupational information services, to rationalise and reduce vocational psychology services, to discontinue the waterfront employment offices, to terminate the former regular servicemen's vocational training scheme, to discontinue the regular collection and publication of CES statistics of persons registered for unemployment and of unfilled vacancies, because such publication is embarrassing to the Government, are blatantly political and will in the long term prove not to be cost effective.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government will reverse these decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef: Oil Exploration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That the undersigned are of the opinion that the Great Barrier Reef and region must be protected in entirety from the potentially destructive effects of mining and respectfully demand that you ensure this by declaring a continuous marine park of the reef zone from Fraser Island to the Torres Strait in 1981, for which management plans of the type devised for the Capricornia Section can be prepared and discussed in due course.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That public investment in tertiary education in the form of Federal Government funding is an investment in Australia's future and enables Australia to meet the demands of technological innovation.
That grave concern has been generated as a result of the Government's decisions to:
(a) Abolish the Education Research and Development Committee,
(b) terminate special support for educational research,
(c) scale down in-house and contracted research activities of the Department of Education,
(d) scale down participation in international education activities, particularly UNESCO and OECD,
(e) further tighten already restrictive eligibility guidelines for TEAS,
(f) supplement TEAS assistance by means of a loan scheme,
(g) phase in tuition fees for students undertaking degrees and diplomas subsequent to an initial tertiary qualification,
(h) reduce grants to universities and colleges to take account of fee income,
(i) completely abolish 30 colleges of advanced education and
(j) scale down various engineering schools in colleges of advanced education around Australia.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will rescind these regressive decisions and desist from obvious attempts to pave the way for a complete re-introduction of tertiary fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the decision of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Government Functions to establish an inquiry into Telecom to examine the extent to which private interests might become involved in or take over activities currently performed by Telecom is in itself a waste of taxpayers' money and is of highly questionable value.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will not dismantle Telecom for the benefit of private interests.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That, as ex-servicemen are eligible to receive a service pension five years earlier than other Australian males are eligible to receive an age pension, subject to certain conditions, so too should the age at which the means test is applied to pension increases be reduced for service pensioners by five years to age 65.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will, in recognition of the service they have performed for their country, and because of reduced life expectancy as a result of that service, reduce the so-called means test free age limit for service pensioners from 70 years to 65.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) The financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.
(ii) The imposition of tuition fees for second degrees and post graduate degrees will deter many able persons from enrolling in such courses and further preserve higher education for the rich.

(iii) The introduction of a loans scheme, subsequent review of the level of TEAS and the tightening of the eligibility criteria for TEAS will cause great financial hardship and will deter students from enrolling in tertiary institutions.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. Post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students.
2. The visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
3. The government reverse its decision to introduce a loans scheme and instead increase and extend TEAS scheme.
And your petitioners as in duty bound shall ever humbly pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care Services: Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we strongly condemn any action taken by the Federal Government which will lead to the destruction of the Free Hospital and Medical Services of the State of Queensland.
And your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Parliament reject the proposed health cost sharing arrangements between the Commonwealth and the State governments and guarantee the maintenance of the present scheme whereby all Queenslanders who wish to avail themselves of these services may do so.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Regulation and Control of Nuclear Activities
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The decision of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Government functions to transfer the responsibility for the regulation and control of nuclear activities in Australia to State governments represents a shameful abdication of national responsibility on the part of the national Government and, in respect of the State governments of Queensland, Western Australia and South Australia, places an enormous and highly dangerous power in very dubious hands.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will resume its proper and reasonable role of regulation and control of all nuclear activities in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Migrant Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That serious concern has been generated in the migrant community following the Government's endorsement of decisions of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Government Functions to:

Restrict the role of the Commonwealth in adult migrant and refugee education programs to the arrangement and co-ordination only of such programs and relinquish responsibility for the conduct of individual programs.
Terminate some and rationalise other information services provided by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
Terminate forthwith the migrant assisted passage scheme.
Transfer the translation/interpreting services to private agencies or withdraw altogether.
Reduce hours of operation of the telephone interpreting service.
Discontinue production of the national groups directory.

Reduce overseas based staff associated with the recruitment and selection of persons for permanent settlement in Australia, which will result in greater delays in the processing of immigration applications.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government respect the needs of Australia's migrants and accordingly rescind these decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the Government's decision to provide brochures and information on Government programs at post offices around Australia highlights further the Government's excessive use of public money for its own propaganda machine.

That the listing of this decision by the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Government Functions under the heading 'Post Offices as Agents for Government Activities' strongly implies the use of postal officers as Government servants, not public servants.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will not abuse its authority in this way and will reverse this decision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Legal Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That serious concern has been generated in the Australian community following the announcement of the Government's decisions to:
Attempt to transfer responsibility for legal aid, presently provided by the Australian Legal Aid Office, to the States of New South Wales and Tasmania and the Government of the Northern Territory;
Abandon the new building for the Institute of Criminology and
Apply pressure to State governments to contribute six-sevenths of all costs of the institute.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will rescind these regressive decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Administrative Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That serious concern has been generated in the Australian community following the announcement of the Government's decisions to:
Transfer most of the work of the Government Printer to the private sector, with AGPS bookshops to be leased to private interests,
Reduce resources devoted to the purchasing division in the technical services sections of the Department of Administrative Services,
Limit circulation of ministerial statements service, and
Transfer the provision of non-departmental food, the cleaning and watching of Commonwealth properties, and the management of migrant hostels, to private interests.
That the functions referred to above are best provided by the Public Service.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will rescind these regressive decisions and desist from its ill-advised policy of selling off public property and transferring Public Service functions to private interests.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Aid
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That Australia, as an affluent and developed nation, should be able to expend more of its resources on the alleviation of human suffering and deprivation in other less developed countries.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will:
increase overseas aid to 0.7 per cent of Australia's GNP;
increase to 4 per cent the proportion of overseas aid channelled through recognised non-government organisations such as world vision.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting Information Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That concern has been generated in the Australian community following the announcement of the Government's decisions to:
Not proceed with the establishment of a broadcasting information office,
abolish the Australia Post Courier service to reduce competition with private companies,
maintain a postal express service for postal items only,
use private contractors for mail cartage,
pave the way for delivery of mail by private companies by examining Australia Post's powers with the stated view to their reduction or elimination.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will rescind these regressive and provocative decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Social Security
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That concern has been generated by the Government's decision to cut back expenditure in the Department of Social Security as outlined in the report of the committee of Review of Commonwealth Government Functions, i.e., by reducing the rate of expansion of regional offices of the Department of Social Security, confining social work activity to that relating to departmental functions, and scaling down the social welfare division of the department.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will rescind these decisions.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Privacy and Personal Information
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Paragraphs 107 and 108 of the Privacy and Personal Information discussion paper number 14, brought down by the Law Reform Commission in June 1980, undermines the family unit and the authority of parents, which is the Christian basis of our society, by proposing that 'between 12 and 16 years, a child should be entitled to object to disclosure of information to a parent.'
It is your petitioners sincere belief that:

(a) an adolescent between the ages of 12 and 16 is not at a mature enough stage of life to decide whether or not the disclosure of information to a parent will be in the best interests of the adolescent.
(b) as a record keeper has no responsibility for the child, and as his moral standards may be different to those of a parent, he should not be permitted to come between child and parent.

(c) a parent has a unique position which may enable him/her to perceive a situation that the record keeper does not. The parent must therefore be aware of the problem if remedial action is to be taken, and has the right to guide the child in the direction he/she feels fit.
Your petitioners therefore pray:
That the Members of the House of Representatives will reject the recommendation of the Law Reform Commission and find some other means to protect children from the excessive abuse of some parents.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Bendigo Ordnance and Clothing Factories
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We, the undersigned, wish to make it known to the Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, and the Liberal Government that we strongly condemn the proposed implementation of the Government Review Committee (The Razor Gang) recommendations:

The proposed sale of Government enterprises in a number of areas and their implied discontinuation of operation if not sold is simply a sell-out to private commercial interests and a rejection of the rights of the public to have a say in the operation of many areas of industrial importance.
We are particularly concerned with the proposed closure of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory and the sale or lease to private enterprise of the Australian Government Clothing Factory.
The acts will risk the jobs of many hundreds of workers and jeopardise the working conditions of many hundreds of others.
Your petitioners urge that the decisions taken by the Liberal Government in relation to these plants be reversed.
We demand that the Bendigo Ordnance Factory and the Australian Government Clothing Factory remain as they are.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Interpreter Service: Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we protest most strongly against the Government's decision to phase out the Telephone Interpreter Service in Tasmania.

The TIS has given the migrants of Tasmania a reliable and efficient service for the past two and a half years. If the decision to cut TIS is not reversed, calls will be diverted to Melbourne, and this will mean extra burden to their already overworked service, installation of diverter units, which will prove to be a costly, time consuming and inefficient way of running a previously successful service.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will look favourably on our petition to retain the Telephone Interpreter Service in Tasmania.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That the decisions arising out of the Review of Government Functions (undertaken by the Razor Gang) in relation to tertiary education funding will severely impair the process of developing the nation's intellectual resources.
2. That the invevitable outcome of the decisions will, in general terms, be:
(i) the financial impoverishment of small and medium-sized universities;
(ii) the abandonment of non-vocational courses and the possibility of widespread academic unemployment.
3. That amongst the particular consequences of the decisions, namely, consequences following on the re-introduction of tertiary fees for selected categories of post-graduate students, will be:
(i) the discouraging of part-time post-graduate students and all those not receiving Commonwealth or University scholarships;
(ii) the weakening of the national research effort to which post-graduate students have in the past made a significant contribution.

4. That the provision of the maximum TEAS benefit to only 14 per cent of all students, indeed, the failure to adequately support financially all undergraduate students, will be a disincentive to enrolment in tertiary institutions.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to re-consider the decisions arising out of the Review of Commonwealth Functions and urgently initiate a full and complete inquiry into the following:
(i) employment in tertiary institutions;
(ii) the effects of the Government's decisions upon the national research effort and upon post-graduate enrolments;
(iii) the adequacy of tertiary student support systems.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Health Insurance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. That Federal Government proposals to shift the cost of health insurance onto the individual has placed a disproportionate and unfair financial burden on lower income groups, but particularly on large families; single income families; the chronically ill; those with recurrent illnesses and those on fixed incomes.

2. That an estimated 15-20 per cent of Australians will not be able to afford insurance and will be forced to undertake extensive travel to avail themselves of outpatient services, the quality of which will be drastically reduced because of staff cuts.
3. That doctors, who at this moment are awaiting a fee increase, will inevitably become more and more expensive.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government (i) will re-examine the effects of health proposals and of the necessity for compulsory health insurance on lower income groups who do not presently meet the description of disadvantaged, and (ii) redefine the criteria determining the genuinely needy and disadvantaged to encompass the categories of persons mentioned in 1. above.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) That merchant seamen have in the past served in theatres of war; they have been decorated for valor following war action; they have been prisoners of war and should therefore be entitled to similar pension rights and medical benefits as regular servicemen.
(2) That by being denied the entitlements, such as pension and medical benefits, which other war veterans receive, they are thereby being discriminated against.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government amend the Repatriation Act (1920) Section 100 (d) (iv) to take account of war-related service by merchant seamen during World War 2.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That all members of the Women's Services 1939-45 War qualify as 'Australian Soldier' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian Forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies, making themselves available for combat duty in war zones, and according to Acts and Regulations of the period the military women had enlisted for service anywhere, some naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force of the 1939-45 war who were not sent to war zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all the ex-servicewomen of the 1939-45 war is unjust and unfair.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you amend the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of the 1939-45 war.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Women's Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled: This petition of concerned citizens earnestly requests that the funding of the Women's Health Centres and Rape Crisis Centres be increased to allow these centres to adequately provide the services vitally needed by the women of New South Wales. Further to this end that funding be granted to allow new greatly needed Womens' Health Centres and Rape Crisis Centres to be established.
We abhor the continued cuts in funding that have occurred over the past three years, which is creating a situation whereby the centres are facing the likelihood of no longer being able to function.
We submit that the deficit incurred by the cuts be made good by the Federal Government and to this end we submit this petition.
And we your petitioners, as in duty bound, will every pray for the granting of our plea.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. There is lack of public information about the content and intention of the proposed legislation on plant variety rights;
2. there is concern that the ethical and moral issues of granting private proprietorial rights over genetic resources have not been properly and publicly considered;
3. there is evidence to suggest that such legislation may lead to a reduction in the existing plant diversity;
4. there is reason to fear that farmers may be restricted in their activities due to the controls placed on the use and propagation of seed stocks;
5. evidence suggests that plant varietal rights legislation will lead to higher costs for the farmer, the consumer, the plant-breeder and the taxpayer; and
6. evidence suggests that plant varietal rights legislation will lead to a further increase in foreign control of Australian resources.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament defer introducing the legislation until full and informed public discussion of the issues involved has taken place.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That funding in the area of children's services, which has been reduced by almost 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-76 Budget. And further, that annual Budget allocations in the area of children's services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trade Unions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we are gravely disturbed by the actions of militant unions, the ACTU and the failure of the President of the ACTU to assist positively in settling the dispute which has caused massive losses to Qantas, our national airline; and we applaud the action of the Government in using RAAF planes to rescue Australians stranded abroad.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament and the Government should be of firm resolve not to permit such unions to hold the country to ransom and continue to take a forceful and resolute stand against such union militancy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(1) The financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of ducation's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditures) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(2) the imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1974 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(3) those students and potential students from social groups currently under-represented and disadvantaged in the post-secondary education system would be most severely affected by the reintroduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
(1) Post-secondary tuition fees not be reintroduced for any courses or for any category of students.
(2) The imposition of visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately.
(3) The Minister for Education immediately clarify the Government's attitude to the reintroduction of post-secondary tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

(1)Interest rates, rather than falling by 2 per cent as promised by the Prime Minister in November, 1977, are now between 2 per cent and 5 per cent higher than when that promise was made, and are at historically higher levels.

(2) This prevents many potential home buyers from borrowing to purchase a house; causes severe hardship to many people who are paying off a housing loan, causing some to default and lose their home; prevents or restrains the establishment or expansion of many businesses; and is directly responsible for increasing numbers of bankruptcies.
Your petitioners, therefore, pray that:
Minimisation of interest rates be adopted as one of the aims of economic policy;
the money supply target be relaxed to accommodate income growth without forcing credit restrictions and exorbitant interest rates;
regulation of borrowing rates be reintroduced to prevent the financial institutions raising lending rates to compensate for higher borrowing rates; and
foreign investment be more rigorously controlled in order to prevent destabilising inflows of foreign funds.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Deakin University: Engineering School
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth our gravest concern about the detrimental effects of the abolition of the Engineering School at Deakin University. We respectfully showeth that:

(1) The Engineering School at the Gordon Institute of Technology and now at Deakin University has been serving the Geelong region and Australia for the past 60 years. It would be the waste of a great service to the Australian public.
(2) The phasing out of Deakin University Engineering by not enrolling students in 1982 will greatly disadvantage students and lecturers via unemployment and curriculum difficulties.
(3) Geelong, being the largest industrial centre in Victoria outside Melbourne, will be disadvantaged industrially through the lack of locally trained engineers.
(4) Geelong students will have to put up with the inconvenience of travelling to other Victorian education centres for studies, as well as the expense of such a move.
(5) The Geelong community and small industries will be disadvantaged through the Deakin University Research and Consulting Engineers (DURAC) not being able to function.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you reverse the decision to abolish the Engineering School at Deakin University immediately for Australia's and Geelong's sake.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Fees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

(1) While the abolition of fees could not, in itself, provide all people with equal access to tertiary education, the reimposition of fees will make it even more difficult for people from ordinary families as well as women and mature-age students-who are already under represented-to commence or continue in tertiary education.

(2) The introduction of a comprehensive loans scheme, to cover tertiary fees, would undermine the TEAS scheme and force students and graduates into debt to finance companies. Such a scheme would inevitably discourage poorer students from attending post secondary education.

We, the undersigned, oppose any attempts to introduce tertiary fees or a comprehensive loans scheme for post secondary education, and call upon the Government to restate its commitment to free access to education, without fees or loans, and to assure students that no such options are under consideration for the 1981 Budget.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Staging of American B52 Bombers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned in the Northern Territory respectfully showeth:
That the proposed use of Darwin Airport as a refuelling and Rest and Recreation base of American B52 bombers:

Jeopardises the welfare of the citizens of Darwin and of all Australians, in that it establishes a stronger potential of Darwin being a nuclear target in any conflict between the USA and another power.
Impedes the sovereignty of the Australian nation in that Australian citizens would have neither control nor knowledge of whether B52s:
(a) Carried nuclear weapons.
(b) Were engaged in bombing missions against another state.
Violates the Australian people's independence and links this nation irreconcilably with United States foreign policies thereby destroying the potential for independent Australian defence policy.

Violates democratic procedures in committing the Australian nation to participation in future wars without due consultation and informed assessment by Australian citizens and further increases the militarisation of the Indian Ocean thereby increasing the likelihood of super power conflict in this region.
Jeopardises the welfare of the citizens of Darwin, in that noise, pollution and the threat of accidential radioactive fallout will increase substantially to the residents.
Negates the potential of the Australian nation to establish itself as a nation of peace in the Pacific region and violates Australia's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

Your petitioners' therefore pray that the members of the House of Representatives will ensure that the Prime Minister withdraw the offer of Darwin, or any other location in Australia, as a base or depot for American B52 bombers, and furthermore will ensure that any requests of such usage by the US Government be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley and Mr Kent.

PETITION.TITLE: Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the Dystrophic Epidermolysis Bullosa Research Association of Australia (DEBRAA) and their supporters respectfully shows that funds for medical research into epidermolysis bullosa are no longer being made available from the Federal Government to the medical research team at the University of New South Wales, enabling them to continue medical research into epidermolysis bullosa.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that these signatures contained on these forms will serve to make it known that we expect these funds to be forthcoming in the very near future.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Schools Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned members of parents and citizens associations respectively showeth:

That retention of the schools commission and the curriculum development centre in their present forms is essential for the balanced and progressive allocation of educational resources and facilities in the Australian community.

That serious concern has been generated by the Government's decision to reduce the involvement of the Schools Commission in program administration in the States, and the collections of information; its decision to alter the basis for providing subsidies for school buildings and other capital facilities; and the abolition of the curriculum development centre.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That the Government will reverse these decisions to ensure the continuation of the positive role of the Schools Commission in the assessment of needs and initiatives in education and the continued functioning of the curriculum development centre.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliamenmt assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth:
1. That we are gravely concerned at the lack of children's services within the City of Northcote.
2. That we are dismayed at the refusal of the Department of Social Security (Child Care Division) to fund a family day care program within the City of Northcote.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will ensure adequate funds for children's services will be made available so that family day care may be provided within the City of Northcote.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Two-airline Policy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That we protest most strongly against the present two-airline domestic policy of the Commonwealth Government.
That this policy has resulted in expensive air fares and poor service and discourages tourists from the eastern States visting WA, and vice versa.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will look favourably on our petition and formulate an airline policy providing for greater competition so that prices and service are determined by free market forces.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Garden Island, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:

That although cottages Numbers 11, 12, 13 and 14 on Garden Island in no way impede construction at HMAS Stirling, they are now required by the Department of Administrative Services to move by 30 June 1981.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:
Cottages Numbers 11, 12, 13 and 14 on Garden Island be allowed to remain and to move only when the remaining northern end cottages do so.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House expresses its deep regret at the death on 30 May of His Excellency President Ziaur Rahman, President of Bangladesh since 1977, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family and to the people of Bangladesh.

With the tragic assassination of President Ziaur, Bangladesh has lost a leader of zeal and, I believe, integrity. Bangladesh can ill afford his loss. His party, the Bangladesh National Party, won a substantial majority in democratic elections in 1979. One of the principal reasons for the success and popularity of the late President was his dedication to the development of rural Bangladesh and its immense population. President Ziaur worked hard to overcome the crushing problems of food shortages and poverty. Bangladesh, as many honourable gentlemen would know, has been high on Australia's list as a recipient of food aid and other assistance in recent years. President Ziaur was able to announce this year that food production in Bangladesh doubled during the previous 12 months. That was a remarkable record by any standard. In many respects this had become the primary objective of his Government. He personally spared no efforts either within his country or abroad to achieve that objective.

In the international context, President Ziaur had established himself as a leader of the least developed countries. The late President was highly respected by everyone for his views within the North-South debate. Within the non-aligned movement and the Islamic Conference he had established himself as an independent and moderate leader. President Ziaur was a strong supporter of the Commonwealth. I had many contacts with him through that Commonwealth link. It was especially gratifying that President Ziaur attended the first Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting held in Sydney in 1978. Australia was one of the first countries to recognise the newly independent nation of Bangladesh in 1971 and we sponsored its membership of the United Nations and of the Commonwealth. In the past 10 years the friendship between our two countries has strengthened. In the past year Bangladesh was the third largest recipient of Australian bilateral development aid and an increasingly important trade partner. The late President Ziaur was aware of these links. We discussed them together on many different occasions. We had discussed on many occasions how Australian aid could best assist Bangladesh and the achieving of objectives that he had for the people of Bangladesh.

The Australian Government and the Australian people were particularly shocked by the circumstance of President Ziaur's assassination. This is the third occasion in a matter of months on which a world leader has been the subject of political violence. Words cannot express the abhorrence that Australians must feel about these events. They deserve the strongest condemnation by all people. I am sure that all honourable members of this House and all Australians will join me in condemning this brutal act and in extending sympathy to the President's family and to the people of Bangladesh.

There is one other matter which I would like to add before asking the House to support this motion. When one hears of an assassination or an attempted assassination one feels, in intellectual terms, that it is an abhorrent and brutal thing and it attracts our total condemnation. But when at the same time one knows and has developed some degree of friendship with the person involved it takes on a dimension which is obviously more immediate. It is more personal and the feelings that one has are more compelling. It becomes to an extent a personal thing as well as an intellectual condemnation of the act. I had met the President on a large number of occasions. I had come to like and respect him. I am sure that all honourable members will support the strongest possible condemnation of this act being expressed by this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The murder of President Ziaur Rahman, the President of Bangladesh, is a tragedy for his country. President Ziaur was a hero of his country's liberation. It was he who first declared over the radio in March 1971 the revolt against Pakistan. He was a soldier, but he was more than that. After the assassination in 1975 of Shiek Mujibur, the first ruler of Bangladesh, followed by two further coups, General Ziaur took over as Martial Administrator, and effectively ruler, of his country until his death a few days ago. His five years as ruler of one of the very poorest nations in the world epitomised the great dilemmas faced by even the strongest and most incorruptible of men when faced with appalling poverty, extraordinary disparities of class and wealth, deep religious impulses and a population growing at extraordinary rates. About 90 million people live in a country two-thirds the size of Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: Restrictions on freedom of the Press and on political activities had all been present during President Ziaur's rule. But, at the same time, he made major if halting steps towards civilian rule and democracy. He ended the one-party rule of Shiek Mujibur, held presidential elections in 1977, parliamentary elections in 1979 and local elections in 1977. He felt compelled to abolish the strict principle of secularism both as a reflection of his own commitment to Islam and in consequence of the importance to his position of the Islamic-based political groups. Yet, for all that, he did not impose the sort of extremist theocracy or religious exclusivity of other Muslim states. In foreign policy he withdrew from the very close relationship between Shiek Mujibur and India, but he did not adopt the extreme anti-Indian posture many of his supporters wanted. Indeed, his refusal to indulge in xenophobic anti-Indianism seems to have been an important element in his assassination. More generally, he pursued a policy of firm non-alignment, with an openness to the West which allowed Australia, the first Western country to recognise the new state in 1971, to build a close relationship.

President Ziaur will be remembered most of all for his rejection of the economic philosophy summarised in the phrase 'trickle-down effect', a theory which has few credible adherents these days. Briefly, this philosophy was that as long as the rich of a developing country got richer, as long as an industrial, bureaucratic and technological elite was successfully established, the benefits would eventually trickle down through other strata of society. President Ziaur, himself incorruptible, believed in grass roots development. He instituted a major and geniune land distribution program, devoted resources to increasing food production to such an effect that he had been able to ask for a 40 per cent reduction in food aid in 1981-82, undertook serious birth control programs, and funded at the local level public works such as bridges, roads and irrigation, which would provide employment for the ordinary people. He travelled endlessly to the most remote regions and smallest villages of his country, urging the participation of ordinary people and instilling an urgency and vigour into economic development. That this task was only just begun is true, but the relative stability and complete honesty he brought to government and his practical concern for his people rather than for the elite showed the way for any chance of overcoming the problems of his country. His nation is the poorer for his passing

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett Dr N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of a parliamentary delegation from this Parliament to Bangladesh, where we were welcomed by the late President of Bangladesh, I wish to add a few words on this motion. President Ziaur Rahman was, for all practical purposes, an authoritarian military leader. But to leave assessment there without regard for the tumultuous history of his country or for the inappropriateness of Western values and classifications in an environment vastly different from that of our own would be to do great injustice to the man and to his work.

SPEECH.PARA: Ambitious as the President undoubtedly was, it was an ambition not for himself but for his people and, above all, for the peasants of Bangladesh. The President led a completely unostentatious lifestyle, continuing to live with his wife and two sons in a modest apartment in the military cantonment in Dacca. In a society frequently damaged by political corruption, his personal integrity and honesty were never impugned by his critics or by his enemies. He could be ruthless, which was a virtual necessity for survival in the politics of Bangladesh but in nearly all cases his firmness was tempered by justice and magnanimity. In the last years of his rule there had been a distinct improvement in the respect for political and human rights in Bangladesh. In the election of 1979, for example, opposition parties scored a greater representation than in any previous Bangladeshi or East Pakistani parliament.

President Ziaur Rahman dedicated himself to the alleviation of the poverty of the rural masses through a massive village development program. His intimate involvement in this program was reflected in his continual travel by helicopter, by jeep, and on foot throughout the villages of Bangladesh. Indeed, it has been argued that no contemporary Asian ruler had so intimate a contact as ruler with the masses of his people. It is a tragedy for Bangladesh that it should have lost a President with so much of his potential unfulfilled. It would be an even greater tragedy if his death opened a further bloodstained chapter in the troubled history of that country.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr MALCOLM FRASER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) left Australia on 30 May to attend the sixty-seventh session of the International Labour Conference in Geneva, where I understand he is shortly to be joined by the shadow Minister for industrial relations.

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Hawke-Thank you, Mr Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is bipartisanship. If we practise it there is no knowing where it will ultimately end. The Minister for Education (Mr Fife) is acting as Minister for Industrial Relations until Mr Viner returns on 22 June with or without the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke).

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications. As a result of information being given to media interests on proposed or possible amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act, whether in discussion, as the Minister will have us believe, or by prior supply of written material, as is much more credible, has any documentary response been made to the Government by any such interest since 9 April?
—Yes.

—Is the Minister for Transport aware of the concern being expressed by aircraft owners and the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association of Australia in particular about increases in private aircraft navigation fees? Are the suggestions of increases of up to 300 per cent for private aircraft and of up to 700 per cent for charter aircraft navigation fees correct? Can the Minister inform the House of the current position in relation to the proposals for fee increases?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the concern of the general aviation industry at the general aviation study that was commissioned in 1978 to report on cost recovery in the general aviation sector. At present there is more than a 100 per cent cost recovery for the international airlines. Under legislation before the House the domestic carriers will have to meet approximately 100 per cent of cost recovery. The regional airlines are currently meeting about 30 per cent and general aviation about 14 per cent. However, the recommendations contained in that study, are a matter of great concern to the general aviation industry which is fundamental to aviation in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: I announced to this House not very long ago that we would be extending the period until 30 June to enable the general aviation industry to report formally to the Government on the recommendations contained in that study. At that time I said-I repeat-that the Government will not be taking any decisions that will undermine the viability of this very important section of the aviation industry in Australia.

In due course I will be discussing this matter with my colleagues in the Government in the light of replies that have been received from various sectors of the general aviation industry. I know that the honourable member for Mitchell addressed a large gathering of the general aviation industry in Sydney recently. He made it quite clear to that gathering that the Government had not committed itself to the recommendations in that report.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Communications, refers to his answers to questions asked last week in which he admitted that discussions had taken place with broadcasting media interests on amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act but left unanswered the question of whether draft Bills had been supplied by the Government to such interests. Will he now confirm that neither draft copies of the amendment Bill nor any written material describing proposals were supplied to any media interests?

—The Opposition seems to have a peculiar attitude about consultation. I have made it quite plain in this place that I have talked to a range of people about the proposed details of legislation which affects a very important part of media opportunity in Australia. For the electronic media licences are issued under a system which has been set down by procedures which are enacted in the Broadcasting and Television Act, which is about to be amended. I have certainly consulted extensively and I have discussed the details of the legislation extensively. I will continue to do so until such stage as the legislation is introduced into the Parliament.

—Is the Minister for Trade and Resources aware of the details of recent announcements relating to the future of oil shale deposits at Rundle and Condor in Queensland? Can the Esso company yet be regarded as a reliable partner in the Rundle project, and can the Minister advise the House of the effect of these moves on the development of alternative energy sources in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of the last week there have been very significant developments in arrangements for feasibility studies and the development of some of Australia's huge oil shale deposits. Early in the week there was an announcement that the Esso company and the Australian partners, Central Pacific Minerals NL and Southern Pacific Petroleum NL, had reviewed the previous heads of agreement and had now come to an agreement to proceed with investigating the development of the Rundle deposit. These new heads of agreement really enable the partners to go into direct commercial development rather than setting up a demonstration arrangement. I think this vindicates the confidence that the Government, and indeed the Australian people, had in the hopes of this partnership becoming a reality. I think it condemns members of the Opposition for some of the remarks they made questioning the previous heads of agreement.

ANSWER.PARA: Later in the week there was also an announcement that the Central Pacific and Southern Pacific companies had come to an agreement with the Japan National Oil Corporation, which heads up a whole series of Japanese companies, to do a feasibility study on the Condor deposit, further north in Queensland. They will spend $US24m on a feasibility study over the next two years. Both these developments will require an enormous amount of capital, but I think the events of the last week are an indication of the confidence that overseas interests have in developing oil shale as a possible alternative source of oil. I certainly welcome these decisions and I am sure the rest of Australia welcomes the chance to develop alternative forms of energy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Communications which is supplementary to that asked of him by the honourable member for Macquarie. I ask whether he will now confirm or deny that draft copies of the Broadcasting and Television Amendment Bill and/or any written material describing those proposals were supplied to any media interests?

—I have said yes, that I have consulted with media interests. I have consulted with everybody. I have consulted on the details of the Bills to be introduced. I have consulted with lawyers. I am continuing to do so.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hayden

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. This answer is unnecessarily provocative at Question Time.

INTERJECT.PARA: Government members-Ha, ha!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Hayden

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to avoid describing the indulgence of the Minister, in his usual tactic, in evading the truth.

INTERJECT.PARA: Government members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Members opposite say 'Oh!'
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition will make his point of order.

—The Minister is not answering the questions. On the basis of evidence available to us there is a very strong suggestion that in fact he engaged in behaviour in association with some media interests--

—The honourable gentleman will resume his seat. There is no point of order. The honourable gentleman well knows that, provided the answer is relevant, there is no way I can require a Minister to answer in the form which the questioner may wish.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Hicks proceeding to address a question to the Acting Minister for Primary Industry-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is out of order.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Did the Minister representing the Prime Minister in another place say on 1 April, firstly, that 'it is a well accepted universal practice' for a Minister to disclose any pecuniary interest he or his family may have in matters being discussed by Cabinet; and, secondly, that he was unaware that any Minister had indicated such an interest in discussions on proposed changes to the broadcasting and television legislation? Do Northern Rivers Television Ltd, Richmond-Tweed Television Ltd, Richmond River Broadcasters and Tweed Radio and Broadcasting Company have an interest in this legislation? Is the wife of the Deputy Prime Minister a shareholder in these and other companies involved in regional broadcasting and television, in whose defence the Deputy Prime Minister is reported to have been an active campaigner within the Government? Did the Deputy Prime Minister declare his family pecuniary interest to Cabinet in discussions concerning the changes to the Broadcasting and Television Act, as recommended in paragraph 8.6 of the Bowen report? Finally, did the Deputy Prime Minister then abstain from taking part and from expressing a view in these deliberations or secure the explicit authorisation of his colleagues to take part or to express a view, also as recommended by the Bowen report?

—It is well known that the Bowen report, as recommended, has been applied in the case of Ministers. I think all honourable members will know that I had stated on many occasions, and before the Bowen Committee in fact reported, that there were very real difficulties in relation to declarations because how far does one go-does one include a member, a member's wife, family, children and all the rest? Do not people who are not members of this Parliament, under the normal rules of privacy that we would expect, have the right to their own lives and their own circumstances? The Deputy Prime Minister has reminded me that a declaration was made in relation to those circumstances. Any imputations in the honourable member's question about the nature of argument that might be put would be quite false.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SITING OF SECOND INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT IN SYDNEY

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Administrative Services aware of recent Press reports which claim that certain land exchange deals between New South Wales and the Commonwealth have been negotiated to provide a location for a second international airport in Sydney? Can the Minister provide information to this Parliament regarding these negotiations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman The Hon K.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The newspaper reports referred to in the honourable member's question have been brought to my notice. I think the report appeared in a newspaper called the Voice. In that newspaper report essentially two things were said. First of all the newspaper claimed that sources close to the committee carrying out a study into the needs for a second Sydney international airport had confirmed that Holsworthy would be the site for the second airport. As well, the honourable member for Hughes was quoted as saying that the sources that he has in the Department of Transport had confirmed to him that Holsworthy was a serious consideration. I can tell the honourable member for Barton and other honourable members that both of these suggestions are quite incorrect and untrue. In respect of the consideration by the committee, I think it is true to say that my colleague the Minister for Transport has already advised the honourable member for Hughes that as long ago as 1978 the committee, for a number of reasons, had rejected Holsworthy as being a likely site.

ANSWER.PARA: As to land exchange deals with the Government of New South Wales, the question of Holsworthy as a second site has never been raised. It is true that in the various parcels of land that have been exchanged, Holsworthy is one that has just latterly been determined; but it has been determined for defence needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to add to an answer.
—By indulgence of the Chair the right honourable gentleman may add to an answer which he has given.

—I am advised that the wife of the Deputy Prime Minister has held a small parcel of shares in the companies mentioned since the stations began something like 20 years ago and receives out of it all an annual income of something like $80.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Communications. In the context of the consultations which he said took place between certain media interests and representatives of the Government, at his direction, to discuss proposed amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act, were any draft copies of the amendment Bill and/or any written material relating to the proposals supplied to any media interests?
—They have certainly been discussed, as I have explained before. Written copies, draft copies, of the details of the proposed legislation have been discussed.
—With a reputation like yours, why would you expect us to believe you?

—If I had a reputation like the honourable member's I would be ashamed to hold my head in public, but that is another story. In case anybody in this place is mistaken, I certainly have discussed details of proposed changes to the legislation, but I have shown the final draft of the Bill to nobody except the legislation committee of Cabinet and to the back bench committee at a meeting this morning.

—Is the Treasurer aware that pension-age eligible people are depositing tens of thousands of dollars, frequently obtained in lump sum payments from superannuation, in non-interest bearing investments and bank accounts to enable them to reduce their incomes and so be eligible for the pension? Is he also aware that banks and institutions are openly encouraging people to take this course of action, thereby enabling such institutions to reap a windfall from lending the non-cost capital at up to 20 per cent? Is the Treasurer concerned that people, having made provision for their old age, are through these practices costing the Government and therefore other taxpayers countless millions of dollars? Will the Government give consideration to taking into account non-interest bearing capital and investment in assessing eligibility for pensions and thereby providing pensions only for the needy?

—My attention has been drawn to this matter. I think some of these practices are a consequence of the liberalisation of the tests for eligibility for the pension. To do what the honourable gentleman suggested would constitute, on my quick assessment-I stress that it is a quick assessment-a reversion to some kind of asset or means test as distinct from a pure income test and would, therefore, be contrary to the decision of this Government, promised in the 1975 policy speech and implemented in 1976, to remove the property component of the means test. Having said that, I will certainly analyse the other parts of the honourable gentleman's question. I thank him for drawing the matter to my attention.

—I ask the Minister for Communications a question which is supplementary to the succession I have had to direct to him this afternoon. In the context of his last answer, in which he said that the final draft had not been provided for any source outside the Government, can we presume that drafts or a draft other than the final draft were provided for the attention of outside media interests?

—Drafts have been discussed. The honourable gentleman seems not to understand ordinary English. In order to ensure that the details of this legislation meet with the requirements of the community, the Government has engaged and is engaging in extensive consultations on the details of the proposed legislation. We are not providing legislation. We are talking about details of changes. Drafts have been discussed, yes. Drafts have been discussed with a range of people. They are still being discussed with a range of people and will be discussed until the final form is introduced into the House.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport. In the light of legislation presently before the House regarding the restructuring of the airline system, I ask: Does the Minister envisage an increasing dependence on general aviation to fill the gaps which could result from the major airlines withdrawing from unprofitable routes? The Minister will be aware that Transport Australia proposes to introduce substantial cost increases. Is the Minister alert to the fact that when the need arises to fill the gaps the Government could be faced with a situation where general aviation operators have been forced out of business or alternatively have passed on costs which would raise air fares to country travellers to a prohibitive level? Will the Minister defer cost increases to general aviation until Australia's total air service requirements may be more accurately assessed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Government considers the general aviation study report it will undoubtedly take into account the state of the general aviation industry and the package of Bills introduced into the Parliament which will have a very significant bearing on the shape of the aviation industry for the future. It is true that in clause 12 of the two airlines agreement there is provision for airlines to make application to the Government after six months of having established a consistent loss record. They will have an opportunity of providing a three months notice to terminate services over those sections of the routes. This will have particular importance to the State of Queensland.

ANSWER.PARA: We had a conference yesterday with the airline representatives to obtain certain undertakings from them.
