Clause 12 provides the opportunity for discussions to take place between the airlines and the Government to ensure there is satisfactory transition from unsuitable services-those services that have excess capacity and are being run at a loss-to more economic use of equipment and services. This of course may involve the introduction of other services being operated by the general aviation industry. Of course, the Government will take into account the need to sustain a viable general aviation industry to serve that purpose in the course of considering the general aviation study.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Treasurer admit to selected journalists in infamous background briefings recently that the inflation rate for 1981-82 is expected by the Government to be 11 per cent? Does this not mean that the Government's anti-inflation strategy is a failure? Does this not also mean that the States have been forced to agree to transfer payments effectively at least 2 per cent less than the inflation rate? If these are the facts, as the funds going to the States represent, of course, a cut in real terms, is it the policy of this Government to encourage the States to increase taxes and charges-which is happening in South Australia now-thus taking away the people's money, to use a famous phrase, or is it the policy of the Government to encourage the States to reduce their services and employment?
—The honourable gentleman will draw his question to a close.

—I can assure the honourable member for Adelaide that it is the policy of this Government to continue the policies that produced a non-farm growth of 6.5 per cent in the first half of this financial year.

—I refer the Minister for Communications to a Press statement issued today to members of this House and another place regarding FM broadcasting proposals for the Coffs Harbour area. I ask the Minister to clarify the action necessary under the Broadcasting and Television Act regarding the calling for and issue of FM public broadcasting licences. Was a preliminary planning proposal for broadcasting-both FM and AM-on the mid-North Coast issued late last year? Was time allowed for further submissions on the proposal, as provided for in the Broadcasting and Television Act? Are these submissions currently under consideration? Do the anticipated amendments to the Act have a bearing on the matter? Finally, has the Government acted in accordance with undertakings given to have all related procedures followed in dealing with the needs of the Coffs Harbour area in respect of broadcasting services?

—It is certainly true that radio station CHY is anxious to go on the air. I can understand that. It has made a series of representations to me, as it did to my predecessor. Indeed, as I understand it, the draft planning proposals were first discussed between Mr Staley and representatives of the station in September 1979. There are, however, quite real problems in developing a comprehensive plan for both amplitude modulation and frequency modulation broadcasting in the north coast area. These plans are going ahead as quickly as possible and, no doubt, subject to the contents of some proposed changes to the Broadcasting and Television Bill, could well be facilitated as part of the passage of the Bill. I recognise the desire of the honourable gentleman, however, to take note of all the conflicting interests of the area to ensure that, whatever the extensions of the media might be, they both meet the requirements of the community and ensure that there are adequate and viable broadcasting alternatives throughout the region. I hope that it will be possible to come forward with final proposals shortly.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the fact that the United Nations ad hoc committee on an Indian Ocean peace zone will meet in New York this week to determine whether a conference at ministerial or heads of government level will take place this year on a peace zone proposal. I ask the Minister: What instructions has he given to the Australian delegation on the conference issue? Does the Australian Government intend to continue to oppose a conference in 1981 as it did at a similar meeting last March? If so, why? Does the Government remain committed to the Indian Ocean peace zone proposal? If so, will it entertain participation in a conference on this matter should it be held this year despite any opposition from the Australian Government?

—It is quite true that the Australian Government shares the objective of the zone of peace concept for the Indian Ocean. Recent events-first and foremost, of course, the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan-have made that extremely difficult to achieve. We believe that should a conference be held it would best be held in an atmosphere in which it had some chance of success. We do not come to the judgment that the present circumstances are likely to result in a successful conclusion. We would prefer to wait until that is a possibility.

—I have a short question for the Minister for Housing and Construction which I hope will elicit a concise answer. My question relates to an answer which the Minister gave on Tuesday, 26 May, to the honourable member for Bendigo about the net value of Commonwealth payments to the States for housing. I ask: What is the total value of repayments of capital and interest due to be paid to the Commonwealth by the States in 1981? What amount of repayments will be incurred under the new arrangements for 1981-82? Is it not a fact that next year's repayments by the States will exceed the value of funds they will receive under the new arrangements for housing assistance next year?

—I have to admit that I do not have the exact figures. The situation is that Commonwealth-State housing agreements have been in existence since 1945. In the first year of the arrangement a sum of slightly in excess of $13m was made available. Under last year's proposals the sum of $285m was made available. Quite obviously, each year when the States are repaying those sums with interest over a term of 53 years they are paying back more than they did the previous year. Consequently, quite obviously as we approach 1998 the repayments will reach their height. It is wrong for the honourable member for Grayndler to try to equate payments of interest and redemption by the States over 53 years with a contribution by the Commonwealth in one year. It must also be remembered that the States do not repay money to the Commonwealth with their own funds; those repayments are made by the ordinary citizens, the Jacks and Jills of Australian society. They come from the ordinary, hard-working Australian who pays his or her weekly rent or monthly repayment. They do not come out of the coffers of the State. I am glad I have been given the opportunity of at least educating the honourable member for Grayndler--
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I inform the Minister that an amount of $200.3m was repaid this year by the States to the Commonwealth.
—There is no point of order. I suggest that the Minister return to the figures.

—These payments are made out of the household savings and income of the ordinary person. It is wrong, therefore, for the honourable member for Grayndler to try to imply that the States are repaying this money. When I look at the figures I am astonished sometimes at the generosity of the present Government.
—I ask the Minister to bring his answer to a conclusion.

—Very generous terms are made available by the Commonwealth. In the legislation which we will be debating later today, we are making moneys available at an interest rate of 4 1/2 per cent, notwithstanding the current rates. Of course, general interest rates under the Labor Government showed an alarming increase from 1972 to 1975. Bank loan interest rates went up from 7 per cent to 11 per cent.
—The honourable gentleman will draw his answer to a conclusion.

—On account of the generous terms made available to the States, the States, by taking the money, repaying it and recycling it, and after meeting all administrative and maintenance costs, are able to show a surplus of $142m this financial year. The honourable member's question was very long and important and I wanted to answer it, unlike my usual style, in some depth.
—The honourable gentleman will bring his answer to a conclusion or I will require him to resume his seat.

—I conclude on this note: The sum total of funds made available for welfare housing in Australia is made up of the very significant contribution made by the Commonwealth, plus those surpluses plus input by the States. I would only hope that when the State Premiers come to--
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Is it a fact that State government activity in promoting private health insurance will be a factor in assessing health revenue raising experience in 1981-82? If that is so, and given the legislative pressure by the Commonwealth Government to force people into the private health funds, I ask: In what way does private health insurance differ significantly from any other form of regressive taxation and in what way do private health agencies differ significantly from other taxation agencies?

—The factors to be taken into consideration in the assessment of the States' performances in relation to the new health changes have not finally been decided. At the most recent Health Ministers conference I suggested on behalf of the Commonwealth some factors which may be taken into consideration. I also suggested that there should be a meeting of State officials and Commonwealth officials as soon as possible so that we could get to an agreed position, if that is possible. In relation to health insurance, the Commonwealth's position and the position of these parties is very well established. We believe it is incumbent upon people who can afford to do so to make some provision for their health care costs. They have the choice; they can either pay the costs out of their own pockets or they can join a health insurance fund. Of course, the other side of the coin is that this Government firmly believes that those people in genuine need should be assisted. We believe that scarce public moneys can best be directed towards those most in need by the arrangements that are being put in place by the Government.

—I direct my question to the Acting Minister for Primary Industry. What savings and/or benefits will result, firstly, to the Government, secondly, to the Australian Wool Corporation, thirdly, to wool growers, and fourthly, to wool users, by the disposal of the Australian Wool Testing Authority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot quantify the exact sums that will be saved in accordance with the matter the honourable gentleman put forward, but I think a couple of things need to be recognised. The first is that to date, the Australian Wool Testing Authority has been run entirely under the embrace of the Australian Wool Corporation. Whilst it is true that the Australian Wool Corporation is funded, essentially, from levies that result from legislation passed through this House, those funds do represent growers' funds. They represent money that at the moment is set aside in a way which covers the operation of the reserve scheme and the degree to which funds are necessary to buy wool and to maintain the level of the general reserve established by the industry each year. They also cover various expenses relating to the administration of the wool stores and so on. The constitution of the Australian Wool Testing Authority, as a new body, will enable the freeing of those moneys that are presently used through the Australian Wool Corporation's account. It is hoped that, by the involvement of all those concerned in the industry, growers' money can henceforth be used for other purposes of the Australian Wool Corporation rather than for the Australian Wool Testing Authority.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, the Australian Wool Testing Authority operates in a commercial area. It is a body which gives certain undertakings. As a result of discussion between the Minister for Primary Industry and the Prime Minister, agreement has been reached on the basis of the continuity of the necessary guarantees to ensure that the certificates provided in that area are maintained and the guarantees required by the trade continued. Indeed, there has been an understanding that there will be no hiatus in the change from the present constitution to the new constitution to ensure that there is no interruption to wool selling procedures. It is true that, as it is a body that is operating in the commercial market place, there seems to be a very real reason for it to be constituted, therefore, in the market place. The exact basis on which it is to be constituted, however, is a matter which will be finally concluded between my colleague the Minister for Primary Industry and the industry to ensure that all the requirements of the industry are met. However, I believe that the freeing of the money from the Australian Wool Corporation's account which will result from its being separately constituted will ulti- mately mean a saving of money to the wool grower.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. To what extent will regulation and control of nuclear activities be devolved on the State and Northern Territory governments, as was so vaguely outlined in the Review of Commonwealth Functions? Does the Government intend eventually leaving environmental assessment of uranium projects, waste disposal techniques, mining safety procedures and production levels to the decision of competing State governments? Will this proposed reduced Federal responsibility involve amendments to the Atomic Energy Act and other Federal legislation? If it is not intended to proceed on these matters, will the Minister now tell us why these outrageous proposals were included in the razor gang's report in the first place?

—It was made quite clear in the Prime Minister's announcement of the decisions arising out of the Review of Commonwealth Functions that the Commonwealth's essential interests in this matter would be maintained. The extent to which authority and responsibility are handed over to the Territory in respect of environmental matters will be against that background of the retention by the Commonwealth of its essential interests. Its concern and interest in relation to the uranium industry are clearly known to members of this House.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr O'Keefe proceeding to address a question to the Minister for Trade and Resources-

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable gentleman's question is out of order.

—My question, which is directed to the Prime Minister, refers to his reply to my question without notice on 11 March which concerned the proposed removal of the unemployment benefit for people under the age of 18 years. Will the Government end speculation and anxiety on this matter by completely rejecting this proposal now? If not, when will a determination be made on this matter? Further, when will the Government announce plans for financial assistance to people under the age of 18 years so that more young people-especially from low income families-can afford to remain at school and gain reasonable qualifications and skills?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of the honourable gentleman's question cannot be answered until such time as we, in co-operation with the States and the education authorities, have established education and training opportunities for all young Australians, especially those young Australians who now do not have opportunities because there are not the courses that attract their inclinations or meet their talents. Of course, that is something that we have been pursuing for the last several months, very much as a result of a report of the Schools Commission to which the honourable member for Wills drew attention a week or so ago. I understand that my colleagues have made a good deal of progress with the States and the Cabinet has had reports from them in relation to that. Some of the results of these reports will be revealed when the Minister for Education makes a statement to the House at the appropriate time.

ANSWER.PARA: Quite plainly, when some tens of thousands of young people under the age of 18 years are presently in receipt of the unemployment benefit, it indicates the great task that has to be undertaken in making sure that the education system has places for all those who otherwise would be in that category. That is the first thing that we have to do, if we can, in co-operation with the States.

The second thing, of course, is a budgetary matter; that is, an examination of the adequacy of allowances. I am sure the honourable gentleman would not be interested to know-I will advise him in any case-that I was Minister for Education when the present secondary allowance scheme was introduced. I was concerned that the trend towards more and more young Australians staying at school for the last two years of secondary schooling would pose a problem and a difficulty for low income families. Part of this examination is to test the adequacy of the allowances that might be available if young Australians can be attracted into full time training.

It is only when these two things have been done adequately and to the satisfaction of the Government that we would then consider that third question. If one has a situation where there are good and appropriate-appropriate to the talents and needs of individuals-training opportunities available for all people under the age of 18 years and if at the same time one has the situation where the interests of low income families are protected, it is then, but only then, fair enough to ask that other question about the unemployment benefit. So nobody need have any fear about the circumstances that exist at the moment. Indeed, I believe the more the community understands our objectives in these matters the more it will applaud our efforts to make sure that there are adequate training opportunities for all young Australians. That is certainly much better than that which the present system offers them-a school system which is not suited to their needs, that does not attract them, but leaves them with a feeling of frustration and failure which, more often than not, is the fault of the school rather than the students. Then that becomes compounded by a great difficulty for people in this category being able to get a job. We owe those young Australians something much better than that. The Government has set about trying to achieve something better than that. I hope that we would have the support of all honourable members in that objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Treasurer undertake to review the legislation providing taxation concessions for the film industry so that the legislation agrees with the proposals originally announced by the Government?
—Since legislation was introduced into the House last week to give effect to, in relative terms, an extremely generous concession to a section of the Australian community--
—You can say that again.

—It is a very generous concession, providing a write-off of something like 150 per cent and also exemptions from tax in respect of 50 per cent of the income. Since that legislation was introduced there have been a number of representations to the Government from sections of the film industry and from others. The Government is presently considering those representations. Its response to them will be made known either today or tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present the text of a statement by the Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Carrick) on the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources.

—I understand the honourable member for La Trobe wishes to make a request for detailed information from me concerning one of the parliamentary departments.
—Yes, Mr Speaker. I seek information in relation to the operation of certain parliamentary departments.

—I understand the honourable gentleman has given his question to the Clerk. If it is in order it will be printed in Hansard, and in due course I will give a reply, which also will be printed in Hansard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris Mr P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Does the honourable gentleman wish to make a personal explanation?
—I do.
—He may proceed.

—In the Daily Mirror of yesterday's date, on page 8, in a feature column entitled 'PS' edited by one Debbie Tarrant, there appears an article headed 'Taking refuge in Hansard'. The article purports to cover the proceedings surrounding last Thursday morning's incident at Question Time. It states that following the day's proceedings 'MPs and their staff rushed for a copy of Hansard, the official parliamentary transcript, on Friday to examine at what exact point of Mal's grandiose delivery' certain incidents occurred. It states that 'persons noted with extreme interest that a number of not quite-in-order comments' were made by me. Without going into all the text of the article-it is there to be read-the article also notes that Hansard failed to record the interjections that I made. It concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: But somehow those normally thorough transcriptions omitted the verbal interruptions.

The article notes that as being peculiar. I find the article malicious. Its inferences are without foundation. It implies that the Hansard record was suppressed by me, by Hansard or by someone else. It implies that my interjections were not a coincidence. They were a coincidence to subsequent events. The article labels as peculiar the Hansard staff not having recorded interjections and questions the propriety of the interjections. For the record, my interjections were 'what about a dollar for the kids?' and 'This is costing about $12m'.

Mr Speaker, you are aware and I think can confirm that the practice followed by Hansard in recording interjections is that unless the interjections are responded to they are not recorded. That is my understanding of the practice followed by Hansard. Accordingly, the interjections were not suppressed by me. I did not see the greens. In fact I did not read the Hansard of the events until I noticed this article yesterday evening. I do not believe anybody else suppressed the interjections. No member of the Press Gallery rushed around on Friday morning looking for a copy of Hansard or looking for information on the interjections. I was in this building and I saw no members of Parliament or Press reporters gallivanting about in the building. Given the privations being suffered today by thousands of women and children of broken families, I find it regrettable that rather than recognising the plight of these unfortunates, particularly those in women's refuges, the columnist chose instead to impugn my integrity for making the comments which I made, and which I stand by, and to impugn the integrity of Hansard for carrying out its duties in its traditional manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to part of what was said by the honourable member for Shortland, it is the practice of this House, on the direction of the Presiding Officer-I have maintained that practice-that if an interjection is made but is not noticed by the person speaking at the time, it is not recorded in Hansard. The matter raised by the honourable member also gives me the opportunity to make a personal explanation. Sometimes an interjection heard by members of the House may be offensive but I do not order the interjection to be withdrawn because the person speaking has elected to proceed with his speech. Therefore, the interjection is not included in the Hansard record. This is particularly the case when a second reading speech or some set-piece statement is being delivered to the House.
