DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO PERU, VENEZUELA AND BRAZIL

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the official report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Peru, Venezuela and Brazil. Mr Speaker, I wish to pay a tribute to the leadership which you gave in the early part of the delegation's visit and to the leadership which Senator Young from another place gave during the rest of the visit. I would also like to pay tribute to the work and assistance given by Mr John Dyer, the secretary to the delegation. Without his support and constant attention to detail, I am sure that the delegation would not have achieved the success which I believe it did. I know I express the views of all members of the delegation in that regard. I believe the delegation did a great deal to further good will between Australia and the South American nations we visited.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnson The Hon L.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I join with the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Jarman) in paying tribute to the leaders of our delegation to South America and to the staff members who assisted in such an effective and assiduous way. There are very great lessons to learn from South America. We learned a great deal, first of all, about South American hospitality. Mr Speaker, it was an honour for the Parliament that you were accorded something like the freedom of the city of Cuzco when we visited that place. It was an historical visit as it was the occasion when the country was transferring from dictatorship to democracy. It is significant to say that we were treated with the utmost importance.

SPEECH.PARA: Peru is one of the most impoverished countries in the world, and it has a very high rate of inflation. It seems to me that the new regime will have an extremely difficult time in overcoming those problems. The new President, Fernando Belaunde Terry, is setting out to create one million jobs through co-operatives and to create state companies. He also aims to reduce the foreign debt to 25 per cent of exports. I understand that the inflation rate was running at approximately 160 per cent, although nobody knew the precise situation and there were various accounts of it. The state debt, for example, was $6 billion.

One could gain the impression in Venezuela only that it was a country on the move. There was a very great sense of pride about the achievements and about projects that were being put in hand. It was very interesting to note the size and success of the state-owned gas-fired steel industry; the iron ore mining company, which also is a state instrumentality; the state aluminium company, which is in partnership with a Japanese concern. Enormous hydro projects are under construction, and pine growing projects have resulted in 160 million trees being planted on 350,000 acres. One of the most impressive industrial developments in Venezuela is that pertaining to the oil industry. The state-owned oil company, Petroven, which has been operating since 1975, has the inside running and is returning enormous profits to the people. We visited the great oil centre of Lake Maracaibo, where over 1,000 oil wells are producing about 900,000 barrels of oil a day, or 80 per cent of the nation's production. It is very interesting to note that the state-owned company has taken over responsibility for exploration, refining, transportation and marketing. This kind of thing is happening on a very wide scale throughout South America generally.

The literacy rate in Venezuela presents enormous problems, being at a very low level. One-quarter of the adult population is illiterate. There is a very inadequate distribution of the nation's income, with 20 per cent of the population earning two-thirds of the national income and the poorest 20 per cent earning only 8 per cent of the national income. There is a great deal to be learnt from the enterprising spirit in evidence in that country. In Brazil we could be only impressed by the effectiveness of the state oil body. A great deal is being done to develop ethanol as a major fuel. At present the Volkswagen car industry is orientated mainly to the use of ethanol, and of course the Volkswagen car manufactured in that country is the predominant vehicle. I understand that probably 250,000 alcoholic cars, if I could use that term, will be using this fuel by the end of the year. Australia could learn a great deal from this process, which converts sugar cane to a very effective fuel. Apparently, it is 50 per cent cheaper than ordinary petrol but slightly less efficient, and the overall net effect is very advantageous.

A wealth of information is contained in the report which has been tabled today. Regrettably, the report does not mention-it could not mention-the visit which was made to Chile on an unofficial basis as the delegation was returning from its official itinerary. The regime in that country has caused enormous disruption and has subjected many people to very great injustices. It has subdued the trade union movement and, in many ways, has reduced the whole cause of democracy to a most demeaning state. Any member of the delegation who took part in that unofficial visit to Chile would be able to provide information that could be of extremely great value to people who are interested in the pursuit of democracy. I pay tribute to you, Mr Speaker, as the leader of the delegation in Peru, and to Senator Young, who led the delegation for the other parts of the journey. I believe that enormous benefit has been derived as a consequence, certainly for Australia and, I hope, for the people of Brazil, Venezuela and Peru.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I could not complete the journey and went only to the installation of President Belaunde in Peru. I regret that I could not carry forward because the delegation was an excellent team. Its members applied themselves most assiduously to finding out information, which was the purpose of the journey. I make a comment in passing about Peru, which has experienced the most extraordinary set of circumstances. President Belaunde was elected by democratic process and overthrown by what was termed a left wing military coup. It must have been the most unique military coup in the world. Shortly afterwards, there was a subsequent military coup on the persons who themselves had formed government by military coup. After 10 or 12 years-I have forgotten exactly-the military government got into such a mess that it decided to turn government over to the democratic process once again. Lo and behold, who should win the election but President Belaunde, who had been overthrown by a military coup a decade earlier. The return to democracy was very much appreciated by the people, and we were very glad to have participated in the triumphant return to democracy of one of the great South American states.

—I seek your indulgence, Mr Speaker, to raise a matter. Some time last year I approached you and also spoke in this House about revised sitting hours. This matter has been discussed by the parties and throughout the Parliament for a period of 12 months. I understand that you are proposing to take some action regarding the sitting hours. Can you inform the House what you have in mind?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be happy to do that. In the time I have been in this chamber there have been many occasions on which members have wished to change the sitting hours to suit contemporary requirements. Experiments have been carried out on a variety of times, but after a short period each of those experiments has failed and we have returned to the sitting hours which I have known throughout the period I have been here, except for very minor variations. The honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) raised this matter with me. Generally, it was apparent that the time had arrived when a great number of honourable members wished the issue of sitting hours to be looked at again. Therefore, I felt that it was a responsibility in that I had to do what I could to bring the matter forward for determination. Consideration was made by certain members of the Government parties who then approached me for my response. I thought the most convenient way to determine the matter was to reduce it to two alternatives, that is, to continue with the present hours or with different hours.

INTERJECT.PARA: The different hours proposed after some discussions were quite different, in the sense that at the present we are locked into two situations. One is not to sit during meal hours. I believe it is not necessary for us to rise during meal hours. I add that if we sit during meal hours the debate would not want to be interrupted by calls for quorums or divisions. There would have to be an understanding between all honourable members that quorums and divisions should not be called during the meal break. There is no reason why the business of the House cannot go forward during that time. That is a point that can be discovered whether it works or not. The other point that must be made I think is that we have been locked in by a second factor, which is that under the Standing Orders the proceedings commence with prayers, petitions, et cetera, and, most importantly, questions without notice. In other parliaments of the world questions without notice, or the particular variation of that procedure in that parliament, do not necessarily follow immediately after prayers and petitions.

I have had discussions with party leaders. It has been indicated to me by party leaders on both sides of the House that before a response is given they would wish to have the matter discussed in the party rooms, that is, the Caucus or Government party rooms. What I had in mind is that if there is a consensus established by the party room meetings we could formulate the provision to go ahead. Otherwise it is my intention, unless there is specific request to me from the parties not to do so, to ask the Clerk to conduct a ballot amongst honourable members in which they would be able to opt between two alternatives-the present sitting hours or a new set of sitting hours.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, thank you very much for that answer. Very briefly, as this matter has now occupied the time of honourable members, both in the House and out of the House, for over a year and as we are coming to the end of the session it seems to me that as we are grown adults it is about time we made a decision. I hope that we will have discussions in our party room tomorrow as I hope discussions will occur in the Government party room so that the ballot can be conducted this week or next week. Then some provision can be made for the next sitting of parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek your indulgence to address a few words on this same matter.
—The right honourable gentleman may proceed.

—A paper has been distributed by the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) and by Senator Martin. Unfortunately I did not hear the full text of your comments to the House, Mr Speaker, but quite obviously there is a shared concern that there is a basis on which the present sitting hours can be modified in any way to meet the requirements of honourable members and yet still maintain the general available opportunity for Government Business and private members' business. The Government has had some discussions about the matter. It believes it is necessary perhaps to develop further propositions than those now before us. For example, on other occasions there have been propositions relating to two-week back-to-back Tuesday to Friday, Monday to Thursday proposition, with two weeks up. Some honourable members are attracted to that type of proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware, Mr Speaker, that the group of which you have been chairman has been looking at some alternative proposals. The Government feels that perhaps still more work is needed to be done, not just for the purpose of looking at those proposals before us but perhaps to look at some of the other dimensions as to how we can accommodate adequately party committees, parliamentary committees and those other very important parts of a member's conduct of parliamentary business such as the interviewing of constituents and so on. Therefore, it will be a matter which will be discussed in the Joint Party Room tomorrow on the basis of looking at perhaps a wider range of options than is included just within the proposal that you, Mr Speaker, commented on a few moments ago.

The honourable member for Robertson suggested that the matter is urgent. In agreeing with that I still think it is necessary to determine a proposal that is workable. Whatever proposition is put forward I think we need to test it in relation both to the demands of the front bench Executive and the Opposition parties as well as the need for Cabinet to meet and to debate the wide range of matters that seem to come up for consideration both for it and in consultation with various groups.

We are anxious in that whatever proposals go forward that we try to meet generally the wishes of honourable members. We do not wish to do that without consultation with the Opposition or with members of Parliament as a whole. I hope that through party room discussion tomorrow we might be able to progress the matter a little further. I throw some caution into the arena as far as our being necessarily able to resolve the proposition finally at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I say to the right honourable Leader of the House (Mr Sinclair) that everything he has put is predicated on a decision by the Executive; whereas it has been put to me by honourable members who have approached me that it is a parliamentary matter. As I see it and as I have been informed by party leaders, they wish the matters to be discussed at party meetings. It is well known that at the request of members from both chambers the President and I had drawn up some ballot papers which could be used to ascertain the wishes of honourable members and honourable senators.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The refusal of the Government to provide for public funding of political parties for election campaigns.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal and National Country parties are terrified of the great reform which has been brought about by the Wran Labor Government in New South Wales that political parties be funded from the public purse as from the 1981 election onwards. The New South Wales Labor Government has brought Australia into line with what is occurring throughout all the other great democracies of the Western world. This is an extremely serious debate. It requires serious contributions from both sides of the House. All that we have heard in the past both from this Government and from the Opposition in New South Wales through its former leader, Mr Mason, and its new leader, Mr McDonald, is that the system of funding political parties by the public purse is corrupt. No substantiation of the allegations and no reasons why it would be corrupt-no mention why all the other countries which practise this measure would be corrupt-have been given. Really, it is just a little rhetoric in the hope that the New South Wales Opposition can win some votes back to increase the miserable 35 per cent which it received at the last New South Wales election. After the New South Wales Opposition's efforts yesterday I would have thought that the percentage would fall to 25 per cent because not only has the New South Wales Opposition changed to a worse leader but it has the ayatollah as deputy. One will be able to go into Martin Place every Friday and watch people being stoned to death if the Liberals ever get power in New South Wales again.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been campaign director or deputy campaign director on behalf of the Labor Party in no fewer than 11 Federal and State campaigns. I have been very close to the situation of raising funds, setting budgets and watching expenditure on television, radio and newspaper advertising grow, and I understand completely what is happening in Australia. There are very few people in this Parliament on the other side who have had such experience. If there are such people, the Government is not putting them up to speak in this debate. Jim Carlton obviously would have a good deal of experience--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman will refer to a member by his electorate.

—The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) would be expected to take part in this debate but he will not. Obviously, as an apparatchik of the New South Wales Liberal Party, he would know what is involved. We have reached a stage when the Liberal and Country parties expended about $6m during the 1980 Federal election campaign. We cannot get an exact amount but we do know that on television alone $2m was spent by the Government parties. The days of raffling chooks and the days of going down to get two bob or a dollar off a party's local supporters to meet that sort of expenditure have long since gone. The Liberal and Country parties are receiving massive donations from major companies both inside and outside Australia. The Australian people are entitled to know where that money is coming from, for what reason the money is being given and if this Government is giving any favours to the people who are making these massive donations. The Labor Party is pledged not only in New South Wales but also in every other State and in this Parliament to bring about the same reforms which have been adopted by almost every other Western democracy. I will come to that matter a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), of course, joined in the chorus at the weekend at the Liberal Party Council meeting by saying that the proposed system in New South Wales is corrupt; that we should not use taxpayers' money this way. Let the taxpayers say whether they want an honest political system in which they know where the money is coming from. Do the taxpayers believe that money spent in this way is not as valuable to the body politic in Australia as, say, spending $40m on VIP aircraft or spending $120,000 to send some of the members from the Liberal Party around the world to deliver letters? One of them, the honourable member for Bradfield, David Miles Connolly, or 'smiling cunningly', as they used to call him in the Department--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman will not use those terms in relation to another member. He will withdraw.

—I withdraw. The honourable member is being sent around the world to deliver letters. It is not so long ago that he was a guest of the infamous Smith regime in Rhodesia in defiance of a United Nations declaration. I hope that the Prime Minister does not send him to any of the black Commonwealth countries to deliver his messages. That exercise is taking $120,000 of taxpayers' money, $40m on the VIP aircraft and thousands of dollars was spent on the Lodge when the Prime Minister took over from the former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, because the Lodge was not up to the Prime Minister's expectations. Let the taxpayers make a judgment about the way in which the money should be spent in bringing about a decent system for funding election campaigns or in the other ways I have mentioned. The Government does not argue about that other expenditure. It says that it has to spend the money on those things, but it says that spending taxpayers' money to bring about a decent political system is not on.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Parliament: How could a system of using money from taxpayers, which money has to publicly accounted for, be corrupt, as the parties opposite charge, when business donations, which are not accounted for and are hidden in the annual balance sheets of businesses, are not corrupt. As I say, $5m or $6m came to the Government parties at the time of the last election and was completely unaccounted for. We do not know where one cent came from. We do not know what deals are being done between business and government. We do not know what favours are being bestowed on businesses as a result of their donations. That is not corrupt, according to the Government. It is corrupt only if governments, as they are doing in so many parts of the world, pay out taxpayers' money, a much smaller amount, and are fully accountable to government auditors. The Government says that that is a corrupt system but that private business donations are not corrupt.

These questions ought to be asked: How was the $5m or $6m that was spent by the Liberal and Country parties in the 1980 election campaign obtained? Who were the donors? Were any agreements reached with the donors? Have any favours been granted by the Government to the donors? All these questions have to be answered to satisfy the Australian people. The allegations that public funding is corrupt, that it is unacceptable, without any serious substantive argument in support of them are not acceptable either in the Parliament or outside the Parliament among members of the public.

Let us look at some of the things that are on record. I was campaign director for the Labor Party in 1972. Mr Murdoch has gone on record-this is not something I would have made public because the agreements between political parties and donors are such that the parties try to keep everything secret-since 1972 and said that he made a donation of $74,000 to the Labor Party in 1972. In 1972 Mr Murdoch had one television station, in Adelaide in one of the smaller States, and he had a number of newspapers around Australia. But let us look at what has happened to Mr Murdoch's empire since 1972. Let there be no mistake about it; Mr Murdoch now stands 100 per cent behind this Government-101 per cent, if one likes. He not only donates to the Government parties but also uses his newspapers regularly to support this Government, to do everything possible to see that the Liberal Party is in control both at the national level and the State level. We had the disgusting display of Press bias in South Australia two years ago when the Corcoran Government was overturned partially by the Murdoch empire. Now, Mr Murdoch wants television stations in Sydney and Melbourne. He wants the airways. What additional things would Mr Murdoch do for the Liberal Party that he would not even have thought of doing for the Labor Party in 1972? The answer must have come as a bit of a shock to him in 1972 when he asked Mr Whitlam to make him high commissioner to the United Kingdom. Mr Whitlam said: 'You must be joking'. But Mr Murdoch said: 'But I have made a big donation'. It was not on.

What is Mr Murdoch getting now? Many questions are being asked in the Parliament about the draft of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal legislation? The Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) says: 'Certain discussions have been going on with Mr Murdoch'. Everybody in Australia believes that substantial donations are coming from the business people in this country, including Mr Murdoch, to the Liberal and Country parties. This is one of the reasons why the Liberal and Country parties are absolutely terrified of the legislation which has been introduced in New South Wales, which will give us a decent electoral law at last. It will not be long before every other Parliament follows. Every other State will follow and so will the Commonwealth, because the Labor Party, the largest single political party in this country, is pledged to bring about this reform. Reform in this area we will have. People opposite say that the business world has no influence in the Liberal Party. Those opposite should ask Dick Hamer how much influence business has in the Liberal Party. He has been on television for the last four days telling us that it was not his colleagues who sacked him; it was big business in Victoria that sacked him. That is the influence that big business has on the parties that sit opposite. Those parties carry on with so much nonsense about the system proposed by the Labor Party.

If the Prime Minister leaves Australia in two or three weeks time and wanders around the world he will meet and shake hands with some very prominent citizens in the other Western countries. Mr Fraser is on record in Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will refer to a Minister by his portfolio.

—The Prime Minister will go to shake hands with some very prominent people. He is on record in Australia as saying that the public funding of political parties is corrupt. I suggest that if he believes that the system is corrupt he believes the people who practise it are corrupt. Let us look at the people Mr Fraser will have to accuse of corruption.
—I remind the honourable member to refrain from using the names of honourable members.

—The Prime Minister has used the term, Mr Deputy Speaker. He used it at the Liberal Party Council meeting, where one can say anything because only a bunch of nongs are listening. In West Germany the Prime Minister will shake hands with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, who was publicly funded by taxpayers' money during the last Bundestag elections. He will have to shake hands with Helmut Schmidt and say: 'Look, you know you were elected under a corrupt system of public funding for political parties'. Schmidt will do what Nasser did when he met Menzies. He will look up at the ceiling and say: 'Where did they get this one from?' For years and years West Germany has had not only public funding for election campaigns but also public funding for the existence of the political parties.

SPEECH.PARA: Then the Prime Minister will go to Austria to meet Bruno Kreisky. He will say the same thing to him. Kreisky is new to politics. He has been involved only since 1919! The Austrian parties are being funded not only for elections but also for the existence of their political parties and the publication of their newspapers. So they have an opposing view in their newspapers to the monopolies which might be owned as they are here in Australia. Again, he will tell Schmidt and Kreisky that they should do away with this system. In Italy he will talk to President Pertini and tell him that the electoral system of funding political parties is corrupt. Let us see how Italy adopted the system. I quote from the New South Wales report dealing with the funding system. It stated:

The system of public subsidies was introduced following scandals about clandestine payments to political parties by some industrialists in the oil and chemical industries. There was broad bi-partisan agreement on its introduction. It was enacted in 1974.

The Prime Minister will see President Pertini, Chancellor Kreisky and Chancellor Schmidt. In Sweden a conservative government is in office at the moment. Sweden, since 1964, with the approval of all the political parties, conservative and labour, had supported the funding of political parties. They are not just supported at election time; they are funded continuously for educational purposes, for the newspapers which the political parties put out for campaigning. I suppose the Prime Minister will say to Falldin in Sweden: 'You have to drop the system as well. Forget about your experience of the last 20 years. Do what we do; sell your soul and try to perpetuate the rotten system which is now applying in Australia.' He will go to Norway, Denmark, Finland, Israel and Canada and then to the last country. No Australian conservative Prime Minister likes anything better than to arrive at the White House. They will do anything to get to the White House. The Prime Minister over the years has written 1,000 letters asking for an invitation to visit various Presidents. When he arrives there he will say to President Reagan: 'I am sorry, President, that $21m which you received in public funding for the last presidential race was made from a corrupt system. You have to drop that. You have to go back and be beholden to all the major United States companies that used to buy and sell Presidents in years gone past'. He will have to tell Jimmy Carter, the former President of the United States: 'You were involved in a system which is corrupt'. I hope he will then get the opportunity to speak to the Congress so that he can inform all the successful candidates in the Congress that they are partaking in a corrupt system.

This debate is extremely serious in Australia at the moment. The Government has to come up with some substantive argument against the system of funding of political parties. Wild rhetoric about allegations of corruption which do not carry the substantive argument are not enough in the debate on this matter. We will win on the question of funding of political parties. A reform will be brought about. I say: More power to the Wran Government of New South Wales for being the first to introduce this very major and necessary reform.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has to be the Opposition's secret weapon in this House. It has to be the most inspired and most aptly chosen matter of public importance by an Opposition for a long time. There is no better demonstration of that than the concluding exhortation of the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young). He said that the Wran Government would win on this issue. He said: 'More power to the arm of the Wran Government'. If Labor is so certain that the Wran Government will win on this issue why does the Wran Government not have the courage to put this issue to a referendum of the New South Wales public? The Premier of New South Wales is holding a referendum on the subject of pecuniary interest and on the subject of a four-year parliamentary term, but he does not have the courage to have a referendum on this issue.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The Treasurer does not seem to know that it is necessary to have a referendum on those two other issues according to the Constitution of New South Wales.
—There is no substance in the point of order.

—The holding of a referendum would be open, convenient and overwhelming common sense, and it would settle this issue once and for all so far as the Australian public and the people of New South Wales are concerned. If the Premier of New South Wales really believed that this was such a winner in that State-that the New South Wales taxpayers were all fired up about the contribution to democracy that this sort of legislation could make-he would have the courage to have a vote on this issue also. The fact of the matter is that the great majority of the people of New South Wales, as well as the great majority of the people elsewhere in this country, do not want taxpayers' money spent on paying off the campaign debts of the Australian Labor Party. That is what the New South Wales legislation is all about. Everybody knows that the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party is massively in debt. Everybody knows that this action is a raid on the taxpayers of New South Wales to pay off the campaign debts of the Labor Party which have been incurred not only in getting Mr Wran elected but also in successive Federal elections. This proposition is wrong in principle. It is wrong in principle that taxpayers' funds should be used to finance the campaigns of political parties. It is wrong in principle that taxpayers' funds should be used to pay off the campaign debts of the Labor Party, the Liberal Party, the National Country Party or any political party in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Part of the test of the capacity of a political party in a democracy to sustain itself over the years is its capacity to attract a degree of financial support. The failure of the Labor Party in this area is part and parcel of its failure as a major party in our system. It is utterly wrong and an utter perversion of proper principles of parliamentary democracy to fall back upon the taxpayers and to force a contribution from every taxpayer in this country towards the activities of a political party that he does not support. That is what this legislation involves. It is not democratic to force a member of the Labor Party to pay, through taxes, to help finance the activities of the Liberal Party. The legislation is a cynical exercise designed to serve the political ends of the Australian Labor Party. The opposition of the Liberal Party in this place and in parliaments throughout Australia is based upon principle. It is based upon the soundly based proposition that part and parcel of the role of a political party is to gather financial as well as physical and electoral support.

Public funding is a long cherished objective of the Labor Party, not only in New South Wales but all over Australia. I remember the maiden speech of the honourable member for Port Adelaide in 1974 when he spoke on that subject in this Parliament. He has spoken on that subject at regular intervals ever since. He is committed to the view that taxpayers' money ought to be used to finance the activities of political parties in this country. I put it to the honourable member for Port Adelaide and to the House that not only does the Labor Party want the New South Wales taxpayers to pay off the campaign debts of the ALP in that State, which were incurred not only in fighting State elections but also in fighting Federal elections, but it also wants that practice to be duplicated all over Australia. The fight that is being waged in New South Wales now by the Liberal and National Country parties is not a fight in respect of New South Wales politics alone. It has implications that go far beyond the State of New South Wales. It has implications all over Australia. The Wran Government is petrified to put to a referendum of the New South Wales people the Bill which was introduced by the Wran Government and passed by the New South Wales Parliament-the Bill which it so believes in. This is the legislation that is supposed to scare us to death. Rather it scares Mr Wran to death. He does not have the courage to put it to a vote of the New South Wales people because he knows it would be overwhelmingly rejected even by the hundreds of thousands of people who regularly vote for the Labor Party in New South Wales in both Federal and State elections.

Not only does this legislation strike at the fundamental principle that taxpayers' money should not be used to pay off the campaign debts of the Labor Party or, indeed, of any other political party in Australia; it also strikes at another very important principle in a democracy, that is, the right of privacy and the right of anonymity of political support. In supporting this legislation the Labor Party is saying to anybody who makes only a modest contribution to a political party that that person has no right to preserve the privacy of his support for that political party. The thing that really matters in the legislation that has been passed by the New South Wales Parliament is the enormous power it gives to inspectors appointed by the Electoral Commission to examine the books of political parties and to destroy a basic right of anonymity and of privacy, which I believe is a very important principle of democracy. That view also happens to be the view of 65 per cent of people surveyed in a poll conducted by the Age newspaper on this subject, which included a very large number of Labor Party and Australian Democrat supporters. So the opposition is to be found not only in the ranks of the Liberal Party and the National Country Party but also amongst many supporters of the other side of politics in Australia. The legislation that has been passed by the Wran Government was passed very quickly.
Opposition members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If honourable members persist in interjecting, the Chair will deal with them.

—The legislation that has been hurried through the New South Wales Parliament by the Wran Government gives extremely draconian inspectorial powers to those people who are appointed by the Commission established under the legislation. That legislation is quite patently designed to serve the political interests of the Australian Labor Party. It forces taxpayers, against their will, to support the political activities of people for whom they would never vote throughout their whole lives. It is wrong in principle for that reason. It is wrong also because it attacks the principle of anonymity and the principle of privacy.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Labor Party's support for this legislation is based upon two totally false propositions. The first false proposition is that, somehow or other, parliaments, be they in Australia, the United States or anywhere else in the democratic world, can legislate for the honesty of their elected members. The history of democracies around the world has been that no matter how elaborate are the electoral laws of a country, no matter how severe are the sanctions for doing certain things, honest people can be retained and promoted in politics only through the proper workings of the parliamentary and political systems.

All the sanctions under the sun in the United States did not prevent somebody who reached the office of Vice-President of that country from being driven from office, basically because of corruption. All the elaborate electoral laws in the United States a few years ago did not prevent that from happening.

TALK.START.PARA: —He had a few admirers here.

—The honourable member for Lalor knows the person to whom I am referring. I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that all the elaborate laws in this country will not ensure a higher level of honesty and a higher level of integrity amongst elected people. I do not assert that any monopoly of integrity or honesty is held on one or other side of this Parliament, or, indeed, of any parliament in the States of this country. What I do assert is that it is absolutely false and misguided to believe that we will necessarily produce a higher degree of honesty and a higher degree of integrity by passing law upon law and imposing regulation upon regulation, particularly so far as this type of legislation is concerned. There can be no doubt that a political system which allows the contributions of very large trade unions towards the funds of the Australian Labor Party, contributions which are funded as a result of membership and other dues paid by members of trade unions throughout this country, who are in turn not forced--
—They are all published.
—Does the honourable member for Port Adelaide suggest that the inspectors of this Commission will be able to inspect the books of every trade union in Australia?
—The Arbitration Commission can do it now.
—I am not talking about the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Port Adelaide.

—I am not talking about the Arbitration Commission; I am talking about the inspectors appointed by the Electoral Commission in New South Wales. The honourable member for Port Adelaide is assuring the House that those people will be able to inspect the books of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union throughout Australia.
—The IRB is doing it now.

—Is the honourable member for Hindmarsh going to give me the same assurance? That is very good. I am absolutely delighted to hear that. I am sure the officials of that union will also be delighted to know that that inspection will take place.
—You don't even know what is going on.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Hindmarsh.

—Of course the Government is opposed to political funding. Of course we are opposed to the prescription of taxpayers' money to fund the activities of political parties. Of course we are opposed to the funds of Australian taxpayers who live in New South Wales being appropriated to pay off the $300,000 or $400,000 worth of debts of the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party. That is what this legislation is all about. It is not about some highfalutin principle. It is not about the commitment of the Labor Party to parliamentary democracy. It is about paying off the debts incurred over the past few years by the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party. It is about the $300,000 or $400,000 that the Labor Party has got into the red over the last few years. That is as much as the principle of support for this legislation amounts to.

SPEECH.PARA: We reject the legislation. We reject this matter of public importance. We do not believe that it is right in principle to force people to contribute towards the campaign expenses of political parties they do not support. I remind the House that every time the Premier of New South Wales complains to the people of that State that the Commonwealth Government has not given him enough money for the essential services of New South Wales, he should be reminded that the $2m or $3m which would be available under this legislation is the $2m or $3m that could be available to finance hospitals, schools, pre-schools and other activities in New South Wales. If Mr Wran were short of funds to support essential services in New South Wales he would really commit himself to an act of principle and abandon funding under this legislation. If he really believes that the Liberal Party is petrified of this legislation in New South Wales, if he really believes in the rhetoric of the honourable member for Port Adelaide, that he can win on this legislation and that there ought to be more power to his arm, he should have the courage to have a referendum and face the people of New South Wales and really find out that they reject his rotten, corrupt legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard a ranting, raving performance by the Treasurer (Mr Howard), unprecedented in this House. The way he was carrying on, I thought he was going to do himself a mischief. He has called for a referendum to be held in New South Wales on this legislation. A referendum is to be held in New South Wales in a few months' time. It is called a State election. In that election the people of New South Wales will have an opportunity to reject the Government. If the Treasurer wants to get set about the result of that referendum, I can get him set right throughout this House and right throughout the nation for any amount he cares to nominate. The Liberal Party is mounting a campaign in this election in which it is using the term 'morality'. 'Corruption' is a word that crops up.

SPEECH.PARA: This debate is really about the Government's morality, a morality which enables people and companies to provide hundreds of thousands of dollars, millions of dollars, privately and anonymously, to its candidates for election campaigns; or our morality, which is that if people want democracy they have to pay for that democracy to make sure that it is continually and perpetually honest, and that will be done by public funding of election campaigns. We want to get rid of the present situation where democracy is something that can be sold to the highest bidder. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) in his speech said that the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales introduced this legislation to pay off its debts. That is absolute nonsense. The Labor Party in New South Wales, for his information, is not in debt. We know, from the debate today and the argument of the Treasurer today, that the Liberals are scared; they are terrified. I could use a cruder expression, but I will not. They are doing it in their boots regularly over this legislation because they know that when the companies that now pour millions of dollars into their party have to disclose their funds, funds, amongst other things, will drop off.

Last week I saw one of the most disgusting spectacles that I have seen in my life in politics. A Premier of one of the States of this nation was assassinated by one business leader after another on Nationwide. What amazed me was that nothing was said about it in the Press the next week. We saw other top business people-I think it was Peter Couchman first of all-recounting the fact that there had been a series of meetings of business leaders leading up to the decision that Hamer had to go. Then they appeared on television and said: 'He has to go'. Who is running this country?

TALK.START.PARA: —It had nothing to do with the Parliament.

—It had nothing to do with the Parliament? Who is running this country? Big business in Melbourne, or the elected representatives of the country? I am not a supporter of Mr Hamer but, by God, I felt sorry for the man, assassinated in the way in which he was last week. It was the most nauseating thing I have seen. Can honourable members imagine what would have happened if the trade unions had all been interviewed and they had said: 'Hayden has to go and Whitlam has to go'? There would be outcries from the people behind the scenes who are running the Government. I would like to know and I am sure the people of Australia would like to know how much each of those individuals who were named in that program-the many others as well-contributed. Do not people in this country have a right to know how much was put into the Liberal Party's coffers in Victoria and federally? I certainly think they do.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard from the Treasurer about the so-called right of privacy, the right of anonymity. Why do people want to remain anonymous when they have contributed large amounts of money to a political party? The only reason is that there can be a conflict of interest. We know there is a conflict of interest when mining companies are starting to put amounts of $100,000, $200,000, $300,000 or $400,000 into election campaigns. That is why they want to remain anonymous and private. As the previous speaker from this side, the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young), said, what an absurdity it is, in a debate of this nature, to talk about legislation and the public funding of political parties in corrupt regimes such as that of West Germany being corrupt. West Germany passed a Political Parties Act of 1967 funding the election of political parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say one word about that either.

—The Treasurer did not mention that once. All parties participating in an election campaign in Germany are entitled to public funding provided they meet a threshold. Approximately $1.75 is provided by the Bundestag for each person voting for the political parties. Mr Wran is talking about 22c for each person. In West Germany parties must disclose their sources of revenue. Donors of $10,000 or more must be named regardless of whether they are individuals or corporations. Austria has a fund that gives a basic grant to each party with five members in parliament and apportions the remainder of the fund on the basis of votes polled in the national elections. That system has operated since 1975. Is the system operating in Austria a corrupt system?

SPEECH.PARA: We know of the many scandals that have occurred in Italy over the years. One of the means of keeping the Italian system honest-which is recognised by the Italian Parliament-is to provide political funding. Sweden probably leads the way in introducing legislation of this nature because it introduced the payment of subsidies to political parties in 1965. Norway soon followed the Swedish system, as did Denmark, Finland, Israel, Canada and the United States. All those countries are highly respected democracies. What an absurdity it is to suggest that all these countries that have had democratic systems for such a long period would introduce a system that is corrupt. They have introduced a system of public funding for the obvious reason that this gets rid of corruption. Once people are nominated and the amount of money that has been paid in is made known to the general public, that clearly ends the sort of corruption that has gone on before.

The Treasurer spoke about the national level. Let us look at what happens at the local level. Does anyone seriously suggest that, at a local level-most of us are back benchers-a person who contributes $1,000 or $2,000 to the campaign of a local candidate does not buy access to that local candidate? That is not necessarily corrupt. Can any honourable member seriously suggest to me that if Fred Nerks, the managing director of such and such a company, who has contributed $1,000 in the last election campaign to the candidate for Gulargambone or whatever it may be is on the phone he will not get an immediate interview while other people have to wait? Of course he will. He does not buy actual goods and services. He buys access in the same way as do the contributions of general managers of some of the top companies in Australia which contribute $50,000 or $100,000 to the Liberal Party campaign. They want to talk to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). Honourable members opposite do not seriously think that they do not get through. I think they have a better chance of getting through than would the girls from the women's refuges today. We saw a situation only the other day when the Leader of the Opposition--

TALK.START.PARA: —The door isn't closed to anybody.
—The honourable member says that the door is not closed. He would be lucky to get through, let alone the people I was referring to.
—It is disgraceful.

—The honourable member should not be absurd. We saw a situation just recently where the former leader of the Opposition in New South Wales, Mr Mason-he has been deposed; he is amongst others who seem to be falling quickly-admitted that he had been offered bribes of $5,000.
—A week.

—A week. He did not bother to report it to the authorities. To his credit, he rejected the bribe. He should have gone to the police. Rarely has there been a better example of what separates the two political parties. On the one hand, we have a political party that accepts millions of dollars privately from anonymous sources and wants to make sure that those sources remain anonymous. On the other hand, we want open disclosure; we want an end to the peddling of influence by companies and individuals. We want to see political parties funded and we want to see honesty in government.

—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. I call the honourable member for Dundas. Before the honourable member proceeds the Chair suggests to honourable members that the quality of the speeches will be measured by the substance and not the musical accompaniment in the form of interjections.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was suggested in this debate that we would hear arguments of substance by the honourable member for Port Adelaide (Mr Young). I waited in vain to hear the substance. In fact what we have been given are the confessions of the honourable member for Port Adelaide. They were most interesting confessions. What he had to say dealt with his own relationship, as a former officer of the Australian Labor Party, with those people who have supported the Australian Labor Party in financial and other ways. He suggested that we ought to judge everybody else by the way in which he acted in that office.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is a very poor form of analogous argument. The substantial matter that he raised in this debate dealt with the experience of other countries in relation to public funding. There is no way that we would argue, by that sort of analogy, what ought to be acceptable in Australia. Let us look at the position with regard to public funding in Germany. It may be interesting to note the extent to which the nazis were publicly funded in office to remain in office and to draw some analogy from that. It might be relevant to know the extent to which the Italian Communist Party is today aided by public funds of the Italian taxpayers. Are we to argue by analogy that the public funds of Australian taxpayers ought to be payable to parties of that ilk? Even Mr Wran in New South Wales would not buy that one. Yet, that is the sort of argument that we are asked by the honourable member for Port Adelaide and the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) to accept. I do not accept those arguments. They have no currency; they have no substance. The reality is that the Liberal Party does have a code of behaviour in relation to the way in which money for the Liberal Party is raised. It is a code of behaviour which is honourable and upon which the public of this country can rely. I will tell honourable members opposite what the code of behaviour is because I think it is about time somebody told members of the Australian Labor Party what it was about. If honourable members opposite were able just to separate themselves from their own experience and the extent to which they have involved themselves in fund raising for their own party-need one recall the situation involving some Victorians, the former leader of the Opposition and the Iraqis to know just what they mean by standards-and if they were able to build themselves up into a substantial political party with broadly based support they would not be seeking to get taxpayers' funds to support their campaigns.

I go back to the point I wanted to make before. The Liberal Party's code of behaviour is briefly this: The organisation raises its own money. That is separate from the parliamentary party. In the statement that was made by the Liberal Party to the joint committee of the Legislative Council and the Legislative Assembly of New South Wales on the funding of election campaigns, it had this to say:

Briefly stated, the Organisation raises its own money and we insulate our policy-makers from knowledge of our contributions. No Parliamentary member is informed of the details of donations under any circumstances whatsoever. We do not accept money from other Organisations in furtherance of their interests, and we do not accept funds that are subject to political conditions of any kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't know.
—I do not know where the money that supports our political party comes from. There are no conditions attached to any funds that are given by companies or individuals to support our philosophy.
—Except that you will not support socialism.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Lalor.

—There are no such conditions that I am aware of or that I believe any other member of the Liberal Party or of this Parliament would be aware of. We are free to make the decisions that we wish to make within our party councils and within this Parliament on our own judgment, free from any influence of that sort. That is the standard that members of the Labor Party ought to be aware of. That is the basic issue which I think is before the people. We know from the polls that have been taken over a long period that the people of Australia are not in favour of taxpayers' funds being diverted into the funding of political parties before the provision of services and amenities that the people themselves want and require. In fact, the Premier of New South Wales has fought an election on another campaign. I remind honourable members of it. It was the campaign on double taxation. I submit to honourable members that public funding of political parties is a form of double taxation, mainly for supporters of the Opposition. Its supporters-but many other taxpayers as well-are challenged to provide moneys for political purposes through subscriptions to unions. Those same people who will be compelled to pay union subscriptions compulsorily extracted from their pockets will now be asked to pay another compulsory fee taken out of their pockets by government. It is the most scurrilous form of double taxation I have heard of.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no public support for this proposal. A total of 71 per cent of the people are against public funding, according to an Australian Nationwide Opinion Poll, 23 per cent are in favour and 6 per cent are undecided. A decision by the latter group would not alter the result at all. The honourable member for Port Adelaide said in this debate that the Liberals were terrified. I can assure him that in no way are we in the Liberal Party terrified by this proposal. The honourable member for Robertson remarked on the referendum that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said should be called. We will willingly fight the next election campaign in New South Wales on this matter. I believe that the fighting of that campaign will so terrify Mr Wran that we will be lucky to find him wanting to see that matter mentioned at all during the campaign. Mr Wran knows as well as I and honourable members opposite know that this would be a disastrous issue for him to fight on. He would be hounded from office. That is the reality of the situation.

Nobody is in favour of taxpayers' funds being used to pay off the Labor Party's debts. It has no public support whatsoever. Nobody is in favour of a political party that cannot succeed in raising membership of its own to support its own wishes going to the taxpayers' pockets for support. It was interesting to read recently-I cannot vouch for the accuracy of the figures, in absolute terms-of the stated support for each of the parties in New South Wales. It was surprising that the largest political party in New South Wales in terms of membership was the National Country Party, with over 28,000 members. The Liberal Party had over 22,000 members and the Labor Party had of the order of 18,000 members. The smallest political party in terms of paying, subscribing members in this country is the Australian Labor Party. That is the very reason that some $2m of taxpayers' funds have to be extracted from taxpayers' pockets by the New South Wales Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is extortion.

—As the Minister for the Capital Territory says, it is extortion of taxpayers in every sense of the word. The direct cost involved is only a part of it. As I said in a debate the other day in this chamber, when I grieved for New South Wales at the prospect of this legislation, the cost is much more widespread. There is the cost of the very bureaucracy that is to be established to administer this scheme. That will be a significant cost. It includes the cost of establishing and maintaining the election funding authority, the costs of meetings and payments of members of that authority, the costs of research and publication, the costs of registers, the administrative costs of allocating subsidies and recording disclosures, the additional costs of by-elections that have never been disclosed, the legal costs of the authority, the accounting and auditing costs, the staffing of the authority, the hiring of consultants and the hiring of inspectors to carry out inspections. The indirect costs of parties to meet legal and recording and auditing requirements are additional costs that parties themselves will have to meet simply as a result of the nature of these proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: To be considered also is the matter of invasion of privacy and discretionary powers. The New South Wales proposals, by way of the New South Wales Election Act, shows to the people of Australia what is envisaged in terms of intrusion into their lives by inspectors who will know what their private circumstances might be and who they want to support in terms of philosophy. Why should governments be able to pry by these means, by looking at party officers, into the ideas in people's minds? In fact this privacy is something protected by the very secrecy of the secret ballot. In this community we do not try to intrude into people's lives in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is now concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Statute Law Revision Bill 1981 has three purposes. First, it is designed to correct some printing and drafting errors that have been found to exist in a number of Acts. Secondly, it provides for the repeal of a number of Acts and provisions of Acts the operation of which is exhausted or which are no longer required. Thirdly, it makes a number of technical or minor amendments which, while having some substance, are regarded as being of a non-controversial nature.

The Government has decided to introduce statute law revision bills into the Parliament on a regular basis, at least once in each year and, if required, once in each sitting. This will enable the prompt correction of mistakes and errors and removal from the statute book of expired laws. In the absence of the regular passage of Bills of this kind, the correction of an error in an Act can be achieved only by having a special Bill passed for that purpose or waiting until the Act needs to be amended for some other more important purpose. An objection sometimes made to omnibus amending Bills is that they result in so-called 'hidden' amendments. However, the Government Printer now issues monthly tables of Acts passed by the Parliament and these tables indicate clearly whenever an Act is amended by an omnibus Act such as a statute law revision Act. The provisions of the present Bill that deal with the correction of errors and the repeal and amendment of expired laws do not call for particular comment. I propose to explain in some detail the nature and effect of the provisions of substance.
Acts Interpretation Act 1901

The Bill provides in Schedule 1 for the insertion in the Acts Interpretation Act of a provision that is relevant to the whole body of statute law. The provision is to the effect that, in the interpretation of a provision of an Act, a construction that would promote the purpose or object underlying the Act, whether that purpose or object is expressly stated in the Act or not, shall be preferred to a construction that would not promote that purpose or object.

Under our constitutional arrangements it is the function of an independent judiciary to interpret the law and no proposals which we make can or should undermine the freedom that this function requires. Nevertheless the general approach to be adopted to statutory interpretation is something which this Parliament can-and at this stage should-address. The volume and complexity of legislation are assuming daunting proportions and the task of understanding and applying it grows in proportion. Increasingly the more significant decisions our courts are called upon to make turn on a point of statutory interpretation. Our problems are not unique. They are shared, for example, by the British Parliament, to which proposals have been made along the lines now proposed by this Bill. The British proposals, I should add, have been initiated and supported by very distinguished law Lords, including Lord Scarman and Lord Wilberforce.

The effect of the provision to be inserted in the Acts Interpretation Act will be to confirm that in interpreting provisions regard is to be had to the object or purpose underlying the Act in question. We are not among those who would say that the general approach of our courts is at present overly legalistic, but we do think that there is scope for expressly stating that the statutes this Parliament makes are to be interpreted in a purposive manner. Tax decisions constitute a topical and important example that will come readily to all members' minds, but the matter has wider implications that extend to many other statutes. I therefore commend the provision to the House, but before moving on I should invite the House's attention to some related questions. Explanatory material is often provided by the Government to assist senators and members, and subsequent users of legislation. The material is of particular value where legislation is complex or specialised in subject matter or both.

The Government thinks that we need to consider placing this practice on a more regular basis, even to the extent of having an explanatory memorandum approved by the Parliament and able to be taken into account by the courts in interpreting difficult provisions in the Act. The memorandum could not and would not be controlling. However, apart from contributing to the ease with which an Act can be understood by the public as well as by senators and members, such a practice offers the hope that the draftsman, when faced with the difficult choice of either using general language which might, however, leave the courts without sufficient guidance, or introducing lengthy detailed provisions, could feel some security in choosing the former course if he knew that a memorandum approved by the Parliament would embody its intent.

A cognate question arises where an Act is based on an expert report tabled in the Parliament, for example by the Law Reform Commission. Courts can at present consider such reports, but the precise way in which they can use them has been the subject of dispute. The fear has been expressed that the use of extraneous materials such as reports and explanatory memoranda will increase the cost and length of legal proceedings. Certainly the possible disadvantages have to be considered and weighed against the benefits that would flow from the use of such materials. The time has come, however, when the matter should be fully explored, and the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) has announced that he proposes to do so with a view to developing specific proposals that can be brought into the Parliament for further consideration. In the meantime, the present position on the use of extraneous materials is preserved by stating in the proposed new provision that it is not to be construed as authorising the consideration of extraneous materials for any purpose for which they could not be considered if the new provision had not been enacted.
Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975

Part II of the Bill repeals the provisions of the Schedule to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 that confer jurisdiction on the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in matters arising under various other Acts, and other parts of the Bill re-enact the provisions concerned as part of those other Acts. In the course of transferring these provisions from one Act to another, Part IV omits the requirement that the Tribunal be constituted by a presidential member sitting alone when a decision is being reviewed under section 20 of the Australian Capital Territory Taxation (Administration) Act 1969. That section empowers the Commissioner of Taxation to revoke a banker's authority to issue cheque forms that are pre-stamped with the duty payable under that Act if the banker is convicted of an offence against that Act. Part XI provides for the Tribunal to have jurisdiction to review decisions of the Collector of Customs under sections 22 and 23 of the Distillation Act 1901. Those sections relate to the renewal of licences to distil spirits. In all other respects these amendments do not make any change in substance to the jurisdiction of the Tribunal.
Schools Commission Act 1973, Tertiary Education Commission Act 1977

The Bill provides for the word 'Commonwealth' to be included at the beginning of the names of the Schools Commission, the Schools Commission advisory boards and the Tertiary Education Commission and provides for these bodies to perform the same functions in relation to the Northern Territory as they perform in relation to a State. Clause 117 amends references in various Acts to the former names of these bodies.
Defence Act 1903, Air Force Act 1923 and Naval Defence Act 1910

The amendments made by Parts III, X and XV and clause 116 give effect to recommendations made by the Millar Committee report on the Citizen Military Forces in 1974 regarding the title and structure of the Army Reserve.

The Millar Committee recommended that the Citizen Military Forces be retained as the country's immediate reserve of Army units and be renamed the Australian Army Reserve. The Committee also recommended that the members of the Regular Army Reserve, the Regular Army Emergency Reserve and the Reserve Citizen Military Forces be brought into this single Army Reserve organisation. On 4 April 1974, the report was tabled in the House of Representatives by the then Minister for Defence, who announced approval of these two recommendations. It was not appropriate to proceed with formal amendment to the titles and structures of the Reserve Forces until the Government had considered a further recommendation of the Committee that the Army Reserve be available for service in situations short of a proclaimed time of defence emergency. Honourable members will recall that in January 1980 the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) announced that the Government had decided not to vary the availability for service of the Army Reserve.

In recommending a change to the title of the Citizen Military Forces, the Millar Committee recognised the concern within that force that the existing title misrepresented the nature of the Citizen Military Forces. It was considered that the essential nature of the force was more accurately reflected in the title 'Australian Army Reserve'. The validity of the Committee's view is shown by the general acceptance of the title 'Army Reserve', except where the use of the present formal title 'Citizen Military Forces' is dictated by legal requirements. Before legislation could be introduced to reflect the new title, it was necessary to consider whether corresponding title changes should be made to the Citizen Naval Forces and Citizen Air Force. It was also necessary to consider the structures of the citizen forces of all three Services because some of the elements of those forces bore derivative titles such as Active Citizen Military Forces and Active Citizen Air Force.

The Bill amends the Defence Act to rename the Active Citizen Military Forces as the Active Australian Army Reserve and the Reserve Citizen Military Forces as the Inactive Australian Army Reserve. The Regular Army Reserve, which is a non-training element of the permanent military forces, is abolished and its members are transferred to the Inactive Reserve. In the context of reserve forces, 'active' denotes those elements the members of which have specific training obligations. The Bill also removes from the Defence Act reference to the unattached list and the Reserve of Officers. These relate to the internal administrative arrangements of the active and inactive reserves, respectively, which are matters of administrative detail appropriate to be dealt with by the regulations or by determinations under section 33 of the Defence Act. It has been decided not to incorporate the Regular Army Emergency Reserve into the Australian Army Reserve as recommended by the Millar Committee. The Emergency Reserve comprises former members of the Regular Army who agree to become members on cessation of their Regular Army service. Members may be called out by the Governor-General when he considers it desirable to do so.

The enactment of the provisions of the Bill to which I have referred will bring to finality implementation of the recommendations of the Millar Committee, except for those few recommendations with which the Government has chosen not to proceed. Parts III and XV of the Bill amend the Air Force Act 1923 and the Naval Defence Act 1910 to make amendments in relation to the Air Force and the Navy corresponding to the amendments made in respect of the Army. The Bill renames the Citizen Air Force as the Australian Air Force Reserve. It also restructures the Reserve so that the Active Citizen Air Force becomes the Air Force Active Reserve, the Air Force Reserve becomes the Air Force General Reserve and an additional element, the Air Force Specialist Reserve, is introduced. The Air Force Specialist Reserve will comprise officers and airmen having specialist skills, such as doctors, dentists, lawyers and chaplains. Members of the General Reserve and the Specialist Reserve will not usually have peacetime training obligations. The Bill renames the Citizen Naval Forces as the Australian Naval Reserve. It does not deal with the elements into which that body is divided because this is dealt with in regulations under the Act.

The opportunity has been taken to revise the provisions of the Defence Act, the Air Force Act and the Naval Defence Act with regard to the rendering of service-other than continuous full time service-by members of the Reserve Forces. The revised provisions are more closely tailored to the needs of the reserves and provide more accurately for the regulations relating to obligatory and voluntary periods of non-continuous service. Clause 116 amends references in various Acts to the former titles of the reserves forces and to 'continuous full time service'.
Federal Court of Australia Act 1976

Schedule 1 amends the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976 so as to permit an affidavit to be sworn before a district registrar and a deputy district registrar of the Court. It also amends that Act so as to enable a reserved judgment to be delivered at any subsequent sitting of the Court, whether or not the Court is sitting as a full court.
Historic Shipwrecks Act 1976

Part XIII amends sub-section 3 (5) of the Historic Shipwrecks Act 1976. The amendment relates to the description of the area adjacent to Queensland contained in the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 and is consequential on an alteration that is proposed to be made to that description by another Bill during the present sittings.
Migration Act 1958

The purpose of the amendments made to the Migration Act 1958 by clause 59 is to overcome a problem resulting from the amendments of section 16 of the Act that were made by the Migration Amendment Act 1979. Section 16 deems to be a prohibited immigrant a person who, for the purpose of securing entry into Australia, produces or produced to an officer an official document that was not issued to him or was forged or obtained by false representation. A doubt has arisen as to whether section 16 would apply to a person who produced a visa or return authority to an officer before 1 November 1979, which was the date on which the amending Act came into force, in a case where the visa or return authority was not a separate document but was stamped in the person's passport. The amendment will make it clear that the section will apply in such a case. Clause 2 will make the amendment retrospective to 1 November 1979.
Navigation Act 1912
Schedule 1 amends the Navigation Act 1912 so as to enable judges of the Federal Court to sit on courts of marine inquiry without the need for special authorisation by the Governor-General.
Parliamentary Counsel Act 1970

Schedule 1 amends the Parliamentary Counsel Act 1970 to remove any doubts as to the validity of the long-standing practice of making dormant acting appointments to the offices of First and Second Parliamentary Counsel. These are appointments that are made in anticipation of any absences from duty of the holders of those offices and are designed to take effect automatically whenever an absence occurs during the currency of the relevant acting appointment.
Pig Industry Research Act 1971

Schedule 1 inserts the word 'Australian' at the commencement of the name of the Pig Industry Research Committee, which is constituted under the Pig Industry Research Act 1971. This will bring the name of the Committee into line with similar committees established under other Acts.
Public Service Act 1922

Clause 79 corrects an obsolete cross-reference in sub-section 82(6B) of the Public Service Act 1922. That sub-section provided that the services of a temporary employee to whom the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979 applied could not be dispensed with except on the ground that the employee had been guilty of conduct which, if he were an officer, would constitute an offence referred to in sub-section 55(1) of the Public Service Act. However, on 15 March 1981 the provisions of sub-section 55(1) were replaced by the new disciplinary provisions of Division 6 of Part III of the Act. Clause 79 therefore omits the reference to the repealed sub-section 55(1) and replaces it by a reference to specified grounds of dismissal, which are the same grounds as are set out in the new Division 6 of Part III of the Act. Clause 2 provides that clause 79 is to be deemed to have come into operation on 15 March 1981.
Social Services Act 1947

Schedule 1 amends the Social Services Act 1947 to enable claims for age, invalid or widows pension, or sheltered employment allowance, to be lodged with any registrar. That Act presently requires such claims to be lodged with the registrar whose office is nearest the place of residence of the claimant.
Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975

In 1979 the Australian Council of Salaried and Professional Associations and the Australian Council of Trade Unions were amalgamated and the former body ceased to exist. Part XXIII provides for the abolition of the offices of the persons representing the former body on the Australian Council for Union Training, and on each of the State Councils for Union Training, established under the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975, but it increases by one the number of persons representing the ACTU on each of those councils. I commend the Bill to the House.
