DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF CAR PARKS BEHIND PARLIAMENT HOUSE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) who is Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974, the House of Representatives approves the following proposal: Construction of car parks behind the provisional Parliament House.
The motion I have just moved is required in accordance with the provisions of the Parliament Act 1974 to carry out the following works:
1. Seal the presently gravelled temporary car park behind the provisional Parliament House into a bitumen sealed 160-space car park.
2. Provide an additional bitumen seal for a 125-space car park to the east of the House with ingress-egress from Queen Victoria Terrace.

3. Provide security lighting in the form of 10-metre high steel columns with 250-watt mercury lamps in each car park. The lighting will be extended into the West Block car park to replace the existing post-top lanterns.
4. Disturbance to native flora will be minimised. However, it is expected that three trees and some shrubbery will be removed to enable the car park to function efficiently.
The estimated cost of the works is $109,000. I commend the motion to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make one or two comments. The necessity for car parking is an unfortunate scourge which lives in our society. Car parking in the vicinity of Parliament House is quite obviously inadequate. It is unfortunate that the area immediately behind Parliament House has to be disturbed, but that decision, I think, was made some considerable time ago. The area is one of the few natural areas that have been preserved in any of Australia's major cities. That was the result of considerable foresight by earlier generations of Australians. I am not sure that any of us will be delighted with the results of turning a substantial proportion of that area into a concrete jungle, irrespective of the utility the necessity and the convenience for doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: I will briefly raise one other matter. That relates to the inadequacy of the current provisions of the Parliament Act. Because of interpretations which have arisen since the drafting of that Act certain alterations to areas within the Parliamentary Triangle can take place without, in fact, reference to this Parliament. I think the Act has been interpreted extraordinarily narrowly to exclude demolition and removal of items that are not structures. I hope that at some stage the Government will forgo the convenience of not having the constrictions of the Parliament Act applied and will amend the Act so that it protects totally the area included for coverage within the Schedule of that Act. There will then be no doubt that no alterations, such as the removal of the trees proposed a year ago and deemed not to have been covered by the Act, can take place in the future without the Parliament's being aware of it. I think the national Parliament has a right, a responsibility and an obligation to protect that area in which the Parliament operates and the ceremonial areas surrounding it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes) for his remarks. At the same time I take the opportunity to assure him that the points he has made will be taken into consideration.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Mr Viner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate, which commenced last Thursday, we have already heard the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) and the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). As usual, the honourable member for Kooyong unfortunately was very long in rhetoric and short in substance in his speech. He did not really refer in great detail to the secret ballot provisions which are the major part of these amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. The new secret ballot provisions in the Bill can really be summed up in just one word-'lunatic'. The secret ballot provisions introduced by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) are or were a blatant election gimmick with which the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) hoped to capture some easy votes at last year's federal election. As the old saying goes, you can fool some of the people some of the time but not all the people all the time. Without any hesitation I say again that these secret ballots are and were nothing more than an election gimmick.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course the people of Australia want to know the answers to several very important questions: Is there no provision like this in the present Act? How will these new provisions work? Are they practical? If a person goes on strike after a secret ballot has been held how does that person come off strike and go back to work? None of these questions are addressed in any detail in this legislation. I suspect that the Government and, in fact, the Minister have not addressed themselves to these questions either. The answer to the first question is that there is provision now in the Act under section 45 which allows the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to order a ballot of members to ascertain the attitudes of those members in an industry or work place if the Commission sees fit and considers that it will help in the situation or in the negotiations and settlement of the dispute or disputes. For the benefit of every honourable member and for people listening at home, I will read out part of section 45 of the Act so that we all know that in fact such provisions do exist although this Government keeps burying them slightly. The section states:
(1) Where-

(a) an organisation is a party to or concerned in an industrial dispute with which the Commission or some other tribunal acting in pursuance of a law of the Commonwealth is empowered to deal (whether or not proceedings in relation to the dispute are before the Commission or such a tribunal); and

(b) the Commission thinks that the prevention or settlement of the dispute would or might be encouraged or assisted by ascertaining the views or attitude of the members, or of a section or class of the members, of the organisation or of a branch of the organisation in relation to a matter the Commission may order that a vote of those members, or of the members included in that section or class, for the purpose of ascertaining their views or attitude in relation to that matter, be taken by secret ballot.

The honourable member for Wills said on Thursday that the Commission has used that section, although only on a handful of occasions. The section does exist. The power is vested in the Act now for the Commission to use. To quote from the words in the Minister's second reading speech, 'to build on this' we have these wonderful new provisions for secret ballots where only 5 per cent of people in a work place may make application for a secret ballot of all members; that is five people out of 100 or 5 per cent. The practicalities are that while negotiations are taking place, where in a work place 95 out of 100 members are in favour of industrial action of some kind because they feel they have a just cause, five people can make application to the Commission for a secret ballot and completely stifle the negotiations and an early settlement. Let us look at the practical implications that go with this. Negotiations are taking place between an employer and the employees. The rumour is that there could be industrial action of some kind. Five out of 100 members, that is the 5 per cent needed, decide to apply for secret ballot. Now what happens? The Minister's second reading speech states:
The Commission, constituted by a presidential member, will be required to order the conduct of a ballot . . .

So, the presidential member looks into the case and decides whether to conduct a ballot. We will get back to the question of what happens if the presidential member, a Deputy President of the Commission, decides against a ballot. We will assume for a second that he decides for a ballot. Then what happens? We have to draw up the ballot papers, get them all ready, go through the rolls and decide who is eligible to vote and who is not and when and how the ballot will take place. At this stage-it could be several days later-what has happened on the industrial front? Heaven only knows! Negotiations have more than likely become stifled and, in fact, become drawn out by the kerfuffle about the pending secret ballot. Let us get to the crunch. We eventually get around to having the ballot. What happens if the ballot decides that we are all going on strike? The possibility is that it has totally ruined any negotiations that have taken place. The Commission has had to intervene. We are back where we started. How do we get off strike and back to work if the negotiations have reached that stage? I assume that we have another secret ballot. After all, we had a secret ballot to go on strike. I suppose that we now have to have another secret ballot to come off strike and to go back to work. All in all this process has probably taken nearly a week and done more harm than good. The employees will not like it in general. The employers will not like it. It will hinder their operations and the possibilities of good and peaceful settlements much more than it will help them. The Commission will find it an absolute nightmare.

One very interesting thing about the Minister's second reading speech is that the Minister does not mention anything on the situation that I have just mentioned. His silence on the matter would suggest-this is how I read his speech-that in the majority of cases employees will vote against industrial action. I quote from the report of the Royal Commission on Trade Unions and Employers Associations 1965-68, from which the honourable member for Wills also quoted. There is some more very interesting information in this report. The Chairman of the Royal Commission was the Right Honourable Lord Donovan. The report was presented to the British Parliament in 1968. The references to 'official' and 'unofficial' in the report relate to the British system and not to the Australian system. In paragraph 426 this famous Donovan Royal Commission stated on the issue of compulsory strike ballots:

A number of witnesses have suggested to us that a secret ballot should be required before a strike can lawfully take place. This proposal is based on the belief that workers are likely to be less militant than their leaders and that, given the opportunity of such a ballot, they would often be likely to vote against strike action.
It seems that our present Prime Minister must have given evidence. In paragraph 427 the report stated:

It is clear that the scope of any legislation to this end, if it were to be effective, would have to be confined to major official strikes. A law forbidding strike action before the holding of a secret ballot could not be enforced in the case of small-scale unofficial stoppages, which make up the overwhelming majority of the total number of strikes.
The honourable member for Wills quoted the following words of this famous Donovan Royal Commission:

There is little justification in the available evidence for the view that workers are less likely to vote for strike action than their leaders; and findings from our workshop relations survey, already cited, confirm this. Experience in the USA has been that strike ballots are overwhelmingly likely to go in favour of strike action. This is also the experience of Canada, where strike ballots are compulsory in the provinces of Alberta and British Columbia.
Paragraph 429 stated:

There are other objections to such ballots. Once a vote has been taken and has gone in favour of strike action, the resulting stoppage may delay a settlement by restricting union leaders' freedom of action.

This is exactly what I have just said. In Australia from 1975 to 1978 half the number of the strikes recorded by the Australian Bureau of Statistics were of one day's duration or less. I ask leave of the House to incorporate in Hansard tables to that effect.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. It would pay the Government and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) to do some long and hard homework on industrial relations. These secret ballot provisions are absolute lunacy. However, I must say that they are in accord with the Government's record. I ask the Minister to look at clause 6 and proposed new sub-section (3D) of the Bill, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to this section, the Commission shall, upon an application made to it under sub-section (3A), order that a vote of the members to whom the application relates-

Later the proposed new sub-section uses the words 'to which the application relates'. I sincerely ask the Minister: What does that mean? Does that mean that people in one work place can make an application for their work mates in the same work place, or does that mean also that people in one work place can make application for people in another work place on the other side of the city? It is not very clear at all. Of course such questions have to be cleared up by regulations. I would prefer this matter to be cleared up in the Parliament now. If it has to be cleared up with regulations, of course, the regulations have to lie before both the Houses of Parliament. I suggest to this Government that there is quite a possibility that after 1 July those regulations will not be allowed.

This Government has a reputation for confrontation and divisiveness. It has a never-ending resolve to set one Australian against another. History will see this Government in that light-make no mistake about that. These secret ballot provisions will continue this Government's policies of hampering and hindering good industrial relations and once again set Australian against Australian. Talking about that, may I get back to the situation that would obtain if a Deputy President of the Commission refused to grant a secret ballot. The Minister's second reading speech states:
. . . a refusal to order a place of work ballot must be reviewed automatically by the President of the Commission.

In other words, the Deputy Presidents will be watched over by the President, at present Sir John Moore. What a position to place the President in. The Deputy Presidents of the Commission are all honourable and learned people of high integrity; yet in this case they are unable to make a decision without that decision and them being reviewed by the President. What an outrageous situation. To get one person to look over the shoulder of another is just not the way to help solve and further better industrial relations in any way, shape or form.

Like the honourable member for Wills, I was also outraged that the amendments relating to union amalgamations are not being introduced with the secret ballot amendments, as the Prime Minister and former Minister for Industrial Relations Street promised they would be. But we are used to broken promises from this Government and this Prime Minister. After the election the Minister for Industrial Relations announced that the Government had decided to introduce the legislation during the autumn session this year in order 'to meet the Government's commitment to introduce this legislation as indicated by the Prime Minister in his policy speech'. Despite all the assurances and the Government's alleged commitment to consultation, the legislation relating to union amalgamations has been shoved under the carpet. I do not suppose that this is any news to us, though, because had it been introduced it would have been the first piece of industrial legislation that the Fraser Government introduced with the support of both the employers and the unions. The proposed changes to the law relating to amalgamations were first raised by the Australian Council of Trade Unions at the National Labour Consultative Council meeting in April 1978. The changes were the subject of almost three years consideration by a specialist committee of the NLCC which comprised senior representatives of the Department of Industrial Relations, national employers and the union movement. A unanimous proposal for changes to the amalgamation law was endorsed by the NLCC and forwarded to the Government. The Minister for Industrial Relations at the time, Mr Street, in announcing the Government's intention to introduce legislation to effect the changes, stated:
It is now widely agreed that the current amalgamation provisions impose considerable constraints and can operate to delay or prevent what might otherwise be desirable amalgamations.

This Government has now deferred the only constructive piece of industrial legislation that it has come close to introducing. In contrast, of course, the secret ballot provisions were not asked for by the national union bodies or the national employers. The national employers do not particularly want this legislation. The Government knows it. The national employers can see the dangers that exist for them in this legislation, as I mentioned earlier. This Government, with its absolute resolve for confrontation and to create industrial problems rather than solve them, have once again set Australia on a course of industrial disputation. Now, as one who has been an executive member of a union for some six years, I can say quite categorically that it is impossible for officials of a union to tell members of a union to go on strike, place bans on the employer, or cause some other industrial action to be taken, if the members do not wish to take that action. Any sensible union official knows how his members feel. He can read the feelings of his members and, in fact, when the meetings of members take place he gets a very clear indication of what the members want. Any union official that tries to push his own views on the members against their massive membership reaction is just plain idiotic.

However, this Government continues to attempt to portray the image of the union official as some big bogeyman who leads the poor employees by the nose through thick and thin without any regard for their welfare. The truth is that it is this Federal Government that has little regard for the welfare for the people of Australia. If it did, it would not be bringing into this place legislation such as we have before us today. It is totally ridiculous and will hinder good industrial relations, as I have said before.

Since the Fraser Government came to power in 1975 its approach to industrial relations has been disastrous. In the majority of cases there has been absolutely no attempt by this Government to solve industrial problems peacefully and in a rational way. The manic behaviour of the Prime Minister-if I may borrow a phrase from the honourable member for Kooyong-backed up by the present Minister for Industrial Relations, the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) and the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair), is a disgrace to this Parliament. In fact, this is what the Minister for Communications had to say on 22 May-just last Friday week-in the middle of the very important and delicate negotiations that were going on at that stage and that are continuing at present in regard to the Telecom dispute. This Minister, in an exercise in how to win friends and influence people in the industrial world, addressed the National Party conference in Queensland. He began his speech by saying:
It has been an extraordinary week of head burying in the sands of futility by a number of people on the industrial front.
He then referred to the Telecom unions. He continued:
They are both as groups set on a course of industrial anarchy through not pursuing claims along the announced and agreed lines under the announced and agreed umpire's rules.

Imagine that-the umpire's rules! It is just like the umpire's decision which this Government accepted in regard to Public Service Determination 503! After months of negotiation and arbitration, the umpire brought down a decision and this Government disallowed it. It shot the umpire. Yet the Minister for Communications had the effrontery to mention the umpire's rules. The Minister for Industrial Relations also likes to play the game by his rules. In the Telecom debate of last week he failed to address himself to the existing Telecom dispute at all.

These amendments-that is, the amendments concerning the secret ballots-were purely an election gimmick and have no practical validity at all. As history will very shortly prove, the introduction of these lunatic provisions and the complete absence of the amalgamation provisions, which would assist industrial harmony greatly, are just more nails in the coffin of this Federal Government. This Government should be condemned in the strongest possible terms, although unfortunately we have become used to seeing this Government stagger from crisis to crisis. It is surely staggering like a drunken sailor to a massive defeat at the next Federal election and will continue on that path if it keeps introducing ridiculous legislation such as that before the House at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: — There are three questions that need to be asked about the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill which is before this House. The first is: What are the main purposes of the Bill? The second is: How are those purposes to be achieved? The third is: Are those purposes consistent with the spirit and intent of the provision in the Constitution which gives to this Parliament the power to make laws with respect to the prevention and settlement of disputes of an industrial nature extending beyond any one State by means of conciliation and arbitration? I now address myself to the two main purposes of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, the Bill seeks to give to members of an organisation, or of a branch, working for a particular employer and at a particular place of work the right to have their views taken into account by means of a secret ballot when directed or requested by that organisation or branch to engage in industrial action. Secondly, in cases where the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission forms the view that the majority of the members of the organisation or branch who have recorded a valid vote in a ballot ordered to be held under the proposed legislation were not in favour of engaging in the industrial action with which that ballot was concerned, the members are to be freed from compliance with a direction or request made by the organisation to engage in or support that industrial action; that is, the industrial action which is the subject of that ballot.

How are these purposes to be achieved? They are to be achieved by carefully regulated steps which must be understood if the Bill is to be dispassionately examined and not simply emotionally expounded. The steps are these: In the first place, there must be a direction or a request made on behalf of the organisation or branch or made under the rules of the organisation or branch. This Bill is not concerned with unofficial strikes, so we can put that matter to one side. The direction or request to engage in industrial action must be made to members of an organisation or branch employed by a particular employer at a particular place of work. We are not concerned with people across the way, as the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) seems to think we are. We are concerned with particular employees at a particular place of work. When the direction or request is given, and if the requisite minimum number of members employed by the same employer at the same place wish to do so, they may apply for a secret ballot. For what purpose? For the purpose of ascertaining whether they support the industrial action in question. That is the matter which seems to be so objectionable to honourable members on the other side of the House. What happens then? The next step is that the application is heard by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission constituted by a presidential member.

When the application is heard the Commission shall order that a ballot be held and give the directions unless it comes to one of four views. These are the matters that were entirely ignored by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) and the honourable member for Isaacs. Firstly, if the Commission forms the view that cessation or prevention of the industrial action or the settlement of the matters giving rise to the industrial action to which the application for the ballot relates would not be encouraged or assisted by ascertaining the views of the members to whom the application relates-that is, those members at a particular place of work employed by a particular employee-the application is to be refused. In the second case, if the view is come to by the Commission that the industrial action to which the application relates has ceased, then again the application is to be refused. Thirdly, if the cessation of the industrial action is imminent and the Commission forms that view, then once again the application is to be refused. Fourthly, if the Commission forms the view that the industrial action to which the application relates is not likely to take place, again it is to be refused. Of course, this matter has to go ultimately to the President, but that does not matter. That is simply a question of procedure. So there are four bases on which the application can be refused which would exclude the kind of vexatious litigant that the honourable member for Wills sought to draw out of his hat.

Next, if after a secret ballot has been ordered it appears that the dispute has been settled or the industrial action has ceased, or that settlement or cessation is imminent, or that the industrial action concerned is not likely to take place, then after the ordering of a secret ballot but before the vote, when one of those matters appears the Commission shall revoke the order for the secret ballot. That is the way in which the procedures for the hearing of an application and for orders made work. Now, what happens if a ballot is heard and not revoked? If that be the case, notice of the result shall be given to the organisation to which the members belong, the persons eligible to vote, and the employer. That seems perfectly sensible and perfectly straight forward. Next, if the Commission forms the view that the majority of those who recorded valid votes were not in favour of engaging in the industrial action with which the ballot was concerned a statement to that effect shall be given to the organisation, the employer, and those eligible to vote. Again, that is perfectly straightforward and perfectly sensible.

What then are the consequences when a ballot has been taken? The consequences for the ongoing process of work and conciliation and arbitration are, first, that the Commission shall have regard to the result. This simply makes clear the view of the rank and file, not in the somewhat fantastic way that was put forward by the honourable member for Wills but as a sensible and clear guide of the views of the rank and file. Secondly, where the Commission forms the view that amongst those who recorded a valid vote there was a majority who were not in favour of the industrial action in question, then the members are relieved from compliance with requests or directions that they engage in that industrial action. The fundamental point is that those who are directly and immediately concerned should have a right to have a say about their own industrial destiny.

A number of objections were raised to the Bill by the honourable member for Wills, when he got around to addressing it. He spent about half of his time talking about a provision which is not before this House. His attitude to secret ballots is somewhat inconsistent. On the same day and, indeed, in the same speech he commended secret ballots when he said that 98 per cent of persons concerned in a certain ballot had voted in a particular way-that is a very sensible thing for him to have said because it gave a clear indication of the views of the members concerned-yet in the same speech he found something wrong with the proposition that there should be secret ballots.

I put aside some of the general criticisms made by the honourable member for Wills and also by the honourable member for Isaacs, which were simply general by nature-assertions that the legislation is bad, that it is all wrong-and deal with some of the particular matters raised by the honourable member for Wills.

Firstly, he seemed to object to the fact that the Government was keeping an election promise. Secondly, he raised questions of practical difficulties. No doubt in some cases there will be practical difficulties. In other cases, there will not be practical difficulties. It has to be borne in mind that we are not talking of an organisation vote, we are talking of a vote taken of the employees of a particular employer. He then said, and this seemed to be the major thrust of his argument, that there had been a general condemnation by all academics of any standing, so far as one could gather, of the kind of legislation that is before this House. All one can say of what he said on that subject is that his coverage was incomplete and his comments were utterly irrelevant. First, I will deal with his coverage. He cited what Sir John Moore had to say, and he quoted this passage from the Age:
Sir John also warned that compulsory ballots for unions contemplating strikes would not be as effective as many people believed in reducing strikes.
The honourable member for Wills ended his quotations there. The article continued:
In some cases, workers would have left the job before a ballot could be organised and the mechanics of a ballot would be almost overwhelming.
In the case of the 150,000-strong Amalgamated Metal Workers and Ship Wrights Union, it would be virtually impossible to conduct a poll of all its members.

There, Sir John was directing his attention to a secret ballot of an entire organisation. Next, the honourable member referred to the Donovan report of 1968, and he cited that as convincing evidence that the Government's approach was wrong. His knowledge of the English scene seems to have stopped in 1968. If he had turned his attention to 1969 he would have found that the Labour Government in 1969 proposed that in certain circumstances there should be secret ballots. I quote from Great Britain Trade Union Immunities 1981, paragraph 248, which states:
Another proposal, that the Secretary of State should be able to require a union to hold a secret ballot before a major official strike, was considered in 1969-
That was the year after the Donovan report-

in the Labour Government's White Paper, 'In Place of Strife'. The White Paper said that it was 'a matter for concern that at present it is possible for a major official strike to be called when the support of those involved may be in doubt'. It proposed that the Secretary of State should have discretionary power to require the union or unions involved to hold a ballot on the question of strike action. The power would be used where the Secretary of State believed that the proposed strike would 'involve a serious threat to the economy or public interest' and there was doubt whether it commanded the support of those concerned.

That was in the year following the Donovan report, something that the honourable member for Wills conveniently overlooked when he said that it was universal, as we understand him, that academic opinion was in favour of the proposition he was putting. Thirdly, if he was looking at academic opinions or, indeed, at industrial action, he might have cast his mind to what has taken place in Germany for very many years. If he wishes to look at this, it is to be found at page 13 of 'Trade Unions in West Germany' in the Westview Press 1976. There we find-I summarise what is said-that the German unions have adopted the principle that a strike may not take place until there has been a secret ballot and a 75 per cent majority must be obtained before the strike can commence. What the honourable member said was incomplete and, secondly, it was irrelevant. It was irrelevant because the question to which the authors to whom he referred were addressing their attention was that of compulsory secret ballots. That is not the question before the House. The question before the House is that of ballots at the request of members; ballots which are secret but not compulsory.

Let us recall certain fundamental facts about the affairs of registered organisations. Many of their officials are elected only every four years. Of course, that means that those organisations may get out of touch with the affairs of their members. Such elections are permitted under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, but it is perfectly plain that the organisations can get out of touch, as the honourable member for Wills well knows. One of the reasons is, that it is perfectly plain that they can get out of touch because of the very high turnover of members in certain areas; for example, employees in shops. The size of organisations alone can put officials out of touch. One looks to the size of some of the unions such as the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union of 160,000 members; the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association of 145,000 members; and the Australian Workers Union of 130,000 members. How is it that the leaders of these unions will at all times be conscious of what is happening in all places and in the hearts and minds of all their members? Of course they will not! Of course they can get out of touch! Indeed, in many cases union members will have never had the opportunity to participate in the ballot for the very simple reason-I speak now of a ballot for the election of union officials-that they have joined a union between four-year ballots. Of course, in other cases members may feel that undue pressures have been brought to bear on them and they wish to have an opportunity to express a view that is free from pressure. In some cases strikes are brought about for purely political purposes-strikes that have nothing to do with the working interests of union members. A case that the honourable member for Wills would well understand is the possibility of directions being given in respect of uranium mining because that is contrary to the policy of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It might be exceedingly relevant for the Commission to know the views of those members of unions who earn their living from mining. As I have said, that is quite contrary to the views of the ACTU.

I conclude by making the following comment: We have had secret ballot provisions in this country for many years. They are to be found in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act and in the New South Wales industrial and arbitration Act. I believe there is a provision in the Western Australian Act which deals with industrial matters. These provisions have given to a court or to the Commission power to order a secret ballot of their own volition. The provisions before the House are essentially different. Those provisions open the way to members to initiate the procedure of a secret ballot themselves. I do not suggest for one moment that these provisions represent a panacea. They may be seldom used, but they give individuals a greater opportunity to have a say in their own affairs, something which honourable members on the other side of the House seem to resent. That accords with the intent of the provision in the Constitution which gives to this House power to pass laws in respect of conciliation and arbitration for the prevention and settlement of industrial disputes. How better, when the right time arises, to get a view of what the members really want than to conduct a ballot which is not ordered by a court or by any government but which is requested by the members?

It is right that trade unions should be an essential part of the fabric of our life, but it is right also that since their very reason for existence is to represent the individual interests of their members those members should have the right to vote on questions which directly and immediately concern their very means of livelihood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The attitude expressed by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) and his lack of knowledge as to how the trade union movement operates and what occurs in strike situations really indicate all that is wrong with this legislation. The Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill is ill-conceived and unnecessary. Rather than make any contribution to the settlement of industrial disputes it will compound the problems faced by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in its daily task of trying to resolve issues of industrial confrontation. The principal spokesman for the Opposition, the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), has already indicated to the House that the Government has failed to introduce legislation to facilitate the amalgamation of unions, despite three years of work by both employer and employee organisations and the endorsement of the National Labour Consultative Council, despite the fact that the Bill is ready and available and despite the agreement of the employer groups and the trade union movement that such legislation is long overdue and vitally necessary to the proper development of our industrial relations.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead of having a Bill which is designed to facilitate and make industrial relations in this community easier, as requested by employer and trade union organisations, where the work has been done and where the legislation is already drafted, we have this legislation for secret ballots in respect of industrial action in particular places of work. Surely the Parliament is entitled to ask: 'What is the origin of this legislation?' There certainly has been no demand for it from the Commission. It has not been seriously argued for by any significant employer group in this nation and certainly no trade union group. When the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) or the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) referred this concept to the National Labour Consultative Council the Government was told by that body, which represents trade union and employer interests in this nation, that this concept was not necessary. I would have thought in that situation even the most ardent supporter of the Government might have said: 'If the trade union movement'-whom the Government suspects-'and the employers'-whom the Government loves-'are agreed that legislation of this kind is not necessary, perhaps we ought to heed their advice, or perhaps we ought to seek the advice of those members of the Commission who have to face these problems day after day'. Indeed the Parliament has had quoted to it both the views of academic writers operating full time in the industrial relations field and the views of so eminent a person in that area as Sir John Moore, the President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission expressing their doubts as to the effectiveness of legislation of this type. Instead of having before us-as the Parliament is entitled to expect-legislation dealing with union amalgamation we now have this hotchpotch legislation which will not solve industrial problems but, indeed, will compound them.

Where does the Parliament look to find the arguments, the reasons, and the justification for this ill-conceived proposal? The only answer that we have been given by the honourable member for North Sydney was that this was the Prime Minister's promise; that is to say, the whole concept of this legislation is to be found in the Prime Minister's, somewhat narrow view of industrial relations. It is a view in which the Prime Minister's introversion is equalled only by his naivete and his 'macho' need for confrontation. He believes, as do many of his supporters, that every strike is the result of manipulation by radical union bosses-he does not even say communist union bosses-and that the victims of this manipulation, the ordinary, decent Australian male and female workers, will be saved from the results of this continual and ongoing manipulation only by the intervention of this warm-hearted Prime Minister, and this legislation. He believes, as does the honourable member for North Sydney, a man much experienced in industrial relations-his experience shows when he addresses the Parliament--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is a good parliamentarian, too.
—He is probably modelling himself on the Minister for Housing and Construction, so that instead of one political dunce we will have two political dunces.
—See what the electors say.

—I know what the electors would say about this legislation. We should consider the Government's view of men and women who go on strike. Has the Minister for Housing and Construction ever heard either the Prime Minister or the Minister for Industrial Relations say in this Parliament that there might be some justice in a strike, there might be a view that ought to be considered by the Government as to the rightness or the cause of those unionists resorting to industrial action? I have never heard that, and neither has any member of this Parliament. We are not likely to hear it. We are now asked to adopt this legislation because it is the Prime Minister's view that if we give all the decent, ordinary union members, men and women, who he behoves are being manipulated all the time, the right to this odd and secret ballot then the anonymity of that ballot will give them the courage to say 'no' to industrial action. That, at heart, is the underlying philosophy which is the reason for this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the social class condescension that underlines this view, this Parliament is being asked to overlook the fact that on almost every occasion a majority decision of workers in the work place is required before any industrial action is taken. Many industrial actions and stoppages take place without the immediate knowledge of the trade union executives or their full time secretaries and officers. They hear about the problems in the workshop, after the stoppage has taken place, when someone has to sort the matter out. It also overlooks that other essential factor in any strike action-that every worker involved in strike action votes continuously on a daily or weekly basis in respect of that strike, because he votes with his hip pocket. There is no industrial action, no stoppage of work, which does not ultimately involve some loss of wages and some financial hardship for those who take that decision. That being the case, we have to go to examples of this type of legislation being considered in other communities. The honourable member for Wills has already pointed out how the Donovan commission-that was a high-powered commission looking at the whole question of industrial relations-rejected this concept. This concept of strike ballots before legislation has been tried in those communities where the industrial relations system, unlike ours, is based upon the concept of collective bargaining. They do not have the processes of conciliation and arbitration and the intervention of judicial and semi-judicial procedures to try to resolve the industrial issues between the parties.

It is interesting to note that in both the United States and Canada during the war secret ballot strike legislation was introduced. The premises were exactly the same. The governments were in a wartime situation and wanted to minimise industrial strikes. Those governments, quite frankly, took the view that if there were strike ballots then industrial stoppages would be reduced. I wish to quote from an authoritative article which analyses the success of those proposals. It is an article by Mr F. R. Anton entitled 'Work Stoppages: Should Authorisation be Mandatory?' Having examined the origin of that legislation and how it worked, he concluded:

It is reasonable to assume that both the Canadian and United States governments enacted strike vote legislation in wartime to limit a union's right to strike, in the hope of minimizing the number of strikes and thus enabling war production to be maximized. Official statements made at that time support this assumption. But no available evidence indicates that such legislation reduced the number of work stoppages. For what it is worth, many of those who administered the strike vote in the United States held the view that such legislation tended to foster, rather than discourage, strikes. There were indications in Canada too that in no important dispute did workers vote against strike action. Moreover, the impression was gained that whenever strike votes were conducted on federal authority, the public tended to regard such supervised voting as carrying government sanction for a strike.
Here is an objective analysis of this type of legislation in a collective bargaining situation, in both the United States and Canada. What is the conclusion? It is this:
It is therefore significant that in spite of substantial pressures, neither of the central governments saw fit to extend the stroke vote requirement into postwar legislation.

I commend that article to honourable members opposite who obviously do not understand the complexities of our industrial and conciliation system, who do not understand the way in which stroke situations and industrial problems arise or the way in which they are resolved. What we put to this House-I do not think the Government will listen but we are bound to put it-is that this legislation will not make the solution of industrial stoppages any easier. It will compound the problem for the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It involves some very naive concepts, including some very naive legal concepts. I do not know what a commissioner is supposed to do. He is required to recognise the result of a ballot. What occurs if a ballot is conducted in a work place of 1,000 people and 200 people vote against the strike, 400 people vote for it and the others do not vote at all? Is a non-vote to be regarded as a vote in favour or a vote against? What position is a commissioner placed in when he is involved in trying to settle a dispute and there is an overwhelming vote in favour of a strike and its continuance?

TALK.START.PARA: —It shows the depth of feeling.

—It shows the depth of feeling. Will the commissioner say that, having regard to this depth of feeling, he will do nothing to resolve the situation? Supposing people in a work place overstate their case and demand $50 when they really want only $10 or $20. Does the commissioner say that he cannot have regard to the view that $10 or $20 is a proper figure on which to conciliate because the depth of feeling among employees has been shown to be so overwhelming that he must say to them that the only proper thing he can do to resolve the matter is to give them all they require? That is the kind of legal nonsense being perpetrated in this Parliament and heaped on to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. In the name of whom? Is it in the name of the employers? No. In the name of the trade union movement? No. Their responsible bodies have said that they do not require this legislation. This legislation is being heaped on to the Commission, creating incredible problems, not merely for those who are involved in the conciliation and arbitration process but also for employers and responsible trade union leaders, to suit the industrial fantasies of this Prime Minister and to satisfy the industrial viciousness of the present Minister for Industrial Relations. That is the reason for this legislation and that is the reason it ought to be rejected by this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main provision of this amendment to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act is to enable members of a union at a particular place of work to have a secret ballot in connection with a request that may be made of those members to take part in industrial action. In other words, if the union demands that its members at a factory go on strike the members of the union at that factory can request and take part in a secret ballot to decide whether in fact they want to go on strike.

SPEECH.PARA: Before dealing with the details of the legislation I would like to deal in the broad for a moment with the reasons the Government has been prompted to introduce this Bill. We have said many times, and it is worth repeating, that in the industrial relations field it is clear that each member of the community has both rights and responsibilities. Further, the rights of the individual ought to be protected whilst at the same time the individual must meet his or her obligations. This legislation is designed to protect the rights of the individual in the work place. It may also be seen in the wider context to be protecting the community against industrial disruption undertaken by members of a union acting under direction rather than in accordance with their wishes.

There is no doubt that one of the most powerful weapons of the unions, and indeed an important right of the individual worker, is the right to strike. My concern, and I believe the concern of the community, is that the right to strike is no longer being used by many unions as a powerful weapon of last resort; rather, in the fragile field of industrial relations, it is being used as an initiating manoeuvre in order to soften up or lower the resistance of the employers to the unions' demands. At the same time, little account appears to be taken of the effects of such action upon those who are not directly involved in the dispute. Further, the right to strike has now been adopted by some unions as a political weapon to be used in political disputes outside the industrial relations area. I quote just one example. On 20 May this year an article in the Australian newspaper stated:

The ACTU last night threatened 'direct industrial action' against companies which moved to buy government enterprises put up for sale to the private sector. The ACTU President, Mr Dolan, is quoted as warning that action, which would involve strikes and possibly union bans on companies' products, could be taken in the areas of operation of any company which considers buying government businesses. This move by the unions is a direct attack on the implementation of decisions announced by this Federal Government in the report on the Review of Commonwealth Functions or, as it is known, the decisions of the razor gang. Those decisions were made by the properly and democratically elected government which was elected only late last year. The Australian Council of Trade Unions is apparently saying that the Australian people can elect whatever government they like but if the ACTU does not like the decisions of that democratically elected government then it, as a minority group in Australia, will use industrial muscle to prevent the implementation of that Government's decisions.

The same newspaper article reports that Mr Dolan said that union action taken against this Government's decisions would involve top level consultation between the Federal Labor Party and ACTU officials. So the Labor Opposition, not satisfied with the results of the election, is trying to stuff its socialist dogma down the throats of the unwilling public through the ACTU.
Not content with the use of its industrial muscle for political purposes, as the Sydney Morning Herald reported the next day:
The ACTU threw down the gauntlet yesterday to the Arbitration Commission and employers by deciding to press on with its campaign for shorter working hours through productivity bargaining. It--
That is the ACTU-
reiterated its support for centralised wage fixing but rejected the Commission's new guidelines.
The article went on:

After yesterday's executive session, the ACTU President, Mr Dolan forecast that the next few months would see the stormiest period in industrial relations since 1947-49, when the Chifley Government sent soldiers in to work strike-hit coal mines.

The article then stated that Mr Dolan nominated Telecom Australia, Australia Post and the road transport industry as likely trouble spots. So the ACTU has threatened to use the strike weapon on one day against the Government and on the next day against the decisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. At the same time the unions have refused to take part in the proposed inquiry into wage determination and industrial relations. Instead of adopting a positive role they are embarking on a course of massive industrial unrest and disruption. It is my view that this is not a course of action which is accepted by the general public as being either desirable or correct. Within the Australian context I believe it is an abuse of the strike weapon.

This legislation will provide the opportunity for union members to express their wishes in relation to such demands made on them by their union executive. I believe that the people of Australia, employees, consumers, employers and small businessmen-are fed up with the number of strikes in this country. Employees, especially those working in industry, are sick to death of the constant threat and uncertainty which industrial disruption poses to their weekly pay packet. Employees, especially those with young families and a high level of commitments, are naturally and justifiably concerned about their ability to meet their commitments in the event of industrial disruption. Their concern relates not just to being involved directly in an industrial dispute but also to being stood down as a result of being employed in a factory or business which is incapable of maintaining their employment because of an industrial dispute in a related area. Employers are loath to stand down workers. However, if there is no work for those employees they cannot keep them on for very long.

Consumers are another group of people who are inevitably affected by industrial disputes. It seems that many unions in their cavalier attitude towards the use of the strike weapon have no thought for their fellow employees or the consumers who may be affected by their decisions. Consumers, of course, have to pay more for goods because the cost of industrial disputes is built into the cost of the final product. Consumers are often directly and dramatically affected by industrial disputes. For example, travellers relying on Qantas Airways Ltd have been marooned around the world. On the domestic scene, we have a strike involving the domestic air services almost whenever a holiday period is imminent. This was the case both last Christmas and at Easter of this year. It is a classic example of the disruption to services which hits those least able to protect themselves.

Only last week there was a strike in both Sydney and Adelaide by railway workers. This strike was held without warning and with complete disregard for members of the public who had to get home from work that night.

Further, the high level of industrial disruption affects every member of the community through the damage it causes to the economy. Industrial disputes affect business confidence and businessmen's decisions to invest, and therefore the jobs and the standard of living of all Australians. The level of disruption has affected our trading position. We are continually being made aware of countries-such as Japan, a major customer of ours-because of the uncertainty of supply, being unable to rely solely on Australia for the goods which they desire to purchase from us. They are forced, therefore, to spread their purchases amongst other countries, and we are the losers. As I have mentioned, strikes and the like increase the costs of our goods, and thus we also become less competitive on the world market.

This legislation is designed to assist in the protection of the rights of individuals and to protect the community from industrial disruption. It will assist in the development of democratic procedures by introducing a mechanism by which the rank and file union member can express his attitude on a request put to him for industrial action. It will promote communication and consultation between the union executive and its members. It is hoped that this will result in the union executive's becoming more responsive to its members' feelings. Secret ballots will also avoid some of the bullying and standover tactics which, it has been alleged, have taken place in the past. They will also prevent the rigging of such ballots through the importation of members from other unions. I hope that the Bill will reduce the abuse by militant unions of the right to strike and lead to more responsible action by their leaders, who will be directly answerable to their membership.

The legislation provides that 5 per cent of the members of a union at a work place can apply to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for a secret ballot either before or during a strike. That figure of 5 per cent is subject to a maximum requirement of 250 members if there is a large number of members of the union in that work place. There is also a minimum requirement of four people in a case where, for example, there are less than 100 union members in a certain work place. Where a ballot has been requested and the Commission orders it, it will be conducted by the Industrial Registrar or the Australian Electoral Office. The Commission will then be required to have regard to the result of the ballot in its consideration of the matter. Additionally, and perhaps more importantly, when the result of the vote is against the action demanded by the union executive, the members are relieved of any obligation under the rules of their organisation to obey that direction or request for industrial action. In other words, if a group of employees is not satisfied with the union demand to undertake industrial action, it can call for a vote. If the majority is against the union recommendation, it will be unlawful for a union to impose or try to recover a fine under its rules against a member not participating in the industrial action which was the subject of the ballot.

In addition, protection will be provided by amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act in this Bill against victimisation, intimidation or coercion by the union of those members who apply for a secret ballot. The legislation extends not only to those in an identifiable location, such as a factory, but also to those who are required to report regularly to a place in connection with their work, such as air hostesses or timber workers. The Act applies not only to strike action recommended or directed by the union but also to other industrial action such as go-slows or doing only some of the work normally undertaken. The legislation is, therefore, an attempt by the Government to ensure that the rank and file has an opportunity to express its view in relation to a union request or demand for industrial action.

The enactment of this Bill will not mean the end of industrial disputes. I do not believe it is possible for us to achieve that goal within our constitutional power, except perhaps in some specific emergencies. However, I hope that this secret ballot legislation will lead to a reduction in the number and length of industrial disputes in this country for the benefit of all Australians. I strongly support the Bill and urge rank and file union members to exercise their rights under this legislation to express their views.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleagues in strongly opposing the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill which, in our view, further demonstrates the attempt by this Government to attack the trade unions and the living standards of workers. The general weaknesses in this Bill have already been aptly demonstrated by other Labor speakers. I shall concentrate my remarks on the values and attitudes on which this Bill is based. Union bashing by this Government and, to some degree, by the media has often taken the form of hysterical and irrational outbursts of the kind we have just heard. Recently, the Fraser Government has engaged in something more ominous-an attempt to undermine, subvert and destroy the union movement and thereby to water down the basic rights of workers to organise, unite and withdraw their labour.

SPEECH.PARA: Undoubtedly this Government seeks to take advantage of an atmosphere of antagonism which it has created through its continuous attempts to blame the economic problems of this nation on the trade union movement. Because of the cacophony of abuse being heaped on that movement and its leaders there is danger that the true meaning and real worth of the trade union movement will be forgotten. There is a danger, therefore, that the people of Australia will be hoodwinked into supporting attacks on those very organisations, the trade unions, which have been primarily responsible, throughout the history of the present economic system, for improvements in their standards of living and conditions of employment. That point needs to be made strongly to those Australian workers, whether in offices, shops or factories, who have become or are becoming apathetic about it. Without the solidarity of the union movement and the many struggles by workers of previous generations, wages would be much lower than they are at present; the majority of people would be living in dire poverty; hours of employment would be long; and conditions of employment would be atrocious.

Even a cursory look at the historical development of Western economies and the role of unions within them clearly proves this claim. In the nineteenth century, capitalist economies were riddled with crises of over-production of goods and under consumption by workers who could not afford them. In order to survive in that cut-throat world, business leaders attempted to reduce wages. Where this succeeded it led to increasing poverty and misery for workers. They barely had enough to provide for food and shelter. The only way available to combat this tendency of the capitalist system was the organisation of workers into unions. 'Workers Unite' thus became the rallying call of the working class in its attempts to counter these oppressive conditions. Their major weapon in that struggle was the strike, which is nothing more than the communal withdrawal by all the members of the union of their labour. The early unionists sought the protection of workers against the attempt to reduce their wages and to make conditions of employment even worse than they were. The corollary to this was to try to improve the wages and conditions of their members.

Historians have recorded the huge struggles that occurred in Australia in the 1880s and 1890s in which employers, supported by the State, by the Government, attempted to crush the development of unionism. In fact, in many cases the Government succeeded in beating workers into submission. These lessons of history have been forgotten by some of those who enjoy the benefits, in terms of wages and conditions, of those struggles and many others that came later.

TALK.START.PARA: —They never knew them.

—My colleague said 'they never knew them', but they certainly are finding out more about them at present because they are having to struggle once again, because of the actions of this Government, to retain the kind of standards of living which they achieved before. It was at this time and because of this point that the unions also recognised that they would have to fight through the political and democratic process. I am pleased that this last point regarding the trade union origins of the Australian Labor Party is to be specifically included in the new platform of the party, if the Federal Executive's recommendation is accepted. This point reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP has its origins in the recognition by the trade union movement of the necessity for a political voice to take forward the struggle of the working class against the excesses, injustices and inequalities of capitalism.

The present Government in its attitude to unions seeks to return to the nineteenth century situation when workers' organisations were weak and could be crushed by a joint alliance between big business and the government. The Government seeks to use force against the unions so that they cannot achieve any improvements in the wages and conditions of workers. With this secret ballot legislation the Government seeks to castrate the trade union movement. As I shall point out later, it will not succeed. Indeed, there is no doubt that this Government seeks to reverse the gains made by workers in recent years and to reduce the standard of living of workers.

In the last three years we have had constant statements by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) that it is essential to reduce real wages. This claim was echoed by representatives of big business in whose interests this Government continues to act. A paper by Greg Turnidge and Ainsley Jolley published last October by the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures they claimed:
. . . real wage reductions are an essential ingredient of the total economic policy package necessary to return the Australian economy to a completely healthy state.

Attacks of this kind on living standards of workers are the real reason behind this Government's legislation on secret ballots. It believes it can achieve a reduction in the number of strikes and other actions taken by workers in support of their claims through this legislation. Of course, this is based on a myth. The myth that underlines that claim is that workers somehow love to go on strike and that union leaders love to call out their members at the drop of a hat.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the second one tonight.

—That kind of remark just goes to show the honourable member's intelligence. This proposition ignores the fact that workers who strike also suffer. They lose wages. The decision to go on strike is a serious matter which is not taken lightly. It is taken out of a sense of desperation that unless workers act to protect their livelihoods they will be victims of the same greedy impulses which reduced workers to absolute poverty in the last century. We still see those greedy impulses alive and kicking in Australia at present. From 1975 to early 1980 record levels of profit were achieved by many large, often foreign-owned, corporations. Yet during this period real wages relative to inflation fell and so did the standards of living of workers. It is only in the last year because of determined actions by key unions and negotiations over increased productivity awards-because productivity increased dramatically-that some increase in real wages was possible.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) pointed out, it is only this fact-the actions of the unions-which has allowed for growth in consumer spending in the last few months and growth in the economy as a whole. Thus we have the extraordinary situation where the Treasurer is claiming credit for achieving increased economic growth whereas in fact it is only the actions and the achievements of the union movement in the last year in increasing wages which have been the main catalyst of that growth. Is this Government and its Minister grateful for that assistance, for that achievement? Not on your life. They cannot stand the fact that workers have achieved some distribution of the wealth which is generated from workers' labour. This is the crux of the matter with regard to the conservative attitude to workers and unions. The Government is congenitally incapable of understanding a fundamental fact of economics-that it is human labour, the mental and physical work of ordinary Australians, which creates wealth and which recreates the world and everything in it. The god of profit which they worship would be non-existent without the contribution of this human labour.

The union movement which is concerned to ensure that labour is adequately rewarded and exploitation is minimised is the movement which the Government seeks to attack. The legislation seeks to destroy the solidarity and unity of purpose of the workers and to prevent the achievement of those goals which I have just mentioned. It seeks to place special powers in the hands of that tiny minority of unionists who, because they have been indoctrinated by the media and others, seek to disrupt the process of negotiation and action to achieve justice. Significantly, none of these individuals ever, by the way, rejects a wage increase resulting from the action and strike activity of their fellows. These attempts further to control the trade union movement will fail not only for the specific reasons given by the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) but also because of the overriding fact that no legislation, court action or penal provisions or arbitrary use of government powers will prevent the majority of workers from uniting to protect and improve their standards of living and the rewards of labour. It is about time the Liberal Party and other conservative parties recognised that fundamental fact. They cannot continue to attack the living standards of people and expect them to sit down and accept this. If the Government wants workers to behave in accordance with laws then the laws need to be reasonable. The Government does not have reasonable laws in industrial relations at present. This is another stinking law which is going to make industrial relations worse. The sooner the Government comes to accept this fundamental fact the quicker harmonious industrial relations will be created in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) in his second reading speech referred to promises of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and in particular to the Prime Minister's policy speech of September 1980 when he made three policy promises on industrial relations. I think those three promises are worth recording. The Prime Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: For the future, the Government proposes to:
Extend the secret ballot provisions to enable individual employees to apply for a secret ballot to express their views on strike action.
Legislate to facilitate the amalgamation of unions where there is a 'unity of interests'.
In consultation with industry initiate a major campaign of advice and assistance to all levels of management on the conduct and practice of industrial relations.
the Government remains firmly committed to the principle of conciliation and arbitration.

We know what happened to the legislation promised to facilitate the amalgamation of unions. In fact, it was drafted, printed and shelved. So much for the promises. Of course this Government and this Prime Minister have quite a record on promises. In fact the Prime Minister has a unique record of promises made but never kept. His promises are now so infamous that they have even been set to music. The Prime Minister said in the 1977 campaign speech:
We have ended the big tax ripoff.
The statement continues:
Interest rates have begun to fall and they will keep falling.
In a statement to Parliament on 22 February 1979 the same Prime Minister said:
The Government's success in winding back inflation has been a precondition for the substantial progress in reducing interest rates.

We have heard promise after promise broken and have not seen them come to fruition. No one can believe any more the promises of this Government. It is important that we reflect on these promises because the Government has reneged on its promise on the amalgamation of unions. It is all the more sickening when one realises that the legislation has been drafted, printed and, in fact, sighted by members of the Opposition. But the Government has not brought it in for its own reasons. So one cannot help being cynical about the legislation that the Government is trying to put through now.

No matter how this pathetic Minister for Industrial Relations may try to put a veneer of respectability on this legislation further to facilitate secret ballots in respect of industrial action, it can and will be seen for what it really is. It is a vehicle for pimps, scabs, malcontents and dobbers. It is perhaps typical that this Minister should bring it in. These scabs and pimps that the Government would know much of are there to cause disruption within the democratic trade union organisation. If anyone has doubts about this then he will have to look at the razor gang report and see just how many departments were slashed and note that the IRB, the Industrial Relations Bureau-or the industrial police force as it is is known in the trade union movement-this industrial gestapo, has been retained. It is rather ironic that in the report referring to the cutbacks there was a line to say that this Bureau would not be cut back.

I think it is worth while to reflect on the history of industrial relations in this country in particular. Let us deal with one aspect that is constantly raised by the Government. It was raised by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) who piously said that everyone believes in the right to strike. How often do we hear this kind of thing? I want to come back to that aspect. We have heard constant attacks by the Government on the trade unions and on how irresponsible they are. We have heard a number of quotations from this side of the House from practitioners in industrial relations. I wish to quote from a speech by Dr Ian Sharp contained in the Practising Manager Vol. 1 (1) October 1980.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he a socialist?

—Some clown here says that he is a socialist. For the honourable member's information I advise that Dr Ian Sharp was a Deputy President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission until 1978. So much for the ignorance that Government members are prepared to show! When dealing with disputes Dr Sharp stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In general, I do not think the Australian system can claim much success in preventing industrial disputes. I doubt, however, whether any system would have done much better or that we would have been willing to pay the price of total dispute prevention. This is, largely a matter of the make-up of the social community, of its attitudes and collective personality. Australia has a record of having more industrial stoppages than most other countries. However, despite this record it is not one of the top countries in terms of man days lost. The latest figures available for top international comparison of eighteen countries take us up to the end of 1978. They show that over the previous ten years, which include some pretty torrid years for Australia, the United States, Canada, Italy and India have almost consistently lost more working days per 1,000 employees than Australia.

I think that is sufficient to put the lie to the constant attacks on the trade union movement from the Government members. Of course, their own Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) put the lie to them when he was in Japan and when he thought he was out of earshot.

TALK.START.PARA: —To defend us.
—He certainly did not defend the Government when he exposed the lies that the Government members have been spreading.

—Order! The honourable member for Hindmarsh will resume his seat for a minute. My understanding of the Bill is that it is about the introduction of secret ballots. The honourable member has barely touched on that in his first seven minutes. I just thought that I ought to give notice that he ought to return to the Bill before his time has expired.

—At the outset-I think you were not in the chair at the time, Mr Deputy Speaker-I made specific mention of the second reading speech of the Minister and the promises of the Prime Minister that were referred to. That is what I have gone on from. I come to the present Conciliation and Arbitration Act and the provisions for secret ballots that have been in it for some number of years. Of course, we have heard from the Opposition side an explanation of just how often those provisions have been used and the results that have come from their use. We have heard from the Government side talk of the right to strike.

SPEECH.PARA: I will finish on this aspect because it is perfectly relevant. This Bill is further legislation to hamper and interfere with the democratic set-up of the trade union movement. Everyone believes in the right to strike.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't.

—There is always an exception in every community. The editorial of the capitalist newspaper in Adelaide on 9 November 1974, in fact, was on the very question of the right to strike. Those who do not agree can certainly hold there own opinions. The editorial concerned the perfect strike. Public opinion unquestionably concedes the right of every free man and woman in a free society to withdraw his or her labour. It just draws the line at strikes. Perhaps we should try to design the perfect strike. The first essential is to get the profit motivation out of strikes. There is evidence that the public finds striking for higher pay, shorter hours and better conditions to be a distasteful display of materialism. A strike must not cause any loss of production or affect the country's supply of goods and services. Strikes should be arranged in the workers' own time rather than in the employer's. The strike must not cause any loss or inconvenience to customers. The timing of the perfect strike is very important. It would be disloyal to strike when the country is facing economic competition from overseas or at a time when a rise in wages would tend to increase prices. The strike should not be held under a Liberal-Country Party Government. This would be seen as political mischief-making. The strike should not be held under a Labor Government since it could be said to be stabbing one's own side in the back. It should not be an unofficial strike. The public frowns on unofficial strikes. It should not be an official strike because the public thinks that union officials should not encourage strikes. Therefore, taking all these points into consideration, the nearest we might get to the perfect strike would go something like this: A small, polite, well-behaved strike of company directors during one lunch hour in favour of lower wages for trade union officials. It should take place under an Australian Democrat Government just as soon as America, the European Economic Community, Japan and our other principal economic competitors happen to sink into the sea.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that just about typifies the attitude of the Government. It says it believes in the right to strike. It knows that there is already in existence legislation providing for secret ballots. It must also know that a number of unions have written into their rules a requirement to have a secret ballot before they have a strike. More importantly Government members are not practitioners. They do not know what happens. In the real life situation the workers themselves at a factory gate meeting, usually at lunch time, determine whether they will take strike action. Often they will determine whether they will have a secret ballot. They do not have to be coerced. They do not have to have further legislation.
