They certainly do not have to have vehicles that provide for pimps, dobbers and troublemakers within the trade union movement who try to disrupt a democratic organisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard from my colleague the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) about what is the perfect strike. I draw honourable member's attention to the fact that this is the seventy-first amendment-if I was counting rightly-to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, and the fifteenth since 1975. It is obvious that this Government, whenever in trouble, resorts to union bashing to divert the people's attention from its inability to manage the country's economy. My colleagues who preceded me have already mentioned, and it is worth repeating, that this proposal was put forward as an election gimmick before the 1980 elections. The Fraser Government was threatened with defeat and it was desperately looking for something to cover up its mismanagement of the economy. Of course, I did not envy its task as previous conservative governments used just about every trick under the sun to hoodwink the Australian people. The red arrows and yellow arrows of the Menzies era could not be resurrected.

SPEECH.PARA: The crying of wolf so ably used by the late Sir Robert does not suit the arrogance of our present Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). He resorted to sabre rattling instead, but the discovery of his wool earmarked for export to Russia reduced his credibility to nil. So the market researchers of the Liberal Party were called in to try to find some electoral diversion. They found that the monopoly-owned media has created an impression that many people in the community accepted the view that trade unions are irresponsible organisations. They advised the Liberal Party that strikes are unpopular so if the Government promised to reduce the frequency of direct industrial action it may have a chance to restore its popularity. Hence the pre-election promise of the Prime Minister that is being followed now with the Bill which is before the House. By the way, this is probably the only promise-a part promise-that is being kept. It was a desperate attempt to pull the wool over the eyes of the Australian voter. It was conceived by desperate men who managed to hang on to power only by the skin of their teeth. It is no wonder that we now have a piece of legislation before us that is not based on the reality of an industrial situation but is calculated to divide or, to say the least, is based on a misconception.

Of couse, we are not surprised by the divisive nature of this Bill as it has come from a government led by the most divisive Prime Minister since Federation. The secret ballot provision contained in the Bill is calculated to set one Australian worker against the other. It invites and encourages scabbing at the work places. In fact, it will have the effect of exacerbating industrial disputes instead of solving them. Members opposite are espousing the idea of reducing government involvement in every area where the Government should protect individuals and the community as a whole. The razor gang's proposals will reduce or abolish Federal Government responsibility for health, hospitals, migrant services, housing and so on. Yet the same Government vigorously insists that it should intervene in industrial disputes between workers and bosses. The only areas in which this Government is interested to intervene are those where by its intervention it can enlarge the high profits of corporations and at the same time reduce the ability of the workers to ensure for themselves a fair share of the cake. However, in this instance the Government's intervention is so inept that it is not welcomed even by the employers, whose interests it claims to represent. The employers know well that strike ballots will not reduce industrial disputation but will have a contrary effect.

The Government is an uninvited and unwelcome guest in this area. The workers, the bosses or the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission-those who are directly involved in industrial relations in Australia-have not suggested that amendments along the lines proposed by the Government are necessary or even desirable. There is absolutely no need for this legislation, as the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) pointed out when he spoke to the Bill. The Arbitration Commission, as well as the Government, has enough power to deal with any industrial disputation. The Act that we now seek to amend has been amended about 70 times already, as I stated at the outset. I wish to quote from the speech made on this Bill by the former Minister for Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock). Page 2827 of Hansard states:

The Conciliation and Arbitration Act has been amended over 70 times since its enactment in 1904-14 times under the present Government. I have to say that this represents lack of direction and lack of consensus over many years on direction over time and the fallibility of legislation. This Act has surely reached saturation point. The cumulative effect of legislation on industrial relations is largely a matter of conjecture and often ill-informed assumption. There is a need for the Act to be simplified into a useful tool for the practitioner in industrial relations-not complicated by further legislation.

This Government has yet to learn that industrial action cannot be managed by the bludgeon of legislation but has to be approached with common sense and conciliation. As far as the trade union movement is concerned, it is not opposed to secret ballots. They are used in union elections. The trade union leadership is elected in secret ballots. However, it would be silly to suggest that each decision made by that democratically elected leadership should be submitted to secret ballot. Let us look at who is proposing this. Our Prime Minister would not be keen to put his razor gang proposals to the secret vote of the people. On the contrary, last October he was hiding his intentions from the people. Whilst trade union leaders have a mandate from their members to fight for better wages and working conditions, the Prime Minister had no mandate from the people of Australia to abandon universal health insurance or the Government's responsibilities in areas of hospital financing and health care. He had no mandate to sell out publicly owned companies and land. The man who was sneaking in through a back door at Yarralumla is trying to teach workers democracy. What a hypocrite!

The right to strike is an important human right achieved by the workers in countries such as ours. If that right is taken away or limited by government interference we might as well pack our cases and join President Marcos or some other little dictator friend of honourable members opposite. It will be a sorry day for Australia when the Australian worker is not allowed, freely and without fear, to negotiate and, if necessary, to fight for better wages and working conditions. The Government is trying to tell us that strike ballots will reduce industrial disputation, that unions are not democratic and that their leadership does not consult with membership before and during industrial action. There is nothing further from the truth. Decisions to use the worker's ultimate weapon are not lightly made. The amendment to the Act represents a further intrusion by government into internal affairs of unions which will be strongly resisted by the Australian workers who will not tolerate provocative invitations to scabbing in the work place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I could not sit down any longer and allow some of the remarks that have been made by the Opposition to go without somebody saying this: I do not think the Government went far enough with the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill. The honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke), who is seated at the table, made an accusation. I will use the word 'accusation'. Not so long ago he made a point that legislation to facilitate the amalgamation of unions was held up because of the conservative elements in this Government; it was held up by people who realised that the amalgamation of two of the strongest unions in Australia would put the people of Australia at risk. I use the example of the amalgamation of the Transport Workers Union of Australia with the Federated Storemen and Packers Union of Australia. We have had enough trouble with the transport workers in Tasmania as it is. The two unions coming together would stop the life of Tasmania. They have practically ruined Tasmania's economy. They have ruined the social fabric of that State. They have ruined most of the small businesses. Hotels are closing down there at the moment. You have the sheer hypocrisy to talk about the workers and the words 'conciliation and arbitration'.
—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the Chair.
—Yes, I will come back to that. You have allowed--

—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The honourable member may not say 'you are guilty of hypocrisy' because he is in fact addressing the Chair. If he addresses his remarks through the Chair he will not attract so much opposition.

—I am very sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. We have heard the word 'hypocrisy' mentioned. We have heard that we must look after the workers. We have heard that we must protect them. What about the poor people of Australia who are full up to the back teeth of the word 'conciliation'? I think the word 'conciliation' should be taken out of the dictionary. The trade union movement knows nothing of conciliation. When it wants something it uses the word 'power'. It will do everything within its reach and power to get what it wants. It does not matter one bit about the rest of Australia; the people can suffer as a result of it.

SPEECH.PARA: The secret ballot provision contained in the legislation does not go far enough. We did not have the fortitude to go in a little harder because we were afraid to tamper with the great trade union movement. The people in the open arena are suffering as a result. When I go back to Tasmania, the ordinary worker who once supported the Labor Party says: 'Look, what about the trade union movement? What is it trying to do to us?' There is a famous industrial relations Minister in Tasmania. His mentality is such that in one of the newspapers over the weekend he is reported as saying that the Federal Government is to blame for the maritime strike, and that the maritime unions cannot conciliate with the Australian National Line because of the 35-hour week. He is beginning to use the lever of the 35-hour week. Once again Tasmania is being held to ransom by the powerful unions because they now want the 35-hour week. That is why the Government is legislating for secret ballots.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order!
—That is the reason why we want to do far more to offset what the Labor Party is trying to do to Australia.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. It is my understanding that this debate is not about the 35-hour week.
—You allowed a lot of latitude to some of the honourable members opposite.
—I gave them fair latitude, but they were not talking about the 35-hour week.

—With great respect, I have said about all I want to say. The honourable member for Wills can smile, but if he came to Tasmania and debated the issue, as I suggested the other day that he should, he would be thrown out on his neck.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Motion (by Mr Wilson)-proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke Mr R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the exigencies of time, we are not able to consider this matter in Committee. However, I want to make a couple of comments at this third reading stage of the Bill which seem to be necessary if there is to be a proper understanding of the inadequacies of the legislation this House has been asked to pass. I draw the attention of the House to a quite basic inadequacy in clause 6, where the fundamental requirement is that the members of an organisation should have been directed or requested to take part in industrial action. One would expect that in this fundamental requirement to trigger the whole mechanism of the Bill, that is, that the members should have been directed or requested to engage in industrial action, there would have been some definition of what a direction or request is. That is something in respect of which the legislation is entirely silent. Much more disturbing is the provision in clause 6, proposed new sub-section (3D), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to this section, the Commission shall, upon an application made to it under sub-section (3A), order that a vote of the members to whom the application relates . . .

So the sub-section goes on. We have a situation where, in respect of the wording as it stands now, a group of members in one place of employment could make an application. It could be that that application would, in fact, relate to other members of the union in other places of employment. Of course, that is a quite ridiculous situation. Yet to clarify that appropriate regulations will have to be brought into being. As one of my fellow members on this side of the House has pointed out, that will be something that the Government cannot look forward to with any confidence in the future.

Perhaps more than anything else the things that indicate the totally one-sided nature of the Government's approach in this matter are the proposed changes to section 45C of the Act. Without going into the exact language of those changes, the substance of what is suggested is that if a ballot is, in fact, undertaken and the majority of those people taking part in the ballot are not in favour of participating in industrial action then, of course, they are not required to do so and the will of the majority in that respect is taken into account. They cannot in any way be forced to take action, and action cannot be taken against them. In other words, the Government presumably is indicating that, in that sense, the will of the majority as ascertained in a ballot should prevail. One would have thought in these circumstances-if one were in fact concerned with the principle of allowing the will of the majority to prevail-there would have been a provision to cover the obverse situation. If, in fact, the ballot were taken and the majority voted in favour of industrial action then there would be a requirement in those circumstances for the will of the majority to prevail. Those who were in the minority would be bound by the will of the majority as expressed in the ballot. Of course, it is indicative of the one-sided approach of this Government that the legislation does not so provide.

Because of the undertaking which my colleagues on this side of the House have arrived at with leaders on the other side of the House and because it is time to come to the end of this debate, it is impossible, therefore, to allude to all the detailed inadequacies of the Bill. As far as I am concerned, as that agreement is like an industrial agreement and is one which will be kept, at this stage I conclude by expressing my regret that the Government has inflicted upon the community a piece of legislation which is not only unnecessary but also will in the future provoke industrial conflict which would not otherwise have arisen.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr MacKellar, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill is an omnibus Bill by which the Government seeks to make wide-ranging changes to four health Acts. These will give effect to the Government's philosphy and goals outlined in my recent statement to the House on health care services. As honourable members will be aware, the Government's overriding goal in the health area is that all Australians should have access to the high quality health care services we now enjoy in this country. But the achievement of this aim must be at a cost the individual and the community can afford. The Government believes that the most equitable and responsible means of achieving these goals is by means of a health policy that:
(i) requires the State and Northern Territory governments to take up their full constitutional responsibilities for the provision of health services;
(ii) ensures that those in genuine need receive special assistance to cover their hospital and medical bills;
(iii) results in other people contributing towards the cost of the health services they receive-either totally out of their own pockets or through health insurance;
(iv) ensures that health insurance is available to all people at a reasonable cost and directs the relevant government subsidies towards those who are willing to help themselves;
(v) recognises the importance of the community rating principle for a viable health insurance industry;
(vi) fully acknowledges the important role of the private sector of the health care delivery system, particularly private hospitals; and
(vii) seeks to ensure that users and providers of health care services become more aware of the costs they generate.
The Bill now before the House will also:

(i) ensure immediate eligibility to receive basic insurance benefits for people taking out such cover with a registered health fund between 1 September and 31 October 1981 irrespective of any pre-existing illness conditions;

(ii) ensure that those people who lose their entitlement to a pensioner health benefit or health care card and then choose to insure with a registered health fund can immediately become eligible for benefits at the basic coverage level;
(iii) provide for the Commonwealth to pay all nursing home benefits and, so, take over responsibility for those nursing home benefits currently paid by health funds for insured persons;

(iv) provide further protection to people in a nursing home against being unnecessarily charged for extras that would normally be regarded as part of nursing home care and, therefore, included in the approved fee;
(v) expand the operation of the isolated patients' travel and accommodation assistance scheme;
(vi) give effect to certain recommendations made by the pathology services working party which have been accepted by the Government;
(vii) overcome a problem in the existing legislation which relates to the bulk billing of certain pathology services; and
(viii) extend the Commonwealth's supervision of the production and supply of certain therapeutic goods.

The House will recall that in my statement of 29 April on the Goovernment's new health policy I outlined new funding arrangements it is proposed to introduce for State health services. They are designed to ensure that the waste, inefficiencies and unnecessary duplication of costly equipment in State public hospital systems highlighted by the Commission of Inquiry into the Efficiency and Administration of Hospitals are overcome. Such waste and inefficiency cannot be allowed to continue. It results in a needless burden on all taxpayers and the Government would be neglecting its duties if it failed to take appropriate action. The Jamison inquiry found that a major reason for such waste and inefficiency was the problem of divided responsibility between the Commonwealth and State governments. The inquiry recommended that this should be corrected by requiring the States to take up their full constitutional responsibilities for the provision of health services.

The Government's new health care funding arrangements will give the States greater freedom in the spending of Commonwealth funds previously provided for specific health purposes. The States will now be totally responsible for determining their own priorities in this area and appropriately allocating resources. The new health funding arrangements will do this. The relevant enabling legislation-the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill-was introduced by my colleague, the Treasurer (Mr Howard), on 28 May. However, an appropriate amendment to the Health Insurance Act is necessary because South Australia and Tasmania have agreements with the Commonwealth that operate until 30 June 1985 under which the Commonwealth cost-shares the agreed net operating expenses of their public hospitals. This is achieved by clause 18.

The Government recognises that some States may seek to undermine the new health service funding arrangements by transferring traditional State functions in the nursing home area to the Commonwealth. It is recognised, for example, that some States could seek to reclassify public hospitals as State Government nursing homes. This would result in the Commonwealth paying nursing home benefits for such people. To protect the Commonwealth against such action clause 45 will ensure that State Government nursing homes are not to be approved in future for the purpose of paying nursing home benefits without consideration of the need for such homes in the same way that other nursing home proposals are considered. Similarly, States could seek to classify institutions now receiving their financial support as Commonwealth deficit-financed nursing homes. Such action would, again, be unacceptable to the Commonwealth. Clause 67 prevents such an action. However, a ministerial discretion is provided in appropriate circumstances where the Minister considers a transfer of a State financial responsibility is not involved.

A basic element of the Government's health policy is that the Commonwealth should provide special assistance to cover the hospital and medical bills of those in genuine need, namely: persons holding pensioner health benefit cards; migrants and refugees during their first six months in Australia; people in receipt of unemployment and special benefits with private incomes below the pensioner health benefit limits; and people whose incomes fall below certain specified limits plus their dependants. The Commonwealth will ensure that these people will continue to have free access to public hospitals by placing an appropriate condition on the States and Northern Territory. For States other than South Australia and Tasmania this is by a condition in clause 20 of the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Bill 1981 introduced to the Parliament by the Treasurer last week. For South Australia and Tasmania the agreed arrangements will provide for such a condition to apply.

In the face of recent media speculation as to the position of pensioners under the Government's new health policy, I would like again to reassure all those people who hold pensioner health benefit cards and their dependants that there will be no change in their position after 1 September next. The Bill now before the House therefore retains the existing arrangements for eligible pensioners and their dependants. These people will continue to be entitled to free private medical services where their doctor bulk bills them and, as at present, where such a person's doctor chooses not to bulk bill, they will be entitled to a Commonwealth medical benefit of 85 per cent of the schedule fee, with a maximum payment-known as the 'gap payment'-of $5 per service where the doctor charges the schedule fee or less.

The Bill will introduce similar arrangements for those other groups outlined above who are considered to be in special need. They will be eligible for free public hospital accommodation and treatment and free bulk billed medical services. They, in the majority of cases, will receive a health care card before such treatment becomes necessary. A Commonwealth medical benefit of 85 per cent will apply to bulk billed private medical services they receive. This compares with the present level of 75 per cent for those persons classified by their doctors as disadvantaged. It is expected that the majority of people covered will be bulk billed and, therefore, will not have to meet any gap payment. Doctors are, of course, free to choose not to bulk bill. Provision is therefore made in clause 8 for holders of a health care card to be paid a Commonwealth medical benefit of 85 per cent through registered health insurance organisations in such circumstances-in the same way eligible pensioners are-with a maximum gap payment of $5 for each service, so long as the doctor charges no more than the scheduled fee.

Honourable members will be aware that under the Government's new health policy, those people considered to be in a special need are being clearly defined for the first time. The Government has decided to take this action-and no longer leave this in the hands of individual doctors-because of a dual concern, namely: Bulk billed medical services provided under the existing disadvantaged arrangements are growing at a rate which would indicate that those services have been made available to persons who could not normally be regarded as disadvantaged and people in genuine need are not always able to gain the protection of those arrangements. The Bill enables a person to apply for a health care card on the grounds that he or she fell within the low income category at the time a medical or hospital service was provided. The application may be lodged up to 13 weeks after the service was provided. In special circumstances a longer period will be acceptable. This means that it is not essential that people in special need have a health care card before they receive a service. Of course these new arrangements for those in special need will not apply prior to 1 September 1981.

The Government estimates that nearly two million eligible pensioners and their dependants will be protected in this way and that up to one million people will be eligible for special assistance under the new health care card arrangements. I would point out to the House that it will not be necessary for these people to take out medical or hospital insurance. However, if they want doctor of choice in a public hospital or wish to use a private hospital, they would, as is now the case, need to take out hospital insurance. I would also point out that the Government recognises that should any person lose his or her entitlement to a pensioner health benefit or health care card, he or she can obtain immediate cover by basic insurance with a registered health fund. Clause 64 of the Bill will achieve this by requiring funds to waive the two months waiting period before people taking out insurance are entitled to receive both hospital and medical benefits at the basic level in such cases.

Under the Government's new health policy those persons, and their dependants, not protected by the special assistance arrangements outlined above will be required to meet their hospital and medical bills. They may choose to do so by personal payment or through insurance. There are, therefore, considerable advantages in taking out insurance, or maintaining one's cover, after 1 September. Additional advantages will be as follows: Commonwealth medical benefits will be available only to those with at least basic medical cover with a registered health fund; secondly, the Commonwealth Medical Benefit payable will be at a flat rate of 30 per cent and will apply to all items included in the medical benefits schedule; additionally, the total benefit payable to a person with basic medical insurance will be equal to 85 per cent of the schedule fee with a maximum gap payment of $10 where the doctor charges the schedule fee or less-this compares with the present level of 75 per cent and a maximum gap of $10; and, fourthly, a tax rebate of 32c in the dollar will apply for the cost of basic medical and/or hospital insurance with a registered health fund.

These results will be achieved, except in relation to the tax rebate, by clauses 8 and 39 and will apply from 1 September 1981. The relevant legislation to give effect to the tax rebate decision was introduced by my colleague, the Treasurer, on 27 May 1981. As the Treasurer stated in his second reading speech when introducing the Income Tax (Assessment and Rates) Amendment Bill 1981, this rebate will be at a rate of 32c in the dollar and will apply to amounts paid on or after 1 July 1981 for basic hospital and/or medical insurance cover from that date with a registered health fund.

As honourable members will be aware, persons taking out health insurance are normally required to wait two months before they are entitled to receive benefits at the basic level. The Government has decided that this waiting period should be waived between 1 September and 31 October next. The Government has also decided to put beyond any doubt that a fund should not apply a pre-existing ailment exclusion provision to people taking out insurance at the basic level during this period. This will be achieved by clause 65. As a result, no fund can refuse to accept any persons applying for insurance cover at the basic level, no matter how seriously ill they might be when they apply and no matter how long they may have suffered from the illness. This anti-discriminatory measure also applies, of course, to women who are pregnant.

I would stress that the introduction of these legislative provisions should not be seen as a criticism of registered health funds as a whole. The Government believes that, generally speaking, the funds act to ensure that their members receive proper protection against the high cost of health care. However it must be recognised that some funds-very few in number-may not always act in this way and so the Commonwealth must have the means of ensuring that no insured persons are adversely affected by actions of a fund that are contrary to Government policy.

In order to further its aim of ensuring that insurance is available at a reasonable cost-and, at the same time, to provide greater protection for the aged and the chronically ill in relation to the cost of nursing home care-the Government has decided to take over full responsibility for the payment of nursing home benefits. The amendments to the National Health Act provided for in Part III of the Bill, together with complementary amendments to the Nursing Homes Assistance Act, will give effect to this decision. They will operate from 1 September 1981.

Since 1 October 1977 registered hospital benefits organisations have been required to pay, as part of basic hospital insurance, all nursing home benefits for their members. These benefits payable by the funds are equivalent in level to the benefits the Commonwealth pays for all patients in nursing homes who are not insured. The Government has decided that this arrangement is unsatisfactory for two principal reasons, namely: Nursing home patients are, in the strict sense, uninsurable through voluntary insurance in which guaranteed benefits without discrimination or exclusions are made mandatory; and the arrangement represents an inequitable liability for the bulk of people with hospital insurance. The Government believes that this decision will ensure a more equitable distribution of the cost of Commonwealth assistance to those in need of nursing home care. The Government also believes that this measure will further assist in containing the cost of health insurance.

The Government will also be providing additional protection for people receiving nursing home care by new provisions more clearly to prevent nursing homes from imposing a levy or compulsory additional charge on patients. Regrettably some nursing homes attempt to circumvent the present fee control arrangements by such measures. This practice will be prevented by clause 45. I would add that the great bulk of nursing homes do not attempt to pursue such practices, and these new provisions should in no way be taken as a reflection on the industry as a whole.

The Bill now before the House-by virtue of clause 59-also gives effect to the Government's decision to prohibit registered health benefit funds from operating optional benefit tables. These tables undermine the community rating principle under which the cost of health insurance is borne equally by contributors with such cover. The effect of this principle is to reduce the cost of health insurance to the more needy sections of the community-such as the aged, the chronically ill and families with children. The operation of clause 59 will therefore strengthen the community rating principle. It will also simplify the present health insurance arrangements.

The Commonwealth fully acknowledges the important role of the private sector of the health care delivery system. The Government has received a number of submissions expressing concern at the financial problems facing private hospitals. It recognises that in the medium to longer term its overall health policy will assist in correcting this situation. However, immediate action is necessary to assist private hospitals in meeting the increased cost of servicing surgical beds. Surgical facilities in private hospitals should continue to be available to the community.

To achieve this goal a higher rate of subsidy-of $28 per day-is to be introduced for private hospital patients whose admission to hospital or subsequent treatment is primarily related to a surgical procedure. This is achieved by clause 20. The new subsidy will operate from the date the Bill receives royal assent. The existing bed day subsidy of $16 per day will be retained for non-surgical patients in private hospitals. It is proposed that the medical services in private hospitals that will attract the higher subsidy will be prescribed in regulations. The Bill also provides that the Minister for Health will have a discretionary power to review individual cases, and by regulation, to admit additional schedule items to the approved list.

The Bill now before the House contains a number of provisions related to the Isolated Patients' Travel and Accommodation Scheme, the Therapeutic Goods Act and several machinery matters. By virtue of clauses 41 to 44 inclusive, the IPTAAS Scheme is to be expanded in line with the Government's decision last year to include cleft lip and cleft palate patients under 22 years of age requiring orthodontic and associated treatment and other patients requiring specialist oral surgery. The extension of the scheme is to apply retrospectively from 1 January 1981 to coincide with the date of the inclusion of orthodontic treatment for cleft lip patients in the medical benefits schedule.

Part V of the Bill now before the House would amend the Therapeutic Goods Act. The amendments seek to keep Australia abreast with other developed countries and further exemplifies the Government's belief that it should have the capability of ensuring that the therapeutic goods available in Australia are safe, pure, potent and of good quality. Clause 72 of the Bill would amend the definition of therapeutic use to ensure that health care products and medical devices including contraceptive devices, pacemakers and artificial heart valves clearly come within the scope of the Act.

The Bill would also update the references to British publications which are the source of standards for goods for therapeutic use. Unless this is done, the standards upon which Australia has relied for so long would no longer have effect. The Bill would authorise the Minister for Health to set standards by references to other published sources. Under the present legislation the means for obtaining essential information about the way biological products are made is not available. The Bill would provide a mechanism to allow the Commonwealth, when necessary, to seek information about the manufacture and testing of biological products. It will also provide a mechanism to regulate their release on to the market. As the need for a complete list of the medicines used in Australia has long been felt, the Bill would establish the national register of therapeutic goods and provide the power to acquire information regarding the composition of goods included in the register.

To safeguard the rights of manufacturers, the Bill will include appeal machinery. I draw the attention of honourable members to clause 85 which will provide for appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against decisions of the Director-General that affect the commercial operations of a manufacturer. In addition, before the Director-General can seek information about medicinal preparations from a manufacturer for inclusion in the proposed register, those preparations must be declared by the regulations to be goods to which the register applies. The type of information must also be prescribed by the regulations. In this way the Parliament will have the opportunity to oversight the information which is being recorded. Similar arrangements will apply in relation to the expansion of the scope of the Therapeutic Goods Act. Before new health care products can be brought within its scope they must be prescribed.

The Bill also contains a number of clauses related to the rendering of pathology services. Clause 12 would correct an anomaly in relation to the assignment of benefits for pathology services. The Health Insurance Act now stipulates that in cases of bulk billing, a patient must assign his benefit at the time or after the service is provided. However, in the case of the majority of pathology services, the service is carried out sometime after a specimen is collected from the patient and the pathologist has no face-to-face contact with the patient. The amendment will enable benefits to be assigned in advance of the actual rendering of the pathology service.

Clauses 9, 10, 28 and 34 to 37 inclusive of the Bill include a number of changes to the approved pathology practitioner provisions that were recommended by the pathology services working party. This working part was established by the Government in 1976 principally to review pathology arrangements and schedule fees and benefits for pathology services. Its members included representatives from the Australian Medical Association, the Royal College of Pathologists of Australia, the Society of Pathologists in Private Practice, the Health Commission of New South Wales and Commonwealth departments.

Under the present arrangements medical practitioners requiring pathology tests to be per- formed must make their request in writing. The amendment in clause 9 will enable the Minister to approve requests in other forms so as to allow modern methods of data transmission to be used. In addition, the amendment would enable the Minister also to approve the use of alternative methods of modern storage media such as on microfilm and microfiche.

The effect of clause 10 is to require the Minister for Health to keep the Australian Medical Association informed in writing of any changes referred to the medical benefits advisory committee which involved variations to undertakings entered into by pathologists and for the Minister to be aware of the AMA comments before making such changes. The clause also provides for the AMA to be consulted ahead of the implementation of any recommendations by the medical benefits advisory committee which could lead to variations to undertakings.

Clause 28 sets out those practices which were regarded by the pathology services working party as being inconsistent with the generally accepted standards of professional conduct. The effect of this will be to reduce the incidence of the provision of unnecessary practices. In order to clarify for approved pathology practitioners those practices prohibited by clause 28 it will be necessary for them to enter into new undertakings with the Minister for Health. Clauses 34 to 37 provide for the transition from the present undertaking to the new undertaking to be carried out in an orderly fashion.

Other machinery or clarifying amendments that will be of interest to honourable members are as follows: Clause 60 would extend the provisions in the National Health Act which presently permit the Minister to exempt an organisation from paying medical benefits for certain services also to cover benefits for hospitalisation in respect of these same services. The provision clearly defines the limits or exemptions and protects the rights of contributors who seek to transfer to another organisation because of the exemption. Clause 47 will put beyond doubt that under section 43A of the National Health Act the Director-General may request the balance sheets and related statements of nursing homes, as well as other relevant accounts such as profit and loss statements.
Conclusion

The Bill now before the House will give effect to the health policy changes I announced on 29 April 1981. The overriding aim of the Government's new health policy is to ensure that all Australians have access to high quality health care at a cost the individual and the community can afford. The Government believes that the most equitable and responsible means of achieving that goal is through a combination of special assistance schemes for those in genuine need and the fostering of private health insurance for other people.

Honourable members should not lose sight of the fact that major Government subsidies, financed through the general taxation system, are provided to ensure that health insurance is available to the average family man at a reasonable cost. However, the Government rejects the concept of a tax financed universal health insurance scheme. The Government believes that such an approach to health financing does not contain sufficient inbuilt checks and balances designed to prevent overuse and abuses of the health care delivery system and, therefore, that such a system would inevitably lead to an increase in the overall cost of providing health services to the detriment of all taxpayers. Proper health care is vital to all Australians. But the Government's health policy must be both equitable and responsible. The Bill now before the House will achieve these dual goals. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Blewett) adjourned.

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I want to protest and place on record my opposition to the Government's attitude in regard to the agreement under which the Commonwealth will make money available to the States over the next five years for housing purposes. This Government is not even prepared to debate this matter when an allocation is made each year. The Government Whip, on behalf of the Government, told us that one hour will be allocated to debate on this legislation. This state of affairs shows the complete incompetence of the Government. The Parliament has been sitting for months. Opposition members have been waiting to debate issues. We on this side of the House want to debate legislation. Now an enormous amount of legislation is being introduced. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
this House is of the opinion that-

(1) the Bill should be withdrawn and redrafted because it fails to provide sufficient funds to meet the neglected housing needs of the Australian people and signals a further withdrawal by the Federal Government from its-
(a) responsibility to ensure, in co-operation with the States, Territories and local government, security of housing for all Australians, and
(b) direct responsibility for the housing of Aboriginal people;
(2) the Bill should provide-
(a) sufficient funds to housing authorities to ensure a significant reduction of the backlog on their waiting lists;
(b) sufficient funds to ensure a permanent reduction in the number of persons who are homeless or living in sub-standard accommodation;
(c) sufficient funds to allow the housing authorities to undertake a comprehensive survey of housing needs and the adequacy of the existing housing stock;

(d) sufficient funds to enable the housing authorities, in co-operation with the Commonwealth, to develop a strategy as part of overall urban and regional policy planning to ensure a social mix in housing estates as well as ensuring that public housing tenants have access to social and cultural amenities and job opportunities;

(e) sufficient funds to allow the housing authorities to expand and improve the stock of public housing while enabling them to continue an effective program of home ownership assistance for low and middle income earners;
(f) that the interest rates charged for home purchase account 'on lent' to other lending authorities should rise in line with capacity to pay;
(g) that the rents of public housing tenants be related to capacity to pay and otherwise determined on an averaged cost-rent basis, and
(h) an adequate forward commitment of real funds to enable the States and Territories to properly plan their housing programs, and
(3) the opportunity should be provided for the Commonwealth Parliament to debate annually the appropriation to determine progress made in relation to the objectives of the Agreement.

The Housing Assistance Bill is a disgrace, a national scandal. It represents a further withdrawal of the Federal Government from its national responsibilities to ensure security of housing for all Australians. It is an intolerable withdrawal of its special responsibility to provide for the welfare of the Aboriginal people. It signals increases in hardship for the growing number of low and middle income earners. Further, it neglects the hundreds of thousands of people in need of housing security. Never before in the history of the Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement has the Federal Government given so little. Never before has the Federal Government been so mean and miserable. The new agreement is to last for at least five years, and this Bill will be debated for one hour. It will not even be reviewed during those five years. It cannot properly be called an agreement. It is an imposition. The Fraser Government has imposed on the States and individuals the burden of its misguided economic policies. This imposition represents a further transfer of public funds away from the needs of the people and towards the corporate sector.

This Government has singled out the housing sector, both private and public, but particularly the public sector, to bear the brunt of its regressive policies of transferring wealth away from the working people of Australia and their dependants. Next to unemployment, housing security is the most serious social problem in Australia. It is aggravated by the contractionary and regressive policies of the Fraser Government. The full extent of housing needs in Australia has been ob- scured by this Government's failure to provide regular detailed housing information. We are told that across Australia there are 80,000 families on the waiting lists of the housing authorities, but that is a real under-estimation of the real number of people in need of rental accommodation and home purchase assistance. In New South Wales alone, at the end of December 1980 over 36,000 families were on the New South Wales Housing Commission list. The New South Wales Minister of Housing has already made a clear statement that if the new Agreement goes through 40,000 families will be on the waiting list by the end of this year. Of course, the Agreement will be forced through by the Government with its numbers.

The Victorian Minister of Housing has estimated conservatively that at least 100,000 households are in need in that State. On the basis of the 1974-75 data, he has estimated that the public housing stock in Victoria can cater for only 34 per cent of apparent needs. Since that time the number of people below the poverty line has increased as has the number of unemployed and homeless. The Victorian Housing Minister places due blame on the Federal Government's cutback in public sector housing outlays for the deterioration in the Victorian housing position. Even the Victorian Government's irresponsible selling off of too large a proportion of its public housing stock has left it with mostly high rise units or houses in unsuitable areas. The waiting time in Victoria is some cases exceeds four years. It is a wonder that hundreds of thousands of people are not on the waiting list. People know that they hardly have a chance, no matter how long they wait. They know that what they will be offered probably will not be suitable for them in the long term.

Some 80,000 families on the waiting lists of the State public housing authorities around the country is an unacceptable number, but even that number does not indicate the full extent of the housing needs. Across Australia at present about 150,000 people are homeless. A quarter of a million people are living in caravans or temporary makeshift accommodation. In the city of Gladstone about one-quarter of the population is now living in caravans, and those figures do not take into account the new growth in Gladstone. They represent the backlog from the 1960s and 1970s. At the start of the so-called resource development about 25 per cent of people in Gladstone already are living in caravans and temporary accommodation. This will happen across the country wherever resource development occurs. People will live in squalor. This Government cannot and will not provide more detailed statistics, yet it will encourage the Department of Housing and Construction to develop a prototype of a mobile home, the size of a caravan, to be used to house workers and their families in the regions where resource development is taking place. Honourable members should have no doubt that later the Government will put forward this type of accommodation as an alternative in our cities. Instead of providing decent public housing it will try to put people into temporary accommodation.

The problem of housing involves both the public and private sectors. Private rents are increasing beyond the means of the low income families, which are vulnerable to acute poverty as higher and higher proportions of their declining disposable incomes go in rent. I give one example, and I have witnessed this myself. In a terrace in the inner city suburb of Stanmore in Sydney six rooms are rented for between $35 and $60 a week each. Most of the tenants are pensioners. The terrace has one toilet, with outside access for 10 people. Few of the rooms have hot running water. One male pensioner uses a methylated spirit lighter to cook his meals. The place has not been painted for 10 years. The ceiling leaks in a number of places and basic repairs have not been carried out despite the tenant's complaints. Unfortunately, this case is not an exception. There are thousands of over priced, overcrowded, sub-standard dwellings on the Sydney, Melbourne and Gladstone and other city rental markets.

A growing number of people have no choice but to accept what they can get. They dare not complain for fear they will be evicted. That is their problem. There are just too many people in fear they will be evicted if they complain and seek justice. It is not possible to get justice under this type of conservative government. It would not be difficult for me and for other members of the House to describe case by case moral neglect and exploitation in the private rental market. I am sure that if honourable members on the other side cared to look they would find case after case of intolerable hardship for pensioners, single parents, unemployed youth and other groups, but particularly for the young seeking homes. These people deserve more just and humane housing security.

Let us consider the home ownership side of the private housing market. After all this Government seems to be very proud that it is a government of private enterprise. This Government is content to parade figures from a few years back to show that the level of home ownership in Australia, by international standards, is high. The Government neglects to mention that home ownership is declining dramatically, particularly for people between the ages of 20 and 30 years. We have been given figures to suggest that the rate of lending for home purchase is increasing, but we are not told the whole truth. The rate of lending of money to first home buyers is declining. An increasing proportion of loans is going to people who already have homes and who are seeking to renovate them, move into a higher priced home or acquire a second, third, fourth or fifth home. We are not told of the effect of speculation in the housing market which is pushing up prices in the sought after areas of the capital cities, thus putting home ownership outside the reach of a growing number of people.

Some wealthy people are well housed. There are those smart people, who can afford to do it, who can get finance for a second home. They are paying high interest rates to get that second home, but in buying and renting out that second home they can get the interest rate as a tax deduction. Consequently, many people in Sydney, the smarties and the wealthy, instead of investing in gold are investing in real estate. People are suffering as a result because they cannot afford to pay the rent. This Government will not come clean about the factors which have increased the home loan interest rates which have been brought about by its obsession to hold down the domestic and public sector activities in order to allow the foreign corporations free rein in the Australian resource economy. The broad policies in the Australian resource economy are really the Achilles heel of this housing policy.

The Government is not prepared to face up to the fact that persons earning less than $15,000 a year-that accounts for around three-quarters of the people in the work force-cannot obtain sufficient funds to purchase a home. This Government will not face up to the fact that access to home ownership has declined from nine out of ten wage earners ten years ago to two out of ten wage earners today. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard several tables showing the levels of income required to service a housing loan of $30,000 at different interest rates and a deposit gap for home owners on average earnings trying to buy a home priced at $45,000, $55,000 and $65,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The tables show that the person seeking a housing loan of $30,000 over a 30-year term at 11 1/2 per cent interest rate requires a weekly income of $275. That excludes 71 per cent of the male work force in this country. With a one per cent increase to 12 1/2 per cent-the rise likely under the policies of this Government-the weekly income required to service that loan would be $296 a week. That excludes 76 per cent of the male work force. It is shown that a person on average earnings who wishes to buy a house for $55,000, which is almost $30,000 below the medium price in Sydney, has a borrowing limit of $30,140. At an 11 1/2 per cent interest rate, that leaves a deposit gap of $19,360. If the interest rate is 12 1/2 per cent the deposit gap grows to $21,350. Where can a person find the remainder to make up that deposit gap? That is the impossible dream. That is the situation in regard to housing under private ownership in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: A couple could rely on their joint income to obtain a large loan or to secure a second mortgage of around 16 per cent and upwards. For most people such a decision would mean deferring a family. For many it would involve a risk of over-commitment in the event of a partner losing a job. The point is that the pressures of the private home ownership market are creating a higher demand for rental accommodation. In the private rental market those on relatively high incomes are pushing the lower income tenants out as landlords see the opportunity to push up rents so that low income tenants are forced to grab what they can. As I have said, we would see a much higher level of demand for public housing if there were sufficient suitable public housing stock available. The situation is similar to that existing in the labour market. If better jobs were available the unemployment statistics would rise in the immediate term as the hidden unemploment. Those too discouraged to worry about being included in the labour force statistics would come out of hiding. So it is in the public housing sector that present statistics underestimate by a factor of at least ten the real number of people in this country waiting for homes. What has been the Government's response? I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard several tables showing outlays by the Federal Government on housing since 1974-75.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The tables bear close inspection. The Bill provides for a forward commitment in money terms, not in real terms, of $200m each year for the next five years in federal payments to the States and the Northern Territory for housing assistance. In today's prices, the real outlay on housing payments to the States and the Northern Territory, including Aboriginal housing, pensioner housing and assistance to other groups of people in need, equals $850m. In other words, taking the figures in real terms in 1974-75-the last full year Labor was in government-Labor made $850m available, and this Government is making $200m available this year. If we look at the inflation figure and take it as an average of 10 per cent over the next 5 years if the Government keeps this base rate of $200m then to get the same value the figure should be $292.8m at the end of the 5 year term.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill provides for less than one-quarter of the amount which Labor gave 5 years ago. The allocation will be eroded more and more by inflationary pressures under this Government. The Minister has told us that the allocation gives the States and the Northern Territory a chance to enable them properly to plan their housing programs. It gives them a forward commitment to increase stringency. It directs them to cut back on levels of housing services. It entices them to pull out of the Commonwealth-State Agreement. Let us consider some specifics. I was intrigued by the Minister's ignorance, if I may say so, in his statement on Tuesday, 26 May, in answer to a question by the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Bourchier), the Government Whip, who professes to be very interested in housing. On behalf of the Government he has limited this housing debate to one hour. In effect the Minister said that claims of some States having to pay more back to the Commonwealth in capital and interest repayment than they were getting from the Commonwealth under this agreement were scurrilous. What are the facts? I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the real net payments to the States for housing from 1974-75 to 1980-81.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. The table net amount after both the interest repayment and the capital repayment have been repaid. The net amount of Federal payments has fallen from $515m in 1974-75 to $75.7m in 1980-81. This year the States can use only one-seventh of the amount of funds that they had 6 years ago. This year the States are paying back $200.3m to the Commonwealth. A question was asked of the Minister by the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Leo McLeay) this morning during Question Time. Because it was not a Dorothy Dix question the Minister could not answer. I had to take a point of order to say: 'You are only offering $200m a year but, in fact, the States are paying $200.3m back to you'. Of course, this will continue each year. The housing situation is getting so bad that the Minister, like Pontius Pilate, wants to wash his hands of any of the real responsibilities for housing problems. In other words, what we are really looking at is a very acute position.

SPEECH.PARA: The $200m that has been made available this year will consist of $54m in a direct grant for Aboriginals and pensioners and $146m of loan money. Next year, New South Wales will receive 31.1 per cent of the $146m of loan funds made available to the States and the Northern Territory; that is, $45m of which $32m will go to the Housing Commission of New South Wales and the remaining $13.5m to the building societies. The New South Wales Housing Commission estimates that it will be paying back to the Commonwealth $56m in both interest and capital repayments. The New South Wales Government does not know how much of the $54m of grants for Aboriginal housing, pensioners and other persons in need it will receive next year. Under this Bill giving 'autonomy' to the States this is a matter for the Minister to determine on his assessment of need. How can the Minister make such an assessment when he does not have the necessary information? How can he argue that the States can plan their programs properly when they do not know what grants they will receive and whether they will receive topping up funds once the program is under way?

In South Australia the position is similar. South Australia will receive a 14.2 per cent share of the $146m loans, which is about $21m this year-a cut of over $4m on the previous year and about the same amount that South Australia will be paying back to the Commonwealth next year in interest repayments and capital repayments. South Australia has had a progressive housing policy under the Playford non-Labor Government and under Labor governments of building up its public housing stock. But that possibility in the future may well be undermined by the shift to per capita allocation of housing assistance which will erode the payments to South Australia even further. South Australia faces a future of falling Commonwealth payments and rising State repayments. It is the people of South Australia in need of housing assistance who truly will be the meat in the sandwich.

A special feature of this Bill is the inclusion of Aboriginal housing as a State responsibility. The Australian Government has reneged on its special responsibilities to the Aboriginal people and reduced the funds available for Aboriginal housing in real terms from approximately $81m in 1974-75 to less than $62.4m in 1980-81. Next year even less will be made available as only $54m is earmarked for special assistance. This includes not only Aboriginals but also pensioners and other groups in need. All will suffer as a result.

Public housing tenants will face further rent increases as the new agreement moves away from the inequitable concept of market related rents to the outrageous proposal for market rents in the public sector. In some magical way this Bill provides for a uniform national system of establishing market rents. How in heaven's name the Government can do that I do not know. The cost of housing differs so much from city to city and from State to State. In Victoria the sheltered group has called this move a conspiracy against public housing tenants. It is a sad case of policy based on the backward theory that the tail wags the dog. In 1979 over 40 per cent of public housing tenants in Victoria were in rental arrears. The number has increased since. An increasing proportion are more than 10 weeks in arrears. The rate of increase in rental rebates exceeds the rate of increase in rents received in all States. The sad thing about this is that the people getting into arrears are facing insecurity and the fear that has been created because of the enormous debt burden thrown on them by the policies of this Government. Under these conditions the States have smaller rather than larger surpluses with which to finance public housing improvements and expansion. All the policy of market rents means is that the needy and the poor are subsidising the very poor and the very needy. There remains no evidence that middle income tenants have departed from public housing or that eligible low income earners have increased their entry into this area. All the evidence points to the increasing fear and insecurity on the part of public housing tenants-an effect which is contrary to the objective of providing housing security for people in need.

This Bill also provides for rental assistance to be given to private sector tenants. I say with due respect to those people that subsidising public housing rentals is no real solution. The major solution is that we have to make sure that we make more money available to build public sector housing so that form of rental is available. It represents a waste of public expenditures to invest taxpayers' monies in the pockets of existing multiple home owners without the public gaining any tangible return of the investment through an increase in the size and quality of public housing sector stock. Already we have seen the public housing sector reduced to a minimal proportion of the total housing stock in Australia. In 1974-75 public dwelling commencements totalled 19,000. In 1979-80 they were down to almost half that number at 10,500. The public housing sector is a crucial element that provides balance, stability and security in the housing market.

Labor is committed to increasing the access of people to private home ownership. We are clearly committed to that policy. If we can ever get a person on the first rung of the ladder to private home ownership we want to do that. In conclusion I say, as I said at the beginning, that this Bill is a disgrace. This Commonwealth and State Housing Agreement is a scandal. The next Federal Labor Government will renegotiate this agreement and create a new agreement. We will do that after we have discussions with the States. The only way we will really begin to solve the problem is by discussion between the national government and the States, the private sector and local government. That is the only way that we really can decide the great social problem of housing in this country.
