TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition for bringing so many honourable members into the House to listen to my remarks this evening. I certainly welcome this legislation, the Housing Assistance Bill 1981. The Bill is an affirmation that the present Federal Government consistently recognises those most in need and is always working to improve their situation, whether in regard to housing or other needs. It helps to provide housing to those who are unable or cannot afford to purchase their own homes. The Bill also strongly reinforces the Federal Government's policy of minimum interference in State government affairs. The majority of funds are provided by way of untied moneys. This is a positive demonstration of the Government's commitment to federalism.

SPEECH.PARA: I strongly reject the comments made earlier in this debate by the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren). They lacked both substance and logic. I recall the debate in 1978 on the Housing Assistance Bill 1978, which introduced the housing agreement that is due to expire on 30 June this year. That legislation gave effect to what was then a new three-year housing agreement. I took the honourable member for Reid to task for his comments during that debate. His comments tonight show he has not learnt anything during the last three years. It is worth while referring briefly to that debate. The honourable member for Reid claimed that our 1978 legislation would not reduce the backlog of families waiting for housing commission or housing trust homes. The backlog was then around 100,000 homes. However, under that legislation, over the last three years of this Government's administration the backlog has been reduced to 85,000 homes. So the predictions of doom and gloom made by the honourable member for Reid were not fulfilled over that period. Therefore, the comments he has made this evening concerning this legislation should similarly be taken with a grain of salt.

In his remarks tonight, the honourable member for Reid claimed that no detailed information is provided concerning housing in Australia. But since 1978 this Government has ensured that an annual report on housing has been provided to the Parliament. Each year we have provided the most comprehensive report on welfare housing produced in Australia. He claimed that no provision was made for those who find themselves in a homeless situation. But the State housing authorities are able to provide urgently rental housing on a priority basis to those shown to be homeless.

The Australian Labor Party does not support the present Government's positive attitude to housing. It takes the view that the more money the Government spends the better off all members of the community will be, including those most in need. That is a complete fallacy. The experience of the last decade clearly shows that the great bulk of the community is better off if government spending, and therefore taxation, is kept to a minimum so that people are left to spend their own incomes according to their own preferences, free of bureaucratic interference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!
—Hear, hear!

—I thank the honourable member for Barker and the honourable member for Berowra for their support. Government spending can then be directed to those in real need, who are unable to provide for themselves in any way. The detrimental impact of the housing policy of the Labor Party is reflected in its miserable record in the era it was in office. Housing interest rates soared as high as 11 per cent, which was a 4 per cent increase over the three years it was in office. In marked contrast, the Fraser Government has largely stabilised interest rates over the last three years, the highest rate being 12.5 per cent, an increase of only 1.5 per cent in the five years it has been in office. This compares with the 4 per cent increase during just three years that Labor was in office.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Labor Administration, the cost of building materials rose by over 60 per cent. Waiting lists for welfare housing increased to 104,000 families. The Labor Party also discriminates very clearly against home ownership for single income families. In its policy for home ownership put to the people before the last election, it stated that a means test of only $16,000 would apply to single income families seeking assistance. However, the means test for two-income families would be $24,000. That is clear discrimination. A single income family with any number of children would not have been able to receive a grant if its total household income from that one breadwinner was over $16,000, but a family with two breadwinners would have been able to receive assistance, whether it had children or not, if its income was under $24,000. The honourable member for Reid has left the chamber, so his concern about housing, as I said earlier, can be taken with a grain of salt.

TALK.START.PARA: —He can't take it.

—He certainly cannot take it. The electorate quite correctly rejected such an iniquitous proposal with its resounding defeat of the Labor Party at the last election. I might ask whether the Labor Party has rethought its policy on those matters as a result of its defeat.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill is the major instrument for the implementation of the present Government's welfare housing policy. The Commonwealth is providing $285m to the States and the Northern Territory for the purpose of welfare housing in 1980-81. The Commonwealth has also offered to guarantee to provide a base level of $1,000m over the five years from July 1981 to assist the States and the Northern Territory in the provision of welfare housing. Additional funds will be allocated each year under this proposed arrangement as part of normal budgetary procedures. So, contrary to the comments of the honourable member for Reid, the $200m to be provided each year is a minimum amount to be provided and not the maximum, as he perhaps would have had us believe. The Bill is an effective demonstration of the Fraser Government's commitment to the provision of adequate housing for the people of Australia and of encouraging the widest possible enjoyment of home ownership.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not so.

—It is so. Such a program of Government assistance as is provided in this Bill continues to be an important requirement. At the present time some 85,000 people or families throughout Australia are on the waiting list for government-funded rental accommodation. Of these, some 19,000 live in my own State of South Australia. However, the present Government has made significant progress in reducing the massive backlog which developed during the era of the Whitlam Labor Government. From a backlog of something less than 80,000 when the Labor Party came to office, the backlog soared to 104,000 when it left office. This was a direct result of its disastrous economic management, which had a dual effect. More people became dependent on welfare and the cost of housing soared. To reduce this backlog of 85,000 over five years is a creditable performance by this Government. Similarly, over the same period this Government has increased the stock of lettable government housing from 194,000 to 210,000. In South Australia the backlog of applications has been reduced from 23,000 to 19,000, while the stocks of lettable dwellings have increased from 38,000 to 42,000. Despite a continuing need, the Government's policies are commendable. This legislation will continue that favourable trend.

SPEECH.PARA: While encouraging home ownership, the Government recognises that there are those who, because of their circumstances, cannot afford to buy a house. However, some 72 per cent of homes are owned or are being purchased by their occupants. Australia has one of the highest levels of home ownership in the world. It used to be even higher. It is a tragedy that the percentage fell during the period that Labor was in office. The success of the Fraser Government in containing inflation and interest rates in comparison with the way they soared between 1972 and 1975, and also by way of current comparison with most industrialised countries around the world, has helped home ownership grow again. Over the last five years an extra 600,0000 Australian families have acquired their own homes.

Home ownership is a stabilising influence in the community, so it is vital that home purchase assistance be maintained and strengthened by this Government. The 1978 housing agreement was a progressive step forward towards this. When it expires in June, the new arrangements this Bill provides will be more beneficial to needy people than was the case before. Whether people are able to purchase their own homes or must continue to rent, the Government has an obligation to help them. The Fraser Government is fulfilling that obligation. With the proposed program's two-fold purpose of a home purchase assistance program and rental housing assistance program, needy people will have more chance of eventually attaining full home ownership.

Obviously there are those people who would prefer to rent accommodation because of age or special housing needs. Within the general group of needy people in our community, which this legislation assists, special assistance is provided for disadvantaged groups. Aborigines, pensioners and invalids will benefit from the $54m a year which is earmarked for rental accommodation only. The remainder of the $200m per annum-that is, $146m in advances-will either be applied for rental or for home purchase at 4 1/2 per cent per annum which, it should be recognised, is some 8 per cent below the prevailing interest rates. This compares more than favourably with the 2 per cent interest rate concession which the Labor Government gave when it was in office and the 4 per cent concession which the 1978 legislation provided. The honourable member for Reid described this as a miserable contribution. I would suggest than an 8 per cent concession, as against a 2 per cent concession, is a remarkable level of assistance. It should be emphasised, of course, that the States will be at liberty to allocate all those non-earmarked funds between rental housing assistance and home purchase in the proportion they determine as appropriate.

Thus the Government has a progressive yet sensible approach to housing. It recognises that if we are to use the taxpayers' money, it must be used wisely and carefully. Most importantly, the Government's housing policy ensures that the taxpayers' money is directed to families in the community in real need of help with their housing. But the Government is one which recognises the contribution of the individual to society. It strongly encourages home ownership, recognising its benefits. If the individual is able to provide for himself or herself, he or she should be encouraged to do so. Whilst this Bill concentrates on welfare and public housing, it is necessary to take note of the well being of the private housing sector. Ninety per cent of householders satisfy their housing needs in the private sector. The private housing market serves Australia well. I urge the Government to continue to recognise that fact.

As a part of aiding people to achieve home ownership it is noteworthy that the Government is making funds available through lending agencies at concessional interest rates. It is operating in the market system to achieve its aim of optimum home ownership. Australians who aspire to own their own homes will benefit from the concessional rates and from the efficient disbursal of funds through private lending institutions. Once again the Commonwealth will leave it up to the States to determine lending practices-and their flexibility, as well as repayment variations, in the event of hardship.

As regards rental accommodation, the Federal Government in the 1978 agreement pursued an attitude of making States charge market related rents for public rental dwellings, with rental rebates for people unable to afford market related rents. However, the new agreement offers a policy of market rents instead of the market related rent policy required by the 1978 agreement. Income related rebates applied to market rents are the fairest deal for those people with housing needs. As a result, under the 1978 agreement those who received rebates were often those in receipt of social security type benefits, such as widows, age or invalid pensioners and single parent families. Also receiving benefits were those single income two-parent families where income was at a low level. This will continue under this legislation. However, the provision is that those whose circumstances improve substantially will be subject to the payment of rents reflecting increased capacity to pay. Once again, the Government recognises that it is necessary to concentrate on the needs of those who most warrant assistance. It is also significant that the aid given to those people for home purchase is determined upon need. Under the 1978 agreement-in 1979-80 for example-73 per cent of loans were made to households with a total income of less than $239 per week. The new legislation continues that approach.

The Bill further increases flexibility given to the States and ensures that the objectives of the original 1978 housing agreement will not be altered. The three new objectives in the current Bill are also commendable in that they recognise the federalist aims of this Government. In accordance with the aims of the International Year of Disabled Persons, design, style and siting of public housing will, as far as practicable, reflect the needs of handicapped people. States will also have regard to energy savings which can be made by the design style and siting of the public housing. In addition, tenants in public housing will be encouraged to become involved in public housing policy and in estate management. This provides a way to enable more individual involvement in determining how living conditions might be inspired directly by those living in public housing.

The 1981 agreement enacted by this legislation will provide for sales of rental dwellings to tenants. It will also continue the policy of dwellings being sold for cash. With such a cash sale policy, States will be able to replace housing and maintain the levels of accommodation available for rental. People will be eligible to purchase houses and can apply for housing loans under the home purchase assistance program. Tenants who purchase houses will be rewarded if they make improvements to their properties because States will adjust the market value of dwellings accordingly.

In conclusion, the Bill will do much to help those on low incomes who are, therefore, in need of welfare rental housing or who desire to purchase their own homes but who are unable to afford to purchase on the open market. On that basis I strongly support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment moved by the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) goes to the heart of the problem of welfare housing in Australia. The Housing Assistance Bill does not provide sufficient funds to meet the neglected housing needs of the Australian people and signals further withdrawal by the Federal Government from its responsibility in this area. Federal expenditure on housing peaked in 1974-75, and real expenditure has been cut back each year since. As a result, public housing construction rates continue to decline and waiting lists and waiting times continue to increase. The problem is exacerbated by the inability of the private sector to assist, as indicated by a survey conducted by the Real Estate Institute of Australia this year which showed a high demand for private rental housing and flats, with low vacancy rates. The main features of the 1978-79 Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement and the present Bill are statements of principle, but the basic requirement of adequate funds has been ignored.

SPEECH.PARA: The statements by this Government that its policy is directed at giving scope for a wide range of innovations in policy and, in the words of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) 'The current Bill increases the flexibility given to the States and continues the process of ensuring that assistance is directed to people in need' are absolute nonsense as those so-called statements of principle are stated simultaneously with drastic cutbacks in funding. This, as was stated so clearly by the honourable member for Reid, is the core of the problem. The lack of appreciation by this Government of the grave problems in welfare housing is clearly demonstrated from the Victorian Liberal Party document 'Federalism-Is It Working?' There are two particularly relevant quotes from that document. Firstly, if one supports the need for restraint on government expenditure there is still the question why housing has been singled out to receive such an unprecedented attack. Secondly, public housing is the only category to have suffered a fall in Commonwealth outlays in real terms. It is difficult to understand why this should occur, as housing directly stimulates the economy and provides capital works for the private sector. The Government has been slated in dramatic terms by a Victorian government of its own failed, outdated philosophy.

The facts must be spelled out in a plea to the Government to reverse its policy. On 26 March this year figures released by the Government showed that applications for rental accommodation in Australia through State authorities totalled 83,391 at 31 December 1980. This represented an increase of 11,479 over the 1978 figure and 10,927 over the 1979 figure. According to the Government's figures, the waiting list in Victoria was 13,861-an increase of 1,805 over the 1979 figure. To be more specific on the Victorian position, in 1980 the Westernport Regional Housing Council prepared a working paper for the Ministry of Housing. This research showed that in the Westernport area rental stocks of houses and flats totalled 2,045 for a population of 388,000-that is, rental houses and flats as a percentage of population was 0.5 per cent. The consequences for the Westernport area have been devastating. The waiting list for 17 of 22 estates with family dwellings is indefinite; for two estates, three years; for a further two estates, one year; and the other estate is reserved for armed services. The waiting lists for 21 of 27 estates with elderly persons' dwellings are indefinite; for three estates, four years, and for the further three estates, 12 to 18 months.

This tragic situation is reflected in other specific areas in Victoria such as the Ministry of Housing figures for the Dandenong district where over 3,000 people are waiting for home purchase. There is a 4-year to 5-year wait for rental of a two-bedroomed home, over 3 years for a three-bedroomed home and 4 years to 5 years for a ground floor flat. In April 1981 the Westernport Youth Refuge prepared a further submission to the Ministry of Housing. This allowed that in all the municipalities in the Westernport region a desperate need existed for housing for young people on low incomes. The submission concentrated on the two areas of greatest need-Dandenong and Frankston. The term 'youth homelessness' covers a wide range of needs, and the age of young people involved ranges from 14 to 25 years. The submission by the Westernport Youth Refuge focused on young people seeking long term individual accommodation. The emergency housing service which the refuge has been forced to provide is having great difficulty in achieving a quick turnover of residents because there is no long term housing for them to move into. Stays of 9 to 12 weeks are becoming common, and these young people are in need of secure, low cost housing.

The facts outlined by me tonight clearly show a desperate need for welfare housing in Victoria for young people, those in the middle age group and the elderly. Unfortunately, it is necessary to spell out to this Government some specific case studies which were conducted by the Westernport Youth Refuge to emphasise the tragedy over which this Government and its Liberal counterpart in Victoria presided. Some examples from the Westernport Youth Refuge submission are as follows: Firstly, a 19-year-old girl left Tasmania to look for work. She went to stay with a family friend in Lang Lang. This is only a temporary home and is unsuitable in any case because of lack of public transport and employment opportunities. She would like to live by herself in a one-bedroomed flat or in a bungalow. Her income is $53 a week, and as she has been paying board she has no savings. Secondly, a 16 year-old unemployed male, forced to leave home, is receiving $36 a week. His weekly budget does not and could not leave any money over for rent. Thirdly, a 23-year-old male, sleeping in railway stations around Melbourne for 2 weeks prior to residing at the youth refuge, was not receiving benefits at that time but now receives $53 a week. Fourthly, a 20-year-old female living in Sydney decided to travel to Melbourne with a male friend. She was living with him. She was forced to leave because he beat her. She went to the Commonwealth Employment Service and then to a local Community Youth Support Scheme and was referred to the refuge. She is planning to move into a two-bedroomed flat with a friend she met at the refuge. The refuge is being forced to pay the bond and the rent in advance because she cannot afford to do so. Fifthly, a 16-year-old female, forced to leave home after severe beatings from her father, arrived at the refuge with two black eyes and severe body bruising. Her sisters and mother had been subject to similar beatings over several years. She left home and her mother was sympathetic to the girl living in a private board situation. Once again, it is impossible for her to afford to do that.

These are actual case histories. Instead of the Federal Government making adequate finance available to the State of Victoria and the Victorian Government properly applying such funds, supplemented by its own funding, this human tragedy will continue. This must be the case with reductions in funding by the Federal Government, coupled with the incompetence of the Victorian Government, clearly demonstrated by the appalling housing conditions in Victoria and highlighted by the commission of inquiry into the Victorian Housing Commission land deals. Instead of facing the issue, the Federal Minister for Housing and Construction and the State Minister have engaged in public abuse, the State Minister suggesting that the Federal Government should abolish the Department of Housing and sack its Minister. Not to be denied, the Federal Minister, in his reply, accused the State Minister of unwarranted Canberra bashing and unreasonable bellyaching. While the two Ministers engage in an argument about how much Victoria contributes to welfare housing, the people who are suffering are treated as pawns in the dispute. The shadow Minister for Housing in Victoria, Mr Ian Cathie, has requested both Ministers to justify their claims on the figures contributed by Victoria to welfare housing. Clearly both Ministers cannot be correct and the time has come to put up or shut up. We eagerly await their replies to Mr Cathie on this matter.

Never before in the history of Australia has a Federal government given so little to the crucial area of housing. This agreement fixes total Federal housing expenditure at $200m for each of the next five years. That figure, in itself, is bad enough but inflation will erode the real value of such funds year by year. The allocation of the same level of funding in money terms for each of the five years of the agreement guarantees that the real value of Commonwealth assistance will decline in each year of the agreement. Assuming an inflation rate of 10 per cent in each year of the Agreement, to maintain the same real value in 1985-86 the allocation for that year would have to be $292.8m. Under this agreement the amount from the Commonwealth in 1985-86 will remain at $200m, that is, only 70 per cent of what is needed to maintain real value using 1981-82 as the base year. In fact, by the next year some States will be paying more to the Commonwealth in capital and interest than they will receive. Not only are Australians facing insecurity in employment but, because of the policies of this mean and miserable Government, they are also faced with the tragedy of an appalling lack of housing for those most in need. The answer to the question 'Federalism-is It Working?' is clearly no. This is an issue which even the Victorian Liberal Party is capable of understanding. This Government has proved itself incapable of developing a housing policy.

It has been necessary to go through those matters very quickly because of the time allocated for this debate. Any government that seriously puts a Bill such as this before the House and then allows the amount of time to debate it that it has allowed, when one considers that the Bill involves a housing agreement for the next five years, is guilty of a contemptible performance and clearly indicates its contempt for people in desperate need in the area of housing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Housing Assistance Bill endorses the concept that welfare housing should promote the principles of energy conservation and concern for the every day needs of handicapped persons living in that housing. It is to these particular aspects of the legislation that I would like to address my remarks. In the International Year of Disabled Persons it is fitting indeed that this Government should pay particular attention to the needs of the disabled. There are 1.4 million people in Australia who suffer some form of disability affecting their mobility. Many of these people are occupants of welfare housing, and it is to this group that the innovations encouraged by this legislation are relevant. People who are handicapped but mobile, using wheelchairs or walking frames, or who suffer from bad arthritic conditions or other physical disabilities, have an important basic need for easy access to their home. Steps or stairs should not make access to the home or within the home too difficult. Ramps can be used instead of steps. This provision would also benefit mothers and children with pushers and prams. Rooms should be easily accessible, doors should be wide enough for wheelchairs to pass through and multiple level and high rise buildings should be discouraged when we are providing housing for the handicapped. People in wheelchairs or using walking frames require ready access to public transport. It is most important for public housing, whenever possible, to be conveniently sited near public transport and shopping centres.

SPEECH.PARA: Specific design characteristics in houses can greatly improve the standard of living for handicapped or disabled people. Light switches often create difficulties for the handicapped person. They should be placed at a suitable level and consist of a large rocker-type switch which could be operated by any appropriate limb, or part of a limb such as an elbow. Lower switch levels would also be useful for young children who find it very difficult to reach and operate the common type of light switch. Power points are usually located on skirting boards, making them very difficult to reach from a wheelchair, difficult for the aged to reach and almost impossible for a person using a walking frame to reach. This difficulty could be easily overcome by raising power points to waist level, a simple and inexpensive change in any housing design. Cistern buttons and taps in bathrooms and toilets can cause difficulty for disabled people. They should be easily accessible and of careful design. Rails in bathrooms for the elderly and arthritic are a small additional attachment which could be installed in all houses.

The structural design of stoves is another area where simple changes could make a big difference to disabled persons. Usually stove controls are located at the rear of the stove and at a level which is too high for a person in a wheelchair to operate. The design and installation of a stove with controls at the front or side could overcome this inconvenience. Levers instead of knobs to operate doors would be a great advantage, especially for people disadvantaged by arthritis. A paralysed person is not usually able to turn a door knob; however, such a person is able to move a lever or push through a swinging door arrangement. Few of these design suggestions are expensive, and this legislation gives every encouragement for public housing authorities to implement them. Suitable access into and within houses will enable the disabled in our community to live in their own homes rather than face the possibility of having to move into special accommodation. Families will be able to remain together with full encouragement being given to disabled people to live as nearly as possible a normal life.

The second area in this Bill which I would like to discuss concerns measures to reduce energy consumption in housing. The second reading speech of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) refers to the States having regard for energy savings which are appropriate in an energy conscious era. Public housing authorities have the responsibility for including cost efficient, energy-conscious features in their buildings or alternatively providing financial incentives to people who install energy saving devices. To facilitate this energy consciousness it is essential for occupants to be allowed maximum discretion over their own use of energy. They should be able to control thermostat settings or close off sections of the building which are not in use. That means that individual occupants would be responsible for the cost of energy consumed in their dwellings, thus encouraging more energy consciousness. This also supports the principle of the user paying for the services provided.

Siting and site planning are important parts of the total concept of energy conservation. Trees and plants should be planted to provide maximum shade during hot summer conditions and minimum shade during cool winter conditions. To illustrate this point, deciduous vines planted on the northern and western sides of a house provide shade and protection from the sun during the hot summer whilst in the winter, with the loss of foliage, the house is allowed the benefit of the winter sun. In cool climates buildings should be set back from the northern site boundary so as to minimise overshadowing from trees, buildings and other structures on adjacent sites. Buildings designed for temperate climates should have the long elevation of the building facing in a northerly direction. Large glass areas facing north allow for the sun to warm the house in winter and can be protected from the hot summer sun by blinds or other means. It is desirable to plan living rooms and kitchens to be on the northern side so that they receive maximum benefit from the winter sun. The ideal house should have a large amount of its living area facing north with a great deal of natural light entering the house through large windows.

Insulation is another area of house construction which deserves special consideration by public housing authorities. Appropriate ceiling and wall insulation retains warmth in the winter and helps keep the house interior cool in the summer. It is an added cost in construction but the benefits in terms of energy savings far outweigh the initial cost. Floors constructed of concrete provide better insulation and allow for heat retention and, when covered with a heavy carpet or rug, play an important part in maintaining an even temperature throughout the dwelling. Windows fitted with opaque, closely woven, close fitting drapes or blinds help to retain heat in the house during the winter and provide protection from the summer sun.

Consideration should be given to the provision of cost and energy efficient appliances such as solar hot water units. If housing authorities avoid the installation of heating appliances which rely solely on petroleum based fuels cost savings are achieved and the limited reserves of fossil fuels are conserved. These few suggestions give some indication of the possibilities that exist to conserve energy if sensible planning is employed in housing design. All dwellings in Australia should be looked at in terms of conserving energy. It is particularly significant that the Commonwealth Government in its assistance to welfare housing through legislation places so much emphasis on the disadvantaged person and the conservation of energy. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the last few Budgets the Federal Government has effected a redistribution of housing subsidies away from lower income groups. It has introduced matching arrangements to cover up its withdrawal from public housing expenditure. If we look at the Federal allocations for public housing in all States over recent years we will see that $400m was allocated in 1977-78; $330m in 1978-79; and $260m in 1979-80. In 1980-81 the amount went up to $285m but in that year for the first time an amount for the Northern Territory was included. In 1981-82 we see a further reduction to $200m. Worse still, we are debating a 5-year agreement. The Parliament should debate this important issue annually and should provide a forward commitment of real funds so that the States can plan their housing programs instead of having this stop-go racket. This legislation makes a mockery of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh), who in his second reading speech on the 1981 Housing Assistance Bill said:

SPEECH.PARA: Our policy is to ensure that every household in Australia is able to obtain adequate housing within its capacity to pay.
This takes one back to 1977 when the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) stated:
Once the election is over, we will start to move to the consummation of a 2 per cent reduction in interest rates-and that means about $500 a year to someone on an average home loan.

We are aware of what happened to interest rates. They continue to go up. Our expectation in respect of a policy which will ensure that every household in Australia obtains adequate housing is certainly going down.

The poverty inquiry established that 25 per cent of one's income should be the maximum allowed for rent in order for families to meet their costs adequately. What is there in the 1981 Bill of the Minister for Housing and Construction which will help families to overcome the problem of high rents, high interest and the resultant misery from inadequate housing? Where is the provision for families on low incomes to buy their own home? I tell the Minister for his information that the average cost of renting a housing in the Melbourne surburbs of Northcote, Blackburn, Windsor, Oakleigh, Frankston-in fact every suburb in Melbourne; I would think this situation is probably duplicated throughout every State in Australia-is between $60 and $70 a week. So families are paying between 45 per cent and 52 per cent of their income in rent in the private sector, not the 25 per cent as recommended by Professor Henderson. It is estimated by Shelter, a group in Victoria, that there are at least three times as many households with incomes below the poverty line living in private rented houses as there are in total Victoria Housing Commission rental dwellings. The $200m provided in this Bill will not do anything even to touch this tremendous gap. There is a crisis in public housing in Victoria which I am sure applies in other States. Public housing rental units in Victoria in 1980 numbered just over 40,000. In the same period Department of Social Security figures showed that 95,241 Victorian pensioners were receiving the $5 a week supplementary rent allowance-and that is a pitiful amount. A further 89,960 people were benefit recipients not eligible for rent assistance but obviously on very low incomes. Many pensioners and beneficiaries therefore must be renting in the private sector, which further indicates that public rental houses and flats are in desperately short supply. All in all, about 145,201 people need low cost housing in Victoria alone. A real increase was needed to subsidise low cost housing. Once again, the Government has opted out of the public sector as it does consistently.

Those renting in the private sector who are already on or below the poverty line are further disadvantaged by the high rents. There are no figures available on the number of families on low wages who are also in need of low rent housing. This is probably the greatest social problem of the 1980s. The demand for low cost housing is increasing at a time when the Federal Government is trying to get out from under all or any responsibility to the people of Australia, not just in housing but in health and education as well. It is doing so under the guise of fine words-I quote the Minister-such as:
The States will have complete freedom of choice in allocating all untied advances and grants between home purchase and rental housing assistance.

What choice do they have when they are starved of money? What hypocrisy the Minister speaks. On page 3 of the Minister's second reading speech we see that money for Aboriginal housing will be integrated into the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. We all know that this is just one more way in which the Federal Government opts out of its responsibilities. The attitude of the Federal Government is: Pass it over to the States and forget it. Perhaps the Minister hopes the problem will go away just as the Government hopes that the problems of community health centres, the women's refuges and the rape crisis centres will go away. I support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) which states that the Commonwealth must take direct responsibility for the housing of Aboriginal people. No one can say that this Minister lacks humour. On the second page of his second reading speech he said:
. . . the design, style and siting of public housing will . . . reflect the needs of the handicapped. This objective is particularly appropriate in this International Year of Disabled Persons . . .

Does the Minister not know that disabled persons are still waiting for the $700,000 that the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) has been talking about for the past nine months? This amount is to be used, among other things, to modify their homes. They know, as we on this side of the House know, that they cannot have any faith in promises from this Government. Government members seem to feel that if they mention the International Year of Disabled Persons they have done their share. It is all words and not action.

Low and moderate income earners in Victoria are facing a housing crisis and high rents are forcing many of them into financial difficulties. This is exacerbated by the growing incidence of homelessness among youth. The Victorian Housing Commission is in need of substantial new allocations of funds to assist the large numbers of people who are unable to find adequate accommodation in the private rental market. I would also say it is in need of a new Minister and some new administration so that the funds that are available can be allocated where they are needed and not disbursed on such scandals as we had over the land deals some years ago.

The present waiting list for public housing is long. Yet there is a great underestimation of the need. Housing officers can attest to the great number of people in dire housing need who do not apply to the Commission because the housing that is available is not appropriate to their needs, because of the long delays in obtaining it, because of the enormous distances that would be involved in travelling to and from work daily or because mostly high rise housing is available. Who wants to bring up one's children in high rise flats? Because of the severe Budget cuts, the amount of housing provided over past years has been greatly reduced. The Budget cuts must be reversed if the urgent housing needs of the people are to be met. In fact, I suggest that the public housing sector has to be stabilised and given, by this Government, the type of attention it got during the three years of the Whitlam Government, when the needs of the people on low incomes and the dreams of the people of Australia of owning their own homes were recognised by a government which believed in Australia for the people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the Second World War the Federal Government has awarded money to the States for welfare housing. In 1978 we saw an agreement which was to last for three years. That agreement had a number of anti-social features. The agreement which has been put forward in 1981 is even worse than the 1978 agreement, and it is expected to last another five years. The financial cuts imposed upon the States in the area of welfare housing are savage and unprincipled. They are in line with the general anti-social attack of this Government upon the poor and upon people who are not able to afford private housing. Since 1975, when $371m was made available, the situation has deteriorated. Last year only $276m was made available. The Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh) has now told us that the Government will make available only $200m as a base payment. The situation is even worse when we take into account the effects of inflation and repayments from the States to the Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, let us look at the effects of inflation. When we convert to 1981 prices, we find a steady and constant deterioration in Federal funds to the States for public housing. In 1975, $584m was provided. I will not read out all the figures, but in each year, in 1981 prices, there was a fall in real terms. In 1978, only $411m was provided; in 1979, $296m was provided; in 1980, $276m was provided. The base payment next financial year will be $200m. The Minister has said that interest rates, repayment provisions and terms are fairly generous. An interest rate of 4.5 per cent over a period of 53 years in low interest advances for rental assistance, home purchase assistance, and now a rental subsidy in the private sector is fairly generous. Of course, the Minister neglected to say that those terms should be generous. Nevertheless, even though the terms are generous, the repayment provisions affect the situation adversely. As Federal assistance declines in monetary terms, the responsibility of the States to repay previous loans increases. In 1974, $515m was made available to the States on a net basis. The amount fell to $191m in 1978. It decreased further to the extremely meagre sum of $75.7m in 1980. The breakdown of the figure for 1980 indicates that the total payment was $276m, repayment for advances was $35.6m, repayment of interest was $164.7m, and total repayments were a massive $200m. In effect, only $75.7m out of the sum of $276m was made available to the States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shameful.

—It is shameful, I agree. In 1974 total repayments were only 27 per cent of the total made available to the States and 73 per cent was actually spent in the area of public housing. Today that position has exactly reversed. Of the payments made to the States, 73 per cent has to be repaid to finance previous debts. The Minister said that this year from the base payment of $200m $54m will be available for disadvantaged persons such as pensioners and Aboriginals and $146m will be available for housing assistance for other people. That is the sum that has to be repaid.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the Aboriginal situation. The Minister said in his second reading speech that, from now, grants to the States for Aboriginal housing will be integrated into the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. We learn that $54m has been earmarked for Aboriginals, pensioners and other disadvantaged people. I put on the record, as someone who went into this area fairly deeply when I had shadow ministerial responsibility, that the Department of Aboriginal Affairs last year made $22m available for grants-in-aid to Aboriginal housing associations, $10m in State grants and $7.3m for Aboriginal hostels, a total of $39.3m. This was a cut of 43 per cent in real terms since 1975-76, but a further $22.1m was earmarked for Aboriginal housing from the general welfare housing grant. This year what will the position be? I would like an answer from the Minister, who said that he would integrate State grants for Aboriginal housing into the general welfare housing grants. I repeat that last year $10m in State grants and $22m in welfare housing grants was made available for Aboriginal housing, a total of $32m, and $31m was made available for pensioners. In 1980-81 a total of $63m was made available to the States for housing for Aboriginals and pensioners. Next financial year the figure will be $54m. Quite frankly, it needs to be at least $70m to be commensurate in real terms with the allocation made last year. I am very puzzled on this point. The Government needs to increase considerably the amount made available in top-up payments.

I hope I have demonstrated that these payments are completely unacceptable. The cuts are too great. They are despicably mean and they will contribute to unemployment. The Government acts in this way, firstly, for ideological reasons. It is committed to the so-called private sector. Secondly, the Government wishes to make cut-backs in Federal payments for the provision of social infrastructure to allow for the expansion of public financing of State infrastructure to provide the ports, power stations, railway lines, gas pipelines and so on to service the so-called resource development boom. Power stations alone in New South Wales and Victoria are supposed to require $10 billion, according to Commonwealth estimates, over the next seven or eight years. In New South Wales $2.7 billion is needed for three power stations in the Hunter Valley and in Victoria $3.2 billion is needed for the Loy Yang A and B power stations over the next five years. These massive sums will be borrowed mostly through the Loan Council. Yet this year, after taking repayments into account, the States will be given less than $70m to spend on public housing.

Let me refer to the position in boom centres like Gladstone. In Gladstone now 8,000 people out of a total of 24,000 people are living in caravans. New parks are booked out even before they are completed. I was in Gladstone recently. People are paying private residents to park their vans in backyards. No wonder that Housing Commission construction has fallen in this terrible situation. For example, the cuts that have occurred, despite the need in places like Gladstone, must be taken into account. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table prepared by the Parliamentary Library showing the number of housing commission houses and flats completed by State housing authorities year by year and State by State since 1950.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Honourable members will see that the percentage of State housing commission dwelling completions as a percentage of total dwellings completed has fallen from 22 per cent in 1955 to 5.2 per cent in 1980. That is in total. In several States the position is far worse. As a percentage of total completions of houses and flats, in Queensland the completion rate by the Housing Commission was only 1.5 per cent. It was 4.5 per cent in New South Wales and 4.5 per cent in Victoria. It is no wonder that 80,000 families are on waiting lists in Australia for housing commission accommodation, despite the artifically reduced nature of the list due to the imposition of a severe means test for eligibility. People practically have to be pauperised before they are accepted for inclusion on the housing commission lists. There are 40,000 such people in New South Wales, including 1,700 people in my own electorate of Cunningham in the Illawarra. In New South Wales in 1980 there were only 1,900 completions which was 2.3 per cent of existing total stock in New South Wales. In 1979-80 18,000 people were admitted to the waiting list for homes and 9,800 people were allocated dwellings. Of course, many of these dwellings had already been erected for many years. There is little chance that these homeless and poorly housed people will get public housing or housing in the private sector under this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Land and construction costs in the private sector are just too high in a situation of declining Federal finance to the States for public housing. In Sydney and my own town of Wollongong it is not possible even to look at a place for less than $70,000 or $80,000. Even a middle or high-middle income earner cannot afford that amount.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a State Government responsibility.
—It is this Government's responsibility. It is not only the State Government's responsibility but also the Federal Government's responsibility. What chance have these people got?
—Order! The honourable member will address the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Perhaps the Minister will restrain himself from making inane interjections. What chance have people got of saving $80,000 for a modest three-bedroom house, with interest rates from banks at 11 per cent or 12 per cent and interest rates for building society loans at 12 per cent to 13 per cent? People who are lucky enough to be able to afford and get the savings bank loan would have to pay $240 a month. With the high interest rates under this coalition on a loan of $30,000 a person would have to pay $240 a month. What chance have these people got? They would have to earn at least $1,000 a month before they qualified or were considered for a loan.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to mention some further matters and then I will conclude. I do not want to take up the time of the House for too much longer. I think I am entitled to raise these points seeing that it will be another five weary years before the Housing Agreement comes before the House again.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will do something about it in 1983.

—I am assured by my colleague the shadow Minister that we will do something about this tatty agreement in 1983 as a matter of priority. There are several matters in the Agreement itself that we are dissatisfied with. Firstly, I refer to the policy of market rents, with the system of special rebates. I ask: Who determines the market that the Government forces the States to adhere to? The real estate agents? The shortage of housing itself is the main contributing factor. In effect this Government is contributing to the housing shortage by horrendous cuts in the public housing sector. When rents go up as a result of these cuts the Government demands that the States charge the new thus induced market rents. The Government then further allows the States in this Agreement to subsidise people forced to rent at these exorbitant rentals. It will finish up that not one single house will be built in the States. That further contributes to unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition urges that the amendment be passed forthwith by this House to ensure that adequate funds are allocated to the States for public housing including, and not forgetting, housing for pensioners and that the Commonwealth accept its responsibility to fund Aboriginal housing by Federal grants to Aboriginal housing associations and not to bureaucratic State organisations which do not know what the Aboriginal people want. In conclusion we demand that this Bill be withdrawn. This absolutely horrific Bill starves the States in the great area of public housing. The Opposition cannot tolerate the fact that this Agreement is to serve the needs of the States for the next five years. The Bill should be immediately withdrawn and redrafted to take into account those sentiments expressed by my colleague the shadow Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the amendment to the Housing Assistance Bill moved by the honourable member for Reid (Mr Uren) I wish to draw attention to some matters which are of grave concern in my electorate and which are reflected in most other electorates in the outer suburbs of the capital cities of Australia. I have not much time so--
—It is outrageous too. It is a very important measure.

—Indeed, as the honourable member said, the situation is outrageous. I have not time to go into the figures which I would like to have presented to the House. There has been a drastic cut in funds for housing resulting in appalling consequences for homeless people in the outer eastern region of Melbourne. Community workers in the region are experiencing great difficulties in satisfying the demands for accommodation, especially from single parent families and homeless youth. High rents and the limited amount of private accommodation available for rent in the region are forcing many low and moderate income earners into financial and housing difficulties. For unemployed youth the position is even more desperate. The chances of obtaining flats in this area for all of these people are virtually nil. Most people seeking accommodation must look for houses to rent. This requires a $400 to $500 bond plus a $90 deposit for the electricity connection. For the young unemployed living on a pittance of $36 a week unemployment benefit such accommodation is completely unobtainable. I would like to refer to an example to demonstrate such circumstances, but that would take too long.

SPEECH.PARA: In consequence of these appalling policies the homeless are directing their anger against their local councils whereas their real enemies are the Liberal controlled State and Federal governments. Even the State housing Minister in Victoria has been so frustrated by the Commonwealth housing policy that he has called for the resignation of the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr McVeigh). The Minister's only answer to the State housing Minister has been to suggest that the Victorian Government is ignoring its responsibilities to the poor and the needy. I agree with the Minister for Housing and Construction that the Liberal State Government of Victoria has placed the poor and needy at the bottom of its list of priorities. However, the fact cannot be escaped that the reduction in Commonwealth funds provided for welfare housing indicates that the Federal Government has also completely disregarded the problems of the homeless. The Age editorial of 19 May aptly described the recent slanging match between the Commonwealth and the Victorian housing Ministers. It stated:
Sometimes both sides of an argument are clearly wrong.

What is clear is that the 'user pays' philosophy of both Liberal led governments shows a callous disregard for poor and needy people. Another matter I wish to draw to the attention of the House tonight is the desperate financial situation which many home buyers in my electorate are facing. Over the past 15 months there has been a one per cent rise in interest rates, resulting in an increase of $60 a month in average mortgage payments for home buyers. Housing has been pushed into the commercial field. In consequence interest rates are rapidly escalating as financial institutions battle to win money from investors. The high costs of mortgage repayments have been forced on to the public by the Government's deregulation of bank interest rates. Four out of five residents in my electorate own or are purchasing their homes with the aid of mortgage agreements. Many have both first and second mortgages, the second mortgage being subject to very high interest rates. For some of my constituents there has been a 25 per cent increase in mortgage repayments over the past 15 months. Their incomes are not sufficient to meet the additional costs. In consequence, they have been forced to place their homes on the market for sale. The responsibility for such desperate measures can be laid directly at the door of the Federal Government as a result of its irresponsible economic policies. Housing has to compete with resource projects and capital works programs for funds. There is a clear case for the introduction of a Commonwealth funded interest subsidy scheme for lower income familities.

Finally, I draw attention to the plight of women and children who suddenly find themselves homeless because of a breakup of marital relationships. In the vicinity of my electorate are located two women's refuges which carry out an excellent job in providing temporary accommodation for such homeless families. Unfortunately, there is virtually no welfare housing in the eastern suburbs of Melbourne. Because of their economic circumstances these women have to seek permanent accommodation through the Housing Commission. Thus, even if they are successful in reaching the top of the waiting list, they must then accept a high rise flat, which social workers all agree is totally unsuitable for small children. What these homeless families need are welfare houses located within the outer suburban community. Only in such locations will they stand a chance of resuming a normal and meaningful life. As the amendment indicates, the Federal Government has a responsibility to provide sufficient funds to the States to ensure that the housing needs of these broken families are met.

While I am on my feet I would like to express my unqualified support for the demonstrations in King's Hall by representatives of the women's refuges. We are a people's House and this Government is treating--

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame on you.
—It is shameful all right. We are a people's House.
—Order! The honourable member is no longer being relevant to the Bill. I ask him to address himself to the Bill.

—This is a people's House. This Government is treating the homeless people with a callous unprecedented indifference. It is fitting that their protest should be heard inside this chamber. I strongly support the proposed amendment, which if adopted will ensure that help is provided for home buyers on low incomes and the homeless in their present desperate circumstances.
