TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition, whilst believing that there must be some amendments, welcomes the introduction of the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Bill to ratify the 1972 Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter. However, we question why it has taken eight years to ratify the decisions which Australia signed in 1973. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the definition of 'dumping' contained in that Convention.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The definition read as follows-
For the purposes of this Convention:
1. (a) ''Dumping'' means:
(i) any deliberate disposal at sea of wastes or other matter from vessels, aircraft, platforms or other man-made structures at sea;
(ii) any deliberate disposal at sea of vessels, aircraft, platforms or other man-made structures at sea.
(b) ''Dumping'' does not include:

(i) the disposal at sea of wastes or other matter incidental to, or derived from the normal operations of vessels, aircraft, platforms, or other man-made structures at sea and their equipment, other than wastes or other matter transported by or to vessels, aircraft, platforms or other man-made structures at sea, operating for the purpose of disposal of such matter or derived from the treatment of such wastes or other matter on such vessels, aircraft, platforms or structures;
(ii) placement of matter for a purpose other than the mere disposal thereof, provided that such placement is not contrary to the aims of this Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. A resolution made at the third consultation meeting in 1978 stated that incineration at sea was an interim measure for waste disposal pending development of environmentally better solutions and that the intention of the adoption of mandatory provisions for the control of incineration at sea is not to increase the amount of wastes incinerated at sea for which there are practical land-based methods. This point should be extended to all methods of waste disposal at sea. It is not the ideal receptacle for all wastes. We must examine alternative waste disposal methods, increased recycling of wastes, and more efficient resource utilisation. Whilst there have not been many horror stories on the results of dumping of toxic chemicals into the sea from ships, there have been many examples of shore-based dumping into the ocean, most notable being the dumping of mercury into the sea off Minamata Bay in Japan. The residents ate fish and other marine life that was heavily contaminated with mercury. As a result the acute mercury poisoning from which they suffered became known as Minamata Disease. By April 1977, 1,076 residents of Minamata were certified victims of the disease and 3,000 others were awaiting examination.

SPEECH.PARA: Needless to say mercury, as well as cadmium-another environmental poison which became publicly prominent from massive health problems in Japanese waters-are both in Annex I and are totally prohibited from being disposed of in the ocean. Other metals such as arsenic and zinc are in Annex II and will require special permits for dumping. The zinc contaminated oysters of the Derwent Estuary in Tasmania gained notoriety early in the 1970s when one was analysed and found to contain 26,000 parts per million of zinc. It should be noted that the Electrolytic Zinc Co. of (Australasia) Ltd is the only company in Australia regularly to dump wastes into the sea-in 1,500 metres of water south of Hobart to be precise. It would like to move, no doubt, to shallower waters for cost reasons. Toxicity tests, which are being carried out for that company on its wastes, are being done in the United States, on an American species of fish, not those normally found in the dump area. Any research carried out to determine the suitability of the application for dumping permits should be relevant to Australian conditions.

This legislation will apply to all vessels, platforms and planes in Australian waters and to all Australian vessels and planes in any part of the sea. Of course the definition 'Australian waters' means territorial seas, that is, three miles seawards from a given base line. Dumping or incineration of certain substances is prohibited whilst the disposal of other toxic materials needs a special permit and disposal of all other types of material requires a general dumping permit. I think it is important that we get details of the prohibited list on the record. I ask for permission of the House for Annex I of the Convention, which bans dumping of substances such as mercury, cadmium and high level radioactive wastes into the sea, to be incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The Annex read as follows-
ANNEX I
1. Organohalogen compounds.
2. Mercury and mercury compounds.
3. Cadmium and cadmium compounds.

4. Persistent plastics and other persistent synthetic materials, for example, netting and ropes, which may float or may remain in suspension in the sea in such a manner as to interfere materially with fishing, navigation or other legitimate uses of the sea.
5. Crude oil, fuel oil, heavy diesel oil, and lubricating oils, hydraulic fluids, and any mixtures containing any of these, taken on board for the purpose of dumping.

6. High-level radio-active wastes or other high-level radio-active matter, defined on public health, biological or other grounds, by the competent international body in this field, at present the International Atomic Energy Agency, as unsuitable for dumping at sea.
7. Materials in whatever form (e.g. solids, liquids, semi-liquids, gases or in a living state) produced for biological and chemical warefare.
8. The preceding paragraphs of this Annex do not apply to substances which are rapidly rendered harmless by physical, chemical or biological processes in the sea provided they do not:
(i) make edible marine organisms unpalatable, or
(ii) endanger human health or that of domestic animals.
The consultative procedure provided for under Article XIV should be followed by a Party if there is doubt about the harmlessness of the substance.

9. This Annex does not apply to wastes or other materials (e.g. sewage sludges and dredged spoils) containing the matters referred to in paragraphs 1-5 above as trace contaminants. Such wastes shall be subject to the provisions of Annexes II and III as appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. A second list requiring special permits includes substances such as arsenic, lead, zinc and so on and low level radioactive wastes. I seek the leave of the House for Annex II to be incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
ANNEX II
The following substances and materials requiring special care are listed for the purposes of Article VI (1) (a).
A. Wastes containing significant amounts of the matters listed below:
arsenic
lead and their compounds
copper
zinc
organosilicon compounds
cyanides
fluorides
pesticides and their by-products not covered in Annex I.

B. In the issue of permits for the dumping of large quantities of acids and alkalis, consideration shall be given to the possible presence in such wastes of the substances listed in paragraph A and to the following additional substances:
beryllium
chromium and their compounds
nickel
vanadium
C. Containers, scrap metal and other bulky wastes liable to sink to the sea bottom which may present a serious obstacle to fishing or navigation.

D. Radio-active wastes or other radio-active matter not included in Annex I. In the issue of permits for the dumping of this matter, the Contracting Parties should take full account of the recommendations of the competent international body in this field, at present the International Atomic Energy Agency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. We applaud the total ban placed on toxic substances such as mercury and high level radioactive wastes but question whether Annex II is tight enough. The Convention referred to in this Bill allow the dumping into the sea of materials such as arsenic and low and medium level radioactive wastes. We do not and will not accept this practice.
—What about the black lace? Does that go with it? I like your coat.

—The honourable member does not know what this is all about. I can see by the look on his face that he would dump anything into the sea. The Convention referred to in this Bill allows the dumping into the sea of materials such as arsenic and low and medium level radioactive wastes. I repeat that we do not and will not accept this practice. There are two other main areas of concern. The Bill, as I will show, does not adequately cover dumping by other nations on our continental shelf. For the benefit of honourable members opposite, I mention that this will be a bit complicated when I get into it. Clause 9 provides for the States to pass mirror legislation if they so wish and to assume full responsibility for enforcing the laws of an international convention. This reflects just one more consequential inanity arising from the off-shore sellout legislation of May 1980 as amended last week, wherein the States rule the waves, and under them too for that matter, as far as the 3-mile limit or the territorial sea. We see this off-shore package not as a milestone in co-operative federalism but as a miserable hotch-potch involving increased and bigger government administration of every law concerning the continental shelf and any further laws the Federal Government may wish to enact. How many more Bills will it pass where it will invite the States to mirror the legislation? It is unnecessary, complicated big government from a Government that professes to be believers in smaller government.

SPEECH.PARA: I will now examine various clauses in this legislation and foreshadow some amendments to be moved in the Committee stage. Clause 3 repeals the Beaches, Fishing Grounds and Sea Routes Protection Act 1932-61 which allows for regulation of discharge of normal shipboard waste, a type of waste specifically not covered by the Convention and the legislation. The Government should now seek to control discharge of such wastes by other legislation. Clause 5 excludes coverage of disposal of wastes from off-shore mining.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am reluctant to interrupt the honourable gentleman, but it may be timely to remind him and the House for that matter that the second reading debate addresses itself to the principles of the Bill. Specific references to clauses should be made in Committee when each clause is before the Committee. Perhaps we can be jointly accommodated if the honourable member for Cunningham makes reference to the matters contained within the clauses but does not identify or refer to them in specific terms as clauses.
—What I was trying to do-
—Incorporate the whole lot. That way the speech will not be so long.

—If the honourable member opposite wants to stop here all night I will comply with exactly what he is saying and go through the whole business again clause by clause in the Committee stage. I am concerned at a situation which excludes coverage of the disposal of wastes from off-shore mining operations. Whilst the Petroleum (Submerged Lands-Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill and Minerals (Submerged Lands) Bill purport to have a common mining code there is no common environmental code between the States, and disposal of mining wastes may or may not be properly regulated. When the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act is proclaimed, part of the Fraser sell-out of the High Court decision for control over the territorial sea-
—Order! The honourable member will refer to the Prime Minister as such.

—I am sorry. Perhaps I should have said the Fraser Government sellout. When its control over territorial seas and waters falls to the States, the lack of precision and uniformity as applies to environmental assessment legislation on on-shore mining projects will be extended to cover mining on or under the sea floor. If this Federal Government is so keen to hand over its powers to the States it should at least ensure that the common mining code is extended to a common environmental code.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned also that the Bill allows for State legislation to be passed surrendering this Bill's jurisdiction over the States coastal waters. Such a situation will lead to eight pieces of legislation and the possibility of non-compliance by one of the States to the strict letter of the Convention. As I have noted, the Opposition feels that this situation will lead to unnecessary bureaucracy and should be scrapped. A number of clauses in the Bill describe offences under the Act and the penalties which can be levied for illegal dumping or incineration at sea. I wish specifically to refer to the matters raised in clauses 10 and 11. Clause 10 states:
Where, otherwise than in accordance with a permit, any wastes or other matter-
This is very pertinent and absolutely central to my contribution-
(a) are, or is, dumped into Australian waters from any vessel or aircraft; or
(b) are, or is, dumped into any part of the sea from any Australian vessel, Australian aircraft or Australian platform,
the owner and the person in charge of the vessel, aircraft or platform and the owner of the wastes or other matter are each guilty of an offence against this section.

The effect of clauses 10, 11, 12 and so on is to require foreign ships registered with nations which are signatory to the Convention to acquire a permit from the Australian designated authority to dump in Australian waters; that is, the territorial sea for 3 miles. But the Bill only requires those ships to obtain a permit from their own designated authority before dumping on the Australian continental shelf outside the 3-mile territorial sea. Similarly, because of what is set out in clauses 10 and 11, foreign ships-I think the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) will understand this-registered with nations not party to this Convention must, under the Convention rules, obtain an Australian permit to dump in our territorial sea. But, they are not under any control on the continental shelf outside the 3-mile zone. It is essential that all acts of dumping wastes into the waters of the Australian continental shelf are regulated by Australian law. There is adequate precedent for Australia to assert its jurisdiction over dumping above the continental shelf. In 1972 at the London dumping convention Australia and New Zealand issued a joint statement which, in part, said:

It is the understanding of Australia and New Zealand that this Convention in no way detracts from the rights of a coastal State to take action in areas under its jurisdiction, and in particular from the rights of the coastal State to take action for the purpose of protecting the resources of its continental shelf.

We have asserted our sovereign rights over the continental shelf and have declared the 200-mile wide fishing zone. Article VII (1) 1 (c) of the Convention was intended to provide for coastal state jurisdiction in a zone adjacent to the coast. At the time, agreement on the extent of this zone could not be reached but Article 13 in the Convention on the Law of the Sea referred to this point. Articles 210 (5) and 216 (1) (a) of the draft Law of the Sea Convention, recognise the right of a coastal State to control dumping in waters above its continental shelf. Article 210 (5) states:

Dumping within the territorial sea and the exclusive economic zone or onto the continental shelf shall not be carried out without the express prior approval of the coastal State, which has the right to permit, regulate and control such dumping after due consideration of the matter with other States which by reason of their geographical situation may be adversely affected thereby.
Article 216 (1) states:

Laws and regulations adopted in accordance with this Convention and applicable international rules and standards established through competent organisations or diplomatic conference for the prevention, reduction and control of pollution of the marine environment from dumping shall be enforced:
(a) by the coastal State with regard to dumping within its territorial sea or its exclusive economic zone or onto its continental shelf.

This is not a contentious issue. We have always argued strongly for this right. The delay in finalising the Law of the Sea Convention, directly attributable to the delaying tactics of the new United States Reagan Administration, should not prevent Australia from asserting jurisdiction over dumping on our continental shelf. It is a matter clearly consistent with the proposed Law of the Sea Convention as outlined in the articles I have read to this House. Only last week the Australian Government asserted this jurisdiction in making its regulations regarding the Capricornia section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. The regulations prohibit the disposal of wastes in the sea from ships without permission from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in the Capricornia section, both within and beyond the territorial sea. Clearly the Government needs to protect our fisheries as well as the seabed, which we claim to be Australia's, from pollution resulting from sea dumping. There is no justification for not asserting jurisdiction over all dumping on Australia's continental shelf.

The Government projects a curious inconsistency when implementing legislation to control pollution of the sea. Its recent Protection of the Sea (Discharge of Oil from Ships) Bill bans oil discharge within 50 miles from land and then limits discharges to 60 litres per mile. Yet, under last week's amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act, oil exploration and drilling will be allowed 30 miles from the Great Barrier Reef, and probably a lot closer if the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) has his way. Under this legislation the Government will allow foreign ships to discharge arsenic, zinc, radioactive wastes and so on onto our continental shelf. So long as it is further than 3 miles from Australian shores it can be done, in the case of non-signatory nations, without a permit from anyone and, in the case of fellow signatory nations, with a permit from their own designated authority. This Bill must be amended to extend Australian jurisdiction over all dumping at sea to the edge of our continental shelf.

I want now to refer to a provision in this Bill which deals with the dumping of radioactive materials into the sea. There should be no such sea dumping of nuclear wastes and the relevant clause should be replaced with another clause which prohibits sea dumping of low and medium level radioactive waste as if they were listed in the same category as those substances in Annex 1 of the Convention. The Australian Labor Party is opposed to the dumping of any radioactive material into the world's oceans. This Government had a chance to prohibit this but it is showing its true colours and looking to the day when it will bring nuclear power plants and enrichment plants to Australia and will be able to drop the consequent radioactive rubbish into the seas off Australia. Article IV sub-section 3 of the Convention on the prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter states:

No provision of this Convention is to be interpreted as preventing a Contracting Party from prohibiting, insofar as that Party is concerned, the dumping of wastes or other matter not mentioned in Annex 1. That party shall notify such measures to the Organisation.

So, what I propose in the amendments I am foreshadowing are entirely feasible and acceptable to all nations that are signatories to this Convention. At present, only high level radioactive wastes, usually those wastes which come from the reactor cone or from the reprocessing of spent fuel, are listed in Annex 1 and are prohibited from being dumped into the ocean. Are we to follow Japan's lead? Japan is preparing to dump 45,000 barrels of radioactive waste into the Pacific north of the Mariania Islands. American scientists claim deep ocean currents and migrating marine life could spread accumulated radioactivity to both Japan and Micronesia. Clearly Australia is taking this line in not opposing sea dumping of radioactive wastes. In a letter written in answer to my representation to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, the Minister stated that Australian officials talking to the Japanese mission which came to Australia to placate fears about the dumping of radioactive wastes into the Pacific advised the mission that 'Australia considered it essential that the disposal of nuclear waste in any environment, and in particular the Pacific Ocean, should be undertaken only in compliance with the strictest safety measures and in full accordance with the relevant international agreements on the subject'. The Minister's letter is in answer to my representations regarding opposition to the dumping of Japanese nuclear waste in the seas off the Mariania Islands, and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
MINISTER FOR HOME AFFAIRS AND ENVIRONMENT PARLIAMENT HOUSE CANBERRA, A.C.T. 2600
21 May 1981 Dear Mr West,

I refer to your personal representations of 6 February 1981 to the former Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, the Hon. R. J. Ellicott, Q.C., M.P., on behalf of the Wollongong City Council and the Environmental Heritage Committee of Wollongong, Shellharbour and Kiama concerning the dumping of radioactive waste in the Pacific Ocean. I take note of the views expressed.

The Australian Government has been informed that Japan intends to proceed on a trial basis with the dumping of low-level nuclear waste in the North Pacific in 1981. Japan has given certain assurances that the dumping operation will be carried out under stringent safety and environmental controls as laid down by relevant international agreements.

Australia has made it clear that it is opposed to the Pacific region becoming a dumping ground for the indiscriminate and uncontrolled disposal of nuclear waste. A Japanese technical mission, which visited South Pacific countries to explain Japan's proposed operation, held discussions with officials in Canberra during August 1980. It was during these discussions that Australia's views on the matter were made known to the Japanese. Officials advised the Japanese mission that Australia considered it essential that the disposal of nuclear waste in any environment, and in particular the Pacific Ocean, should be undertaken only in compliance with the strictest safety measures and in full accordance with the relevant international agreements on the subject. Australia has taken a position to this effect at meetings of the South Pacific Forum.
Yours sincerely, IAN WILSON Mr Stewart West, M.P.,
Member for Cunningham,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA, .A.C.T. 2600

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. For those honourable members who did not follow the information in the letter, it said that Australia feels it is all right for the Japanese to dump their wastes in the ocean. Of course, the Japanese have been inadvertently doing so, close to home, from their own nuclear reactor at Tsuruga. The United States of America has dumped radioactive cannisters in the north-east Pacific from California to the Hawaiian Islands and up to Canada, and is looking to the seabed as a permanent resting place for its decommissioned nuclear submarines. I ask all honourable members on the other side of the House to consider the implications of nuclear waste being dumped into the oceans of Australia. This legislation is not being amended to prohibit dumping of all nuclear wastes in the oceans. It may be that honourable members opposite will not be affected. But have no doubt that future generations will be affected and will pay the price of the negligence. There is as yet no solution to the permanent disposal of radioactive wastes. There may never be. Perhaps the solution is physically and scientifically impossible. The oceans, therefore, must not be used as an alternative dump.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition supports this legislation but will move amendments at the Committee stage to improve and strengthen the Bill. It is unacceptable for the Australian Government to propose legislation which will allow the dumping of radioactive wastes into the sea. People over the centuries have used the oceans of the world as a sink for their wastes and poisons. They are now realising that it is not a bottomless pit in which rubbish can be dumped without any ill effect. Over 3,500 million years ago the seas spawned the first living cell from which all life on earth-dinosaurs, mammals and, in the last mere 500,000 years, man himself-has evolved. In the last 50 to 100 years the seas have suffered more pollution directly attributable to human folly than they have suffered in all of the previous four billion years of their existence. The convention measures are supportable. But Australians and this House can give a further lead to the world by passing the Opposition amendments in the Committee stage of this Bill tonight.
Wednesday, 3 June 1981

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 4, page 2, lines 27 to 33, omit the definition of ''Australian waters'', substitute the following definition:
'' 'Australian waters' means-

(a) the territorial sea of Australia and any sea that is on the landward side of the territorial sea of Australia, other than any part of the sea that is within the limits of a State or of the Northern Territory; or
(b) the territorial sea of an external Territory and any sea that is on the landward side of that territorial sea,
and includes any area of sea that is declared by the regulations to be included in Australian waters for the purposes of this Act;''.

A new definition of 'Australian waters' is provided for in the legislation. The seaward side of the territorial sea of Australia or of an external territory may be declared by regulation to be Australian waters for the purposes of the Bill. I want to point out that some reference was made in the second reading debate to the fact that certain dumping could take place beyond the outer boundary of the territorial sea. Australian vessels and aircraft which might seek to dump in or over the sea anywhere in the world will come under the legislation. The legislation also controls out to the outer edge of the continental shelf the dumping from an Australian platform.

The legislation restricts the capacity of foreign vessels to dump and requires the operation of this legislation out to the outer boundary of the territorial sea. Some concern was expressed by the Opposition during the second reading stage of the Bill about the fact that foreign vessels could dump between the outer boundary of the territorial sea and the outer edge of the continental shelf. Firstly, I want to draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that the ships and aircraft of the 41 countries that are parties to the London dumping convention would not be permitted to dump in that area unless they had the permission of their own governments under legislation which complied with the convention. It is understood that under the present accepted international law, nations which are parties to the London dumping convention are required to legislate in the form of the Bill which is now before the Committee.

There could come a time when the circumstances will change and, as a result of very difficult negotiations, a new international law of the sea regime will operate. Recognising that circumstances may change, the Government proposes that a new definition be added to the Bill as originally introduced so that the Bill may be expanded by regulation to cover the dumping operations of foreign vessels and aircraft in the area between the outer edge of the territorial sea and the outer edge of the continental shelf. I am aware that the Opposition is proposing to move an amendment under which the legislation would cover right out to the outer edge of the continental shelf. I can indicate at this stage that the Government is not prepared to accept that amendment. However, it is responding to the concern that has been expressed by changing the definition in the Bill to enable adjustment to be made by regulation to extend at some later stage the operation of the legislation beyond the edge of the territorial sea in relation to foreign vessels and aircraft.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Dr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 4 deals with a number of definitions which clearly identify what this Bill applies to. Perhaps one of the most important of these is the description of the convention which Australia is implementing. We welcome the ratification of another international convention. This gives me the opportunity to make the criticism that one of the problems members of national parliaments have is keeping in touch with international conventions that have been ratified and implemented by their parliaments. The Executive Government holds such conventions pretty close to its collective chest. It is very difficult for us to know what response there has been to conventions, such as the one involved in this Bill, which are decided in international forums. One of the matters raised at a weekly meeting of an informal group of parliamentarians attending the United Nations, which I chaired, referred to conventions such as the one before us. Mention was made of the difficulties that members of national parliaments have in finding out what national governments were doing about conventions. Each year the United Nations produces an account of conventions which have been ratified and conventions which have yet to be ratified by various countries. The list is a long one. The delays in ratification of conventions are long. Yet parliamentary consciousness of their existence is abysmally low and public awareness is practically nil. I think executive governments have a responsibility to improve this situation.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the definitions in this clause illustrate some of the problems that my colleague the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) has outlined so well. The ships of countries not party to the Convention can dump substances prohibited by the Convention outside Australia's territorial sea. The Australian permit as it applies to foreign ships, whether their countries are party to the Convention or not, is necessary for dumping only in Australia's territorial waters. Further, included in the details is the permitting of the dumping of low level or medium level radioactive waste. One can query the adequacy of this provision and express concern at the possible concentration of such substances through the ecological chain, with adverse effects at the end of the chain or even earlier.

It has been necessary to define the types of enforcement and monitoring procedures that will operate. It is obvious from the definition of an inspector that, whilst clause 26 provides for persons to be appointed as inspectors, members of the police force will be used. We know that the extent of Australia's coastline and territorial seas causes many problems of inspection and monitoring in other areas such as drug smuggling and illegal immigration. My colleague the honourable member for St George (Mr Morrison) the other day raised the matter of defence. It is difficult to believe that the same sorts of problems will not arise here. I have no confidence that inspectors will be available in appropriate numbers or with appropriate facilities to enforce the proposals.

How will the permit which has to be granted operate? At the moment neither the Federal Government nor the State governments have effective information-gathering bodies giving a real picture of the volume or weight of the substances listed in Schedules 1 and 2 to this Bill; neither are their sources of production or storage details adequately known. We cannot provide adequately for the identification and disposal of substances on land in Australia, let alone at sea. What will the permit system involve? What will be its mechanics? What checking will there be? Will it be as simple to bypass the system as it is now to bypass the permit system for the disposal of hazardous wastes on land in the various States? We do not know how much has been done in regional efforts, which were referred to at the Stockholm Conference. Paragraph 86 (c) of the report of the Stockholm Conference refers to the need for regional efforts to bring all significant sources of pollution within the marine environment, including radioactive pollution from nuclear surface ships and submarines and, in particular, in enclosed and semi-enclosed seas, under appropriate controls. It recommends the complete elimination of deliberate pollution of oil from ships. We have dealt with that matter before. How much progress has been made with this Convention in the regional sense, or are we acting in isolation? What negotiations have there been with countries such as New Zealand, the various Pacific Island nations, Papua New Guinea, Indonesia, and so on? Has that task been effectively carried out?

In the same area, there should be national control over land-based sources of marine pollution, to which my colleague referred. Do we place too much emphasis on the fact that we are an island continent? Have we effectively checked land base sources or do they hold the possibility of a concentration in an ecological chain that I referred to previously? Earlier I referred to the problem of information about the source of production of toxic substances, their storage in Australia and the lack of effective and up to date data. Yet in Stockholm so many years ago this matter was referred to quite bluntly and clearly. I quote paragraph 87 of the Stockholm conference report, which states:
It is recommended that Governments:

Provide to the UN, FAO and UNCTAD, as appropriate to the data-gathering activities of each, statistics on the production and use of toxic or dangerous substances that are potential marine pollutants, especially if they are persistent; . . .

From an inquiry that the Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation is carrying out, it is obvious that the data on the source of production, the volumes, the weights and where they are stored, are thoroughly inadequate; just as the method of by-passing the permit system is so simple in any State. To talk about the permit system here without adequate provision being made for inspectors or for monitoring, will completely beg the question. If we are to be fair dinkum about it we also have to consider that part of the London dumping convention is included in this Bill. Schedule 1, Annex III, C, 4 states:
The practical availability of alternative land-based methods of treatment, disposal or elimination, or of treatment to render the matter less harmful for dumping at sea.

I want to ensure that this will not be forgotten. It would be tragic if the implementation of the Convention which this Bill carries out was to be used as a device to excuse the Australian Government from action along these lines. Yet what mechanism exists to carry it out? In the matter of waste disposal in Australia, the cry is predominantly: 'Land fill, land fill, land fill'. If the waste is the least bit unpleasant, the Government says it must be dumped out of sight. State governments cannot handle it. I remind honourable members of the controversy about using the Darghile forest as a toxic waste dump in Victoria, which was abandoned, and of the present public agitation over the toxic waste site suggested at Avalon.

Clause 9 (Declaration by Minister in relation to coastal waters of a State, et cetera).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes clause 9. I do not want to take up too much time on this because in my speech at the second reading stage, I outlined in a broad sense many of the reasons for these amendments. Obviously, the reason why clause 9 should go is that the Government has been foolish enough to betray our national heritage and to betray the historic decision of the High Court of Australia, which ruled that the Commonwealth had power over the seas and what lay beneath them from the low water mark to the edge of the continental shelf. It followed that the Government made that historic sell out deal with the State Premiers, culminating in the passing of that so-called off-shore package on 1 May last year. I am sorry to say that all State Premiers and governments collaborated against the High Court decision after 10 years of Australian Labor Party struggle on this matter. As a result of all that has transpired we have all the problems that now arise in Queensland in regard to the declaration of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. Mr Bjelke-Petersen and his Government can see that if they can only frustrate the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) about the declaration of the Park and the Cairns section, the Coastal Waters (State Powers) Act 1980 will be declared. It provides for possibly at least 3 miles out to sea for a given base line. At that time the Minister will be in all sorts of trouble because the State Government will continue to say that the boundary of the Marine Park ought to be at least 3 miles out to sea rather than the low water mark so it can have control of all the coast along Queensland and perhaps allow oil drilling there.

SPEECH.PARA: These are some of the problems that have arisen from that historic sellout of May Day 12 months ago. Just because the Government did that does not mean that every time legislation that has something to do with off-shore matters comes up in this House the Government has to continue this folly and say: 'Let us mirror the legislation now even though it is about the ratification of an international convention on dumping at sea'. Why the devil do we have to mirror that sort of thing which is clearly a national responsibility? Why do we say to the States: 'If you deal with the legislation we will get out of the area altogether and rely on you to police it'? The international convention of London on dumping at sea does not expect the Federal Government to say to the States: 'Here is the Bill. If you say you will police our international obligations we will get out of the area altogether and forget it'. That is not the position as it should be at all in regard to clause 9. Clause 9 should go. I urge the Government to vote for my amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Committee to the point that this is an historic Bill implementing an historic agreement which is a demonstration of co-operative federalism. It demonstrates that the States and the Commonwealth can reach an agreement to bring into operation a regime of law which protects coastal waters and enables the States to exercise control in certain ways subject to the terms of the agreement entered into. The control of marine pollution through dumping and the ratification of the London dumping convention has been the subject of detailed discussions with the States and the Northern Territory as part of the overall discussions on off-shore arrangements. In line with the general provisions of the off-shore constitutional settlement to give each State powers with respect to adjacent territorial sea it was agreed that the Commonwealth legislation would apply in respect of dumping outside the territorial sea and that it would also apply in respect of dumping inside the territorial sea if the State does not wish to legislate.

SPEECH.PARA: Time will tell whether any State or whether all States wish to legislate. If they wish to legislate their legislation will apply, but it will apply only so long as the legislation complies with the London dumping convention. What this Parliament is doing is legislating to cover all the seas from low water mark to the limits that we have discussed in earlier debate on this Bill. Clause 9 gives effect to the arrangements entered into between the Commonwealth and the States. It is for the States to determine whether, for their own purposes, they wish to legislate. Their legislation must comply with the conditions of the London dumping convention otherwise the Commonwealth legislation will be brought into effect again.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) a very simple and blunt question. There is a contradiction between international law and municipal law. I think the Committee ought to address itself to the following question: Irrespective of agreements between the States and the Commonwealth, is the Commonwealth in fact responsible for the implementation of the agreement in compliance with the London convention on dumping? I assume that it is, because international jurisdiction does not recognise States per se. It recognises a State in the sense of the Commonwealth of Australia. That is the conflict between the two sections of law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is recognised in international law that States in an international sense often have a Federal system of government. There is acceptance and understanding of the manner in which Federal clauses can be involved in the implementation of international conventions. Having said that, I emphasise that the Federal legislation will operate to comply with the London dumping convention and that legislation will be pushed back, as it were, only if the State legislation itself complies with that convention. Otherwise, the Commonwealth's legislation will move back to the low water mark, as it will do when this Bill first comes into operation.

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Clause 10, page 5, line 5, at the beginning of the clause insert 'Subject to section 22,'.
(3) Clause 10, page 5, lines 7 and 8, omit paragraph (a), substitute the following paragraph:

Clause 10, which is the key to all this, states:
Where, otherwise than in accordance with a permit, any wastes or other matter-
(a) are, or is, dumped into Australian waters from any vessel or aircraft; or
(b) are, or is, dumped into any part of the sea from any Australian vessel, Australian aircraft or Australian platform . . .

I move the amendments to this clause because the effects of the clause are abundantly clear. Even ships of foreign nations which are signatories to the Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of Wastes and Other Matter only need an Australian permit from our designated authority to dump in territorial waters, that is, within three miles from a base line. Once they get outside that area they only require a permit from their own designated authority. That means a ship from France, the United States of America or any other nation could dump, according to its own permit system, four or five miles off the Australian coast. The situation is even worse for ships registered in a port of a foreign nation that is not a signatory to this Convention because outside the 3-mile limit they do not need a permit from anyone. They can simply dump what they like.

This Government has, as I have said, a curious ambivalence when it comes to controlling our off-shore waters. It finds no contradiction at all in moving amendments to the Seas and Submerged Lands Act which claim one million square miles of territory in the Coral Sea to the outermost edge of the continental shelf, not for the purpose of preventing dumping at sea by foreign ships but for the purpose of issuing oil exploration permits and, if oil is found, drilling licences, and then we are told by the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) that he will protect the Great Barrier Reef by not giving a commitment to drill within 30 miles of it. Thanks for nothing! The point with regard to clause 10 is that we find no difficulties whatsoever in claiming the sea out to the continental shelf for fishing purposes, or oil drilling, but when it comes to asserting our national sovereignty as far as preventing the dumping of waste is concerned the Government is not interested.

I conclude by saying, as I outlined in the debate on the motion for the second reading of this Bill, that there is absolutely no contradiction in what I am proposing and what is proposed in the draft law of the sea. If it were not for the belligerence of the incoming Reagan Administration, which jammed up this draft at the last possible moment, as outlined by one of my colleagues the other day, perhaps we would already have a clause to back up my assertion that this Government ought to be claiming that this Convention law operates to the outermost edge of the continental shelf. I am fully aware that the Minister has foreshadowed an amendment to clause 41 that, in effect, picks up and accepts what I am saying. Later he will say that an amendment to clause 41 will set out that the Government can do in future by regulation exactly what I am proposing tonight when it suits its purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not true to say that the Government is not interested in this question of the responsibilities of foreign ships and aircraft beyond the outer boundary of the territorial sea. The amendment assumes that the draft law of the sea is the law of the sea. It is not yet the law of the sea and this legislation takes account of the international law as it is today. The main purpose of this Bill is to enable Australia to control marine pollution through dumping and incineration by giving effect to the London dumping convention. The intention of the Bill is not to assert to the maximum permissible degree the right of Australia to control dumping and incineration by foreign vessels beyond our territorial waters.

SPEECH.PARA: The assertion of such jurisdiction raises issues not directly connected with the convention but which relate to the larger question of coastal state jurisdiction over the sea and seabed and the current state of development of the Law of the Sea. Any assertion by Australia of dumping jurisdiction over foreign vessels beyond the territorial sea could be challenged at international law as the extent of the outer limits of the Australian continental shelf for the purposes of the 1958 convention on the continental shelf is not a matter that can be regarded as free from controversy. It should be noted that whilst the 1958 convention on the continental shelf recognises certain rights of coastal states over the continental shelf, namely the right to control the exploration and exploitation of the resources of the continental shelf, it expressly preserves the 'high seas' status of superjacent waters. It is a potentially controversial question whether and in what circumstances the exercise of a claimed high seas right by foreign vessels would be subject to control by the coastal state under the 1958 convention. It is therefore considered by the Government that the proposed amendments to the definition of 'Australian waters' provide a valid alternative to the amendments moved by the Opposition in that they foreshadow an assertion of dumping jurisdiction beyond the territorial sea and will allow the Government to move swiftly to extend the jurisdiction of the Bill to take account of future international developments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address myself to this clause but, by way of preface-I appreciate that it is late-one cannot emphasise too much the importance of the Environment Protection (Sea Dumping) Bill and the enormous threats that do exist to the environment, particularly as a result of the development of complex chemical substances, heavy metals and radioactive substances which many countries have not as yet found an effective way of disposing of. In those circumstances, as the honourable member for Scullin (Dr Jenkins) pointed out, where solutions simply do not exist-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 22, pages 13 and 14, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Radioactive wastes or other matter
22. (1) The dumping at sea of any radioactive wastes or other radioactive matter, being dumping to which this section applies, is prohibited.
(2) The incineration at sea of any radioactive wastes or other radioactive matter, being incineration to which this section applies, is prohibited.
(3) The loading of any radioactive wastes or other radioactive matter for the purpose of being dumped at sea or incinerated at sea, being loading to which this section applies, is prohibited.
(4) This section applies to dumping at sea and incineration at sea carried out from or by-
(a) any vessel, platform or aircraft in or into Australian waters or in or into the sea above the continental shelf of Australia or of an external Territory;
(b) any Australian vessel, Australian aircraft or Australian platform in or into any part of the sea.
(5) This section applies to loading on or onto
(a) any vessel, aircraft or platform in Australia or in Australian waters or in the sea above the continental shelf of Australia or of an external Territory;
(b) any Australian vessel, Australian aircraft or Australian platform in, or in the territorial sea, of a country that is not a party to the Convention.

(6) The owner and person in charge of the vessel, platform or aircraft on or from which loading, dumping at sea or incineration at sea in contravention of this section is carried out and the owner of the wastes or other matter so loaded, dumped or incinerated are each guilty of an offence against this section, punishable on conviction by a fine not exceeding
(a) if the person is a natural person- $50,000; or
(b) if the person is a body corporate- $100,000.

I have already drawn attention to the problems that have arisen from clauses 10, 11 and 12 regarding signatory nations needing only their own permits to dump radioactive materials within three miles of our shores and the fact that under this legislation non-signatory nations do not require any permits at all to dump within three miles of our shores. It is obvious then that, in the case of signatory nations, low level radioactive wastes could be dumped under their permits within four miles of our shores. Non-signatory nations could dump anything, including high level radioactive waste, within four miles of our shores. Japan is obviously a signatory nation, yet it has already indicated that it will dump 45,000 drums of low level or medium level radioactive waste in the Pacific Ocean. I am absolutely amazed that the Government will not accept my amendment, considering the actions that are going forward.

I say to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Wilson) that I am amazed that the Government has not firmly told the Japanese Government that Australia will not stand by and accept that it is Japan's right to dump radioactive wastes of any sort in the ocean. Of all the nations, one would expect Japan to have some extra sensitivity in this matter. When the Minister was asked questions about the Government's attitude to the Japanese proposal for dumping off the Mariani Islands he said, and I will read from a letter which I advise all honourable members to read in Hansard tomorrow because it was incorporated in my speech on the second reading of the Bill:

Officials advised the Japanese mission that Australia considered it essential that the disposal of nuclear waste in any environment, and in particular the Pacific Ocean, should be undertaken only in compliance with the strictest safety measures and in full accordance with the relevant international agreements on the subject. Australia has taken a position to this effect at meetings of the South Pacific Forum.

The Government has given the Japanese a virtual carte-blanche to dump the stuff by not telling it firmly that we disapprove of the dumping. There is no safe method known to science for the disposal of nuclear wastes. I might add that plutonium, which is a derivative of high level radioactive waste from spent uranium oxide, can exist and be harmful to man for up to half a million years. There is no way we can get around that. There is no way we can get around the fact that no nation has yet been able to decommission a nuclear power station. A period of 100 years has to elapse before the core of these stations can be touched. In the United States nobody has yet been successful in cleaning up the results of the Harrisburg disaster. When they finally get around to cleaning it up, it will cost at least $2 billion. They cannot work out who should be responsible for cleaning it up and who should pay the price. How can we be sure that nuclear nations, committed to nuclear power stations because of the inability of their scientists to work out a way to dispose of nuclear waste, will never dump waste, even of a high level into the ocean? At the very least, Australia should declare that in no circumstances will we ever dump radioactive waste into the seas anywhere and that those nations which will not comply with that declaration will be prevented from disposing of such waste on our continental shelf.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WILSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —The London dumping convention prohibits the disposal of high level radioactive material listed in Annexe I of the convention and places strict controls on the disposal of other radioactive material listed in Annexe II of the convention. This Bill gives effect to these provisions. The effect can be seen in clauses 19 (2) and 19 (5) together with the first Schedule to the Bill. In the issue of permits for the disposal of radioactive material not listed in Annexe I, the convention contracting parties are to take full account of stringent guidelines developed by the International Atomic Energy Agency which is the recognised international authority in this field. Clause 19 (6) (a) of the Bill specifically provides for consideration of these guidelines. These provisions in the Bill indicate Australia's willingness to comply with the strictest international measures laid down for the control of sea dumping of radioactive materials. In view of that fact and the fact that this Bill aims to enable Australia to comply with the London dumping convention, the amendment just moved by the Opposition is not acceptable to the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment to clause 22 of the Bill, as proposed by the Opposition, suggests a course of action which only a completely irresponsible government would reject. I therefore hope that Government members in this House are not just conscientious enough but also are realistic enough to see that to allow the dumping of radioactive matter as close as three miles off the Australian coastline is entirely against the national interest and, in fact, could have disastrous effects on us all. The existing clause 22, as proposed by the Government, gives the Minister the power to issue a permit for dumping or loading radioactive matter, stating special conditions to be adhered to if he deems the matter to be 'so radioactive as to require special precautions to be taken'.

SPEECH.PARA: Question (by Mr Bourchier) put:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put:
That the clause proposed to be omitted (Mr West's amendment) stand part of the Bill.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: The Deputy Chairman-Mr G. O'H. Giles

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 23 to 28-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 29 (Boarding of vessels, &c., by inspectors).
Amendments (by Mr West)-by leave- proposed:
Clause 29, page 16, line 11, at the end of paragraph (c) of sub-clause (1) add 'or in the sea above the continental shelf of Australia or of an external Territory'.
Clause 29, page 16, line 28, after 'waters' insert 'or in the sea above the continental shelf of Australia or of an external Territory'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This clause highlights, as do the other clauses we have been dealing with, the complete inadequacy of this Bill to protect the people of Australia. The Bill allows the dumping of low and medium level radioactive wastes in waters within three miles of the Australian coast. This Parliament should be legislating to make dumping of such waste by persons from any country in Australian coastal waters an offence.

—Order! I cannot hear what the honourable member for Lilley is saying. However, I have doubts about whether she is referring to the amendment. I invite her to get quickly on to it, considering the hour.
—I feel that this is so important to the Australian people that it should be considered even at this late hour.
—The honourable member will not raise matters unless they are related to the amendment, or I will have to rule her out of order.

—I point out that the proposed amendment was in keeping with the Convention for the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping of wastes and other matter, to which Australia is a signatory, along with 44 other nations. Article IV, paragraph 3 of that Convention states:

SPEECH.PARA: No provision of this Convention is to be interpreted as preventing a Contracting Party from prohibiting, insofar as that Party is concerned, the dumping of wastes or other matter not mentioned in Annex 1.

The article allows countries to prohibit the dumping of substances as long as the organisation is notified of such prohibitions. The prohibition of sea dumping of nuclear matter is of particular importance to me, as a Queenslander. The unique reef off the east coast of Queensland must be protected. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park (Capricornia Section) Regulations make dumping of wastes from a vessel or an aircraft, an island or fixed structure within the Capricornia section an offence. Under the Act, dumping of waste by Australians is regulated, but not that of foreign countries.

As the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr West) has pointed out the reef should be protected to the extent of the continental shelf, but it is of even greater importance that people be protected. Protection should be given to all Australian coastal waters. The radioactive pollution of Australian waters has horrific implications for us and for future generations. The probability of such pollution should not be underrated. The Queensland Premier, for one, is feverishly in favour of the extension of the uranium industry in Queensland but his enthusiasm goes beyond the bounds of reason. His determination to proceed with the project, despite the decision by a mining warden's court to disallow expansion of a uranium mining project in Townsville for safety reasons, typifies the situations which could arise in Queensland coastal waters. The Charters Towers mining warden, Mr Eric Lendich, made his decision because of 'grave doubts as to the suitability and safety of proposals by the French company Minatome, for a treatment plant, evaporation ponds and tailing ponds'. In relation to the Premier's response to the warden's decision, I quote from the Hobart Mercury of 28 April 1981. It states:
The Queensland Premier, Mr Joh Bjelke-Petersen-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Lilley will resume her seat. I am afraid I have to rule that she is debating matters which come under clause 22. I can see the relevance she is trying to establish by talking of vessels, but she is not really referring to the inspection and boarding of vessels, which as I understand it is the subject of clause 29.

—I believe it is all closely related. I have been misinterpreted by some honourable members opposite. I draw attention to the fact that there is cause for concern when we are dealing with the dumping of nuclear waste. In trying to establish that that cause is justified I have been quoting statements by the Queensland Premier which show that leakage can occur, and has occurred, from nuclear waste quite close to the coastal waters of Queensland. It is quite credible that in the future, if we allow dumping within three miles of the coast, such leakages could take place in coastal waters. As a matter of fact, in the National Times of 17 May to 23 May, there is a lead article headed 'Uranium Spill Threatens Town'. It discusses a leak which was discovered when a concrete seal covering a uranium ore stockpile--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I will have to ask the honourable member to resume her seat. She is referring directly to clause 22.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs and Environment)

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 29, page 16, add at the end of sub-clause (4) 'to which it is safe and practicable to bring the vessel '.
Clause 29, page 17, line 16, omit '$1,000', substitute '$2,000'.

These amendments have arisen from consultations with the States. The Premier of Tasmania drew to the attention of the Government the fact that the clause, as presently drawn, may require an inspector directing a ship to enter a port to enter the nearest port. The purpose of the first amendment is to cover the possibility that travel to the nearest port by a vessel may be unsafe and impracticable. It would enable a direction to be given that the ship go to the nearest safe or practicable port. The second amendment is technical in nature and increases from $1,000 to $2,000 penalty which may be imposed.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 41, page 21, add at the end thereof the following sub-clause: '(2) Regulations under sub-section (1) may declare that a specified area of sea on the seaward side of the territorial sea of Australia or the territorial sea of an external Territory is included in Australian waters for the purposes of this Act.'.
The issues that are involved in this amendment have been discussed in relation to earlier amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Mr S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition agrees to this amendment, but I wish to put on record that I regard it as a direct consequence of the amendment that was moved by the Opposition to clause 10, which sought to extend the application of the powers established under this legislation to the outermost edge of the continental shelf. We now see what the Government is about. Having accepted the relevance and validity of our argument, it is now saying that it may want to do this at some future point by way of regulation. We would have much preferred that the Government accept our proposed course of action, but will not oppose the amendment. We will merely regard it as a victory for the Opposition.
