PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Wilson)-by leave-read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: COMMONWEALTH LEGAL AID COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Mr Viner:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition opposes this Bill. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst not declining to give this Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that-

(1) the Commonwealth has a continuing national responsibility for the funding of legal aid, the States having amply demonstrated in the past that they have neither the resources nor the inclination to ensure equal access to the law;
(2) the Commonwealth has an indispensable national role in the formulation of legal aid policy so as to ensure that legal services are delivered on a co-ordinated, rational and equitable basis;
(3) the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission has a central national role to play in research, evaluating, advising upon, co-ordinating and monitoring the funding and delivery of legal aid services;

(4) the present functions of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission cannot be performed as adequately or effectively by a part time advisory Council and an Attorney-General's Department already subject to severe staffing constraints, and

(5) the proposals to abolish the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission, to curtail the functions and limit the independence of its successor advisory Council and to limit the number of full time officials working on legal aid policy and funding, are all to be deplored as marking the first step towards the Commonwealth's ultimate abandonment of responsibility for legal aid funding'.

The Opposition has set out in the five paragraphs of the amendment why it suggests that this Bill should be opposed. The purpose of the Bill is to abolish the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission and to create another body called the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council. Honourable members will notice in the preamble to the Bill a proposal to transfer Commonwealth employees. In other words, Commonwealth employees will be made redundant or transferred. This brings us to the point of what the Bill is all about. This is one of the first of the package of Bills which has resulted from the recommendations of what is known as the Lynch committee. That committee is anxious to cut costs and it proposes to do so in a most stupid and ineffective way. It is proposed to transfer people from-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a harsh statement.

—I know that the hour is late and that honourable members are a bit tired. But all the Government is doing is transferring unfortunate officers out to some other jurisdiction where I think they would still be paid. One wonders how the razor gang can justify this cost cutting without any idea or analysis of what it is about from the point of view of Commonwealth programs or State programs. If these people are to be transferred to some other area someone else has to bear the burden either in another area of Commonwealth responsibility or another area of State responsibility. It is really unsound to suggest that the legislation is doing anything at all. I remind the House that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) made a promise in 1975 that no person would be denied legal aid because of lack of means. This is another example of the Prime Minister's again reneging on a promise.
—Don't tell me he broke a promise!

—Oh, he has broken many of them. There are many problems in legal aid in Australia, particularly in Victoria and Tasmania. We see the complete abandonment of Commonwealth involvement. There is a view that the Commonwealth getting out of legal aid would not affect the Australian people. We should bear in mind that very many people are affected by Commonwealth laws. Many people are obliged to go to litigation or to courts because of Commonwealth legislation. We recognise that in a number of areas, particularly in administrative law. We have had to set up a number of tribunals to assist people, even in the welfare field. Now, in the really difficult area of what one would call adversery legislation, many people will be denied any help at all.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also significant that the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission, which was created by the Government, is now being abolished by it. In introducing legislation in 1977 Attorney-General Ellicott said that the Bill was an important part of the framework within which the partnership between the Australian and State governments would be conducted. So much for the partnership! We are now abolishing the Commission. It is clear that no partnership will exist any longer. Again, it would appear that the Government objects to the fact that the Commission was doing effective work and was able to prove it was dynamic. Sir John Nimmo was critical of Commonwealth funding and I suppose that might well have caused the demise of this Commission. In 1978-79 he said:

Since the change in the Federal Government in December 1975 we have seen a 'freeze' in the provision of federal legal aid through the Australian Legal Aid Office while the Government negotiated with the States for the introduction of its new comprehensive scheme. The 'freeze' has been marked, on the one hand, by the imposition of restrictive staff ceilings, and, on the other hand, by failure to adjust or index the monetary commitment limit for referrals to private practitioners to take account of inflation. The commitment limit was fixed at $12m per annum in August 1975. Since then, there has only been one minor increase-to $12.6m-in 1977-78.

A distinction needs to be drawn between the annual monetary commitment limit for referrals and the annual provision in the Budget for expenditure on payment of accounts for referrals completed. Expenditure inevitably increases each year because of the time lag between commitment and expenditure and because of cost increases after the referrals are made. However, the resulting annual increases in expenditure are not a measure of the real level of legal aid which is governed by the annual commitment limit.

In other words, what has been happening for years is that the commitment has been limiting the amount of legal aid but has not been able to cope with the arrears that have had to be met because of the actual taking up of cases. Whilst the commitment was limited to, say, $12m per annum, the Government was actually spending some $16.6m in the Budget merely to pick up arrears and not to provide any additional legal aid.

The Commission also complained of the serious rundown in the provision of federal legal aid and recommended the expenditure of $500,000 on voluntary and community legal aid services. Yet only half that amount has been provided in 1981, two years after the Commission recommended that $500,000 ought to be spent. It is important that we look at what was admitted in the Senate by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack)-that the work of the Commission has been a great credit to it. The Commission has been anxious to expand its role, but the Government as never allowed it to do so. In 1977 the Opposition opposed some aspects of the Legal Aid Commission Act. We wanted to see a truly independent Commission along the lines recommended by Professor Sackville in his report 'Law and Poverty'. We wanted to see the Commission having independent powers of report and review in all areas affecting legal aid. Nevertheless, it can be said that the Commission, at least in its first 2 1/2 years, did some splendid work. Honourable members will notice from Hansard that in the debate in the Senate, to which I can advert here, a summary of the major activities of the Commission was incorporated. The Attorney-General recognised the value of that document.

Amongst the areas of activity and research that were being conducted by the Commission were such matters as the evaluation of criteria for accepting and rejecting legal aid applications and ascertaining what should happen to people whose applications were rejected. The Commission was making interstate cost comparisons to determine which jurisdictions, for example, had the cheapest and most expensive cost structures in the area of family law. That was a most important matter, as the majority of federal legal aid moneys are expended in the area of family law. The Joint Committee on Family Law has drawn attention to the need to achieve similar and less costly procedures in family law. It would be an absurdity if a rationalisation did not occur because of the stupidity of the Government in dismantling the process where it might adversely affect private practitioners. The same is also true of the cost comparison between private and salaried lawyers which has been conducted.

On all the studies available-they are not entirely adequate-it is suggested that the use of salaried lawyers is two or three times less expensive than the use of private practitioners. However, we have a government that is very generous to some private practitioners. Need I remind honourable members of what is called the Greek security fraud case in which one private practitioner is in receipt of $1,070 a day? The cost of that case has run into millions of dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is his name?

—I need not quote it. Substantial sums of money were paid to a Queen's Counsel to assist the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. We now find, quite extraordinarily, that the same gentleman is appearing for a private party in an appeal before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal against the decision of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. Some strange decisions have benefited people in this regard. A decision has been made to divert more work from the Crown Solicitor's Office to the private sector. I recall the views in the Press that the members of the Lynch committee would act with razors in their hands. When we consider this measure, they might as well be handing over bank notes to the people who will get the benefit of the private work. It will have to be paid for. This is outrageous. A decision was also made to contract out bankruptcy work to the private sector. When talking about people in need of legal aid one would have thought that at least bankruptcy work could have been financed. Instead, the work will be given to the private sector, and I believe the costs will be substantially increased rather than reduced. In many cases accountants have acted against the interests of creditors. There are plenty of precedents to show that the private sector may not necessarily be interested all the time in the problems of the people we have to represent. It will be a regressive step if reviews which have been conducted by the Legal Aid Commission are now abandoned. It will add to costs. It is not as though the Government were against reviews in general. Never in the history of federation have so many reviews been announced as were announced in the report of the Lynch Committee. Some 35 individual reviews are involved in that report.

SPEECH.PARA: The functions of the new Council which will replace the old Commission are even more limited. For example, despite the abandonment by the Government of commercials which led to 90 per cent of the Australian people supporting the Australian Legal Aid Office, the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission did a considerable job publicising its activities and it published a national bibliography of legal aid materials. I suggest that if the Government wishes to rationalise costs it look less to abandoning publicity programs such as those which only inform people of their rights and think more about abandoning the costly Government Information Unit, which is no more than an insidious outlet for Government propaganda. The new Council will not have an advisory function in respect of funding and an effectiveness as the State legal aid commissions do. The research function of the old Commission is to be abandoned, and that is where a considerable amount of valuable work was done. The new Council is virtually an automaton of the Attorney-General. Membership of the Council is to be considerably different from that of the Commission. No longer are State Attorneys able to nominate members. No longer is the Australian Council of Social Service able to nominate a representative in its own right. What we now have is a fairly meaningless process for consultation to which the Attorney-General need not pay any attention whatsoever.

When questioned about the situation in Victoria, where there is an average shortfall between applications and approvals of around 600 cases a month, the Attorney-General stated that no one was being denied legal aid but the granting of it may be delayed. The number of cases undertaken by each member of staff of the Australian Legal Aid Office in Victoria is approximately double that in New South Wales. When the Victorian legal aid commission takes over it appears imposible that it will not have a serious backlog of cases, despite the protestations of the Federal Attorney-General to the contrary. Certainly, Mr Storey, the Victorian Attorney-General, believes that it will have such a backlog. The Attorney-General said that $450,000 would be saved by the abolition of the Commission and the creation of the Council. In view of the fact that only $700,000 was spent on the Commision, that seems an unusual claim. Some of the staff of the Commission are to be placed in the Attorney-General's Department and others elsewhere in the Public Service. Accordingly, it is very difficult to see how there could be a saving of $450,000 in realistic terms.

It is also a measure of the paralysis of the legislative process over the past two months that legislation that is so ineptly drafted and, I think, unable to be interpreted is being introduced. A question was asked in the Senate about what proposed new sections 5 (b) (i) and 5 (b) (ii) mean. The Attorney-General himself could not even answer the question. It comes to this extraordinary situation of trying to determine, under this proposed new section, the advice to be given and the recommendations to be made concerning:
(i) the provision by the Commonwealth of financial assistance in respect of the cost of providing legal assistance; and
(ii) the effectiveness of arrangements for the application of financial assistance provided by the Commonwealth in respect of the costs of providing legal assistance;

That shows the difficulties that occur at times because not enough attention has been given to the needs of the people in this area and to the matter of drafting. The Opposition has had assurances in the past that these matters may be only transitory and that there are alternatives. All the assurances we have had have been worthless, whether they apply to pensioners, students or anybody else who is in need. The Lynch committee is about ideas for limiting government and nothing else. It has limited vision, limited horizons and limited capacity to understand the problems of people. For that reason we reject this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this late hour I do not particularly wish to detain the Committee. This matter was very fully debated in the other place and many of the matters raised by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen), of course, were canvassed in considerable detail in that debate. I wish to stress some of the matters the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) raised in his address. He made it clear that the Government had no intention of reducing its commitment to the level of legal aid and the commitments it has made in agreements to the States to maintain the effectiveness of legal aid. I think that is the most important statement he could have made and it is an important aspect of this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney made the point-I reiterate it-that the cost of the administration of the Commonwealth Legal Aid Council is significant and that the reduction of its administration and the incorporation of some of the officers from the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission into the Attorney-General's Department gives greater scope through reduced expenditure to the Government better ordering its priorities. No doubt some of those resources might well find their way into legal aid as well as reduce government expenditure overall. I think that is the important part that has to be noted in relation to this initiative. Having said those few remarks, I will conclude at this point in time.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Lionel Bowen's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Fife) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Mr Moore:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, the purpose of this Bill-and I am going to stay here until the end of my speech-is to validate the collection of customs duties until 31 December 1981 in respect of tariffs imposed on imports of silicone products and wheelchairs. Each of these industries is relatively small, the silicone industry having about 110 employees in Australia and the wheelchair industry having about 55 employees. However, for quite different reasons, these are very important industries and the assistance arrangements afforded to them by the Government will have an important impact on particular sections of the community. Because the Government is mismanaging the affairs of this House so that we have to debate this Bill at 1.45 in the morning is no reason why I am not going to talk on this Bill. The silicone industry is a branch of the chemical industry, and involves high technologies which have had rapidly increasing application since the Second World War. I warn Government members that I have an amendment on this Bill and it is in their best interests that they stay here until the death to vote on it.

SPEECH.PARA: The industry is characterised by large scale, integrated production processes, and as is common in these circumstances, major multinational corporations dominate the industry. Australian production began in 1966 and 70 per cent of production occurs at Dow Corning's plant. The value of production has rapidly grown in the face of expanding demand for products based on silicones such as sealants, greases, adhesives and resins. The industry is now principally supplied by local producers, and export sales have become increasingly important. I am delighted that the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Les Johnson) is wide awake at this early hour of the morning and noting how interesting this speech is. The companies involved have become quite export conscious, and rapid growth in sales to South East Asian countries is expected. The Industries Assistance Commission recommended that a duty of 10 per cent apply for the intermediate and finished silicone products, and minimum duties of 2 per cent apply to raw materials. These rates significantly reduce the nominal levels of assistance afforded to the industry. However, because the cost of raw materials will fall, the effective rates of assistance for many of the products will remain similar to current levels. The Opposition has no objection to these decisions.

The second matter dealt with by this Bill relates to tariff assistance for producers of wheelchairs in Australia. Tariff Proposal No. 7 of 1980, which is validated by this Bill, provides for a duty rate to be applied to imports of wheelchairs of 30 per cent for one year, 25 per cent in the following year, and 20 per cent thereafter. Prior to these changes the rate applicable to mechanically propelled wheelchairs was 34 per cent and 36 per cent for manually operated wheelchairs. These high rates increased the cost of wheelchairs by up to $300. They applied from 1 January 1980, before which time the rate was only 15 per cent on imports from the United Kingdom, a significant source of supply. I repeat the facts. On 1 January 1980 the rate of duty and thus the cost of wheelchairs went up because of an action of the Government in getting rid of the United Kingdom preferences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do they hate invalids?
—Exactly. Why does the Government hate invalids? Why on earth would it allow the cost of wheelchairs to go up, as the honourable member for Hindmarsh has pointed out?
—It is the Year of Disabled Persons on top of it.

—Exactly, in the Year of Disabled Persons. The majority of wheelchairs sold in Australia are imported. It is quite incredible that a Customs duty of 34.36 per cent should have been applied to those imports, to the disadvantage of the disabled, for the past 16 months. After extraordinary delays, the Government has decided to reduce the duties, but they will still be a high 30 per cent for one year, and the ultimate rate of 20 per cent will still be higher than the rate applying to many imports of wheelchairs before 1 January 1980. It is not possible for the Government to excuse its delays in making this decision. The IAC, as requested, forwarded the final report to the Government on 23 December 1980, about five months ago. This delay, I repeat, is inexcusable. How does the Government excuse the decision to maintain high tariff duties on wheelchairs, particularly as this is the Year of Disabled Persons. In the IAC draft report, a minority of commissioners preferred the payment of a bounty for local producers. This proposal is very sensible.
—It pays a bounty on tractors. Why not on wheelchairs?

—As the honourable member for Corio says, bounties are paid on tractors, and sensibly bounties are paid on many other products. Why should they not be paid on wheelchairs? The industry provides only a minority share of the market and employs only 55 people. A bounty would not be expensive, but it would greatly benefit the disadvantaged people who must use wheelchairs. However, the Government announced in the 1980 Budget that it would introduce a program of aids for the disabled. The scheme was intended to commence on 1 April this year and $700,000 was allocated to it. But the plain fact is that the scheme has not been implemented, and it is not likely to be implemented for some time to come. That is a measure of this Government's lack of concern for the disadvantaged in our society. It is also a measure of its lack of commitment to the objectives of the International Year of Disabled Persons. Every member of the Australian community also knows that it is a typical example of what happens when this Government makes a promise. Having failed to implement the program of aids to daily living for the disabled, the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) had the temerity in his second reading speech to refer to the program on apparent justification of the decision to retain high rates of duty.

SPEECH.PARA: It is inexcusable for this Government to commence a new regime of tariff duties on one date while breaking its promises in relation to offsetting assistance. Indeed, we have been given no new commencement date for the aids program of $700,000 promised to the community in this Year of Disabled Persons. In the intervening period, about 500 wheelchairs are sold every month at an inflated cost because of the high rate of duties. It is not merely this delay that should concern us. The Government has not indicated who will be eligible for assistance under the aids program. The program relates not only to wheelchairs but also to a wide range of other aids to daily living.

The Government allocated $700,000 for a three-month period. This implies an annual cost of $2.8m. Yet annual sales of wheelchairs exceed $4m. So there is no way in the wide world, that that particular program would offset the cost of wheelchairs to those poor unfortunate people who are obliged to use that form of transport. It is virtually certain, therefore, that the tariff duties on wheelchairs will have to be paid by many disabled persons, even if the aid program is introduced. This is quite scandalous.

The Government should be condemned for its pathetic efforts in relation to the disabled. It makes promises during election campaigns and then breaks or delays them immediately after the election. The only further promise that the disabled in our community should seek from the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) is his promise to resign. The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs should be ashamed to have the carriage of a Bill such as this which maintains high rates of duty on wheelchairs. Not only should he be ashamed but also he should ensure that something is done very soon to alter the present situation. So that we may focus on this situation more clearly, I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst not opposing this Bill, the House-
(1) expresses its concern that the Customs duties validated by the Bill in relation to wheelchairs will maintain the high cost of these necessary aids for the disabled;

(2) calls upon the Government immediately to review its decision in relation to wheelchairs with a view to replacing the tariff arrangements provided in the Bill with a bounty scheme for local producers, and
(3) condemns the Government for its failure to implement its promise for a Programme of Aids for Disabled People including the free provision of wheelchairs'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Child Mrs J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) as I believe a bounty would be in the best interests of disabled people. On April 29 I brought this matter before the Parliament and asked the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to waive all duty on wheelchairs, both in justice and as a gesture from the Government towards the International Year of Disabled Persons. The Treasurer came into the House to say that he appreciated my concern and would certainly discuss the matter with the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) and with the Cabinet because he agreed that there was some justice in what I had to say.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not really call it justice when the Commonwealth Government announced that tariffs will remain on wheelchairs. Disabled people are currently paying a tariff of 34 per cent on imported electric wheelchairs. Thirty-four per cent is equivalent to approximately $1,000 a chair. This is an enourmous burden to place on people who are already disadvantaged through disability. On top of the cost of $3,000 for an electric wheelchair, it costs a disabled person $20 to $30 a week to maintain it. An electric wheelchair in constant use lasts for only a few years. The Government has indicated that the tariff will reduce to 20 per cent over two years, but it would still be 5 per cent higher than the tariff which existed prior to 1 January 1980.

I think the two basic convictions on which the Government should approach this matter, are firstly, that the needs of the wheelchair user are of basic importance, as a wheelchair is a necessary utility, not a luxury, to many disabled people and, secondly, that the existence of a viable Australian wheelchair manufacturing industry is necessary to supply both standard and non-standard units to cater for specific disabilities, because many of the wheelchairs are tailored to the disability a person has and to provide an efficient maintenance and parts supply service. We must maintain our own industry. In doing this a bounty would be much more beneficial to the end user and would provide greater assistance and more likelihood of the preservation of a viable local industry.

Wheelchair users are a special group of consumers. It would not be appropriate for them to have to bear the cost of protecting the local industry themselves. Again, I stress that wheelchairs are a necessity, not a luxury. The information available on the economic circumstances of the disabled seems to indicate that as a group they are financially disadvantaged because of the expenses incurred through their disability. It appears that most have reduced ability to earn a normal income. Some people may well ask why wheelchair users, as distinct from other disabled people, should receive preferential treatment from the Government. This group, because of its particular type of disability, often requires much more assistance in everyday living than other disabled people.

In addition to the general maintenance costs involved in owning a wheelchair-that is, for wheel replacements, brake adjustments and seat repairs-those confined to a wheelchair often require assistance in bathing, dressing, movement to and from the wheelchair and mobility outside their home. If no family member is available to do these things nursing attendants must be employed. All this costs money and the money comes out of the pockets of the disabled. Yet they are expected to pay this heavy duty on imported wheelchairs. Assistance is also required for house and garden maintenance for those not living in institutions. This type of assistance is not a luxury; it is a necessity if the wheelchair-bound are to live in our society and make a contribution to it. If payment of a bountry is good enough to help farmers to buy tractors and superphosphate, it is good enough to help the disabled to buy wheelchairs.

The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) and the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) indicated that disabled people would be able to obtain wheelchairs through the aids scheme which was announced in August 1980. We keep getting this red herring dragged across. The aids scheme was announced in August of last year. Nine months have passed and not one disabled person has received an aid. Disabled people are asking the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) and the State Health Ministers what they are doing with the money. In nine months not one aid has been prescribed. Unless action occurs immediately disabled people will lost $700,000 worth of aids. The Government obviously does not understand the problems faced by disabled people in obtaining aids for daily living. The decision made on the tariff issue ignores the fact that there was a thriving industry in Australia when the tariff was only 15 per cent. I am appalled that after nine months disabled people still have not received their aids and appliances. I am very disappointed at what the Government has brought down. I asked for better from the Treasuer and expected it, which perhaps was a bit naive of me. I totally support the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Adelaide-which is supported by every member on this side of the chamber-who really does believe that disabled people have a right to live in this community and should be subsidised to give them that right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise at this late hour to speak in support of the proposed amendment because of the importance of this amendment to the handicapped people in Australia, and to point out-to emphasise further-the hypocritical attitude of this Government. On the one hand it is espousing the cause of the disabled in this the International Year of Disabled Persons but, on the other, it is bringing about legislation which will cause severe hardship to users of wheelchairs in Australia. I believe most Australians will be appalled by this callous decision. Currently the tariff on an imported electric wheelchair is 34 per cent, or about $1,000. We should all remember the importance of this equipment to a disabled person. The wheelchair is his or her only source of mobility. In many cases the wheelchair is a life-line which allows a disabled person to participate in a normal lifestyle, to gain employment, to attend social functions and generally to enjoy life's opportunities as much as possible. That is what will be taken from the handicapped people in Australia by the Customs Tariff Validation Bill which is before the House tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: Electric wheelchairs, in particular, are vital to those people unfortunate enough to suffer debilitating diseases, especially multiple sclerosis and other such diseases. These people rely upon electric wheelchairs as they do not have sufficient muscular strength to operate ordinary wheelchairs. These people are already seriously disadvantaged by their disability. Yet this Government wishes to add an enormous financial burden as well. The cost of an electric wheelchair is about $3,000 and a further $20 to $30 a week is required for maintenance. A wheelchair in constant use would last only a few years. It is iniquitous that disabled people are being charged high tariffs on their essential items of equipment. It is particularly unjust when we remember that each year this Government hands out hundreds of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money in subsidies to industry, yet it is too mean to assist the small number of people in our community who are disabled.

The Australian Council for Rehabilitation of the Disabled in a submission to the Industries Assistance Commission in 1980 recommended a bounty of 20 per cent on wheelchairs. Members of the Government may be interested in the comments of the Executive Director of ACROD who said that if a bounty is good enough to help farmers to buy tractors and superphosphate, it should be good enough for disabled people to buy wheelchairs. It has become apparent that this Government has little practical concern for the disabled people, despite its rhetoric. Both the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) and the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) in their announcement in August 1980, indicated that disabled people would be able to obtain wheelchairs through the aids scheme. Nine months later no disabled person has received an aid. So much for the rhetoric.

I am particularly aware of the Government's breach of commitment to giving practical assistance to disabled people through my efforts to assist a young inventor in my electorate. This young man has invented a microprocessor controlled foldable electric wheelchair. This very lightweight wheelchair was the result of the inventor's knowledge of the debilitating effects experienced by his brother and other disabled people when using heavy, conventional wheelchairs. This project is well advanced with patent applications pending and considerable commercial interest being shown in the manufacturing side of the project. This enterprise would be particularly suitable for commercial development in the Australian Capital Territory and would be most appropriate in this International Year of Disabled Persons. The inventor requires funding of between $8,000 and $10,000 to continue the project and develop a prototype. He has spent considerable time and effort to get assistance but so far he has been unsuccessful. He has approached the assistance to inventors scheme but this scheme has no funds available. In any case, the future of this scheme is clouded following the razor gang review and this is yet another case of inefficient and ad hoc decision making. The Department of Productivity apparently has funds for project development but this inventor is precluded from applying as funds are only available when a prototype is complete.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is losing relevance with the Bill before the House. I am sure that the whole House is in sympathy with what the honourable member has to say but she is still required to be relevant.

—All I am trying to do is point out by this example that it would appear that allocation of government funding for projects with enormous potential to improve life for disabled people are not important enough to be treated seriously. This electric wheelchair, designed by a local inventor which could be manufactured locally with great benefit to the Australian Capital Territory economy, is to be ignored. I believe that this is another example of how the Government's rhetoric bears no relation to its action in this International Year of Disabled Persons. The legislation before us tonight only further illustrates that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to delay the House. I point out that this Bill maintains an additional cost on some areas of wheelchairs of up to $1,000. The amendment which was put forward by the Opposition would have that level of savings for some persons who are disabled and therefore who are least able in our community to provide those sorts of funds towards protection of an industry. Bounties are paid on a wide range of industries. Therefore I think the Government should reconsider its position and obviously that will not be done by a vote in the House at this late hour. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be now adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the honourable member for Corio seeking leave to continue his remarks on the resumption of debate?
—No, I expect the Government to change its position and that we will all be satisfied when the House resumes.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Debate on the matter has been extremely interesting, as usual (Quorum formed). I thank the Opposition for drawing the people's attention to the debate that has occurred here tonight. Most of the debate that surrounded the Customs Tariff Validation Bill 1981 has dealt with matters that relate to social security. This Bill relates to an Australian industry which employs people, and it does have some relevance. I know that the Australian Labor Party has a bleeding heart from time to time, but the relevance is to industry. Some honourable members, and particularly the honourable member for Henty (Mrs Child), said that the Government had no scheme. The Government's health scheme envisages that people who require them will receive mechanical and electrical wheelchairs. This is part of what is going on, but it has nothing to do with tariffs.
—It has everything to do with tariffs.

—It has nothing to do with tariffs whatsoever. Even the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) might need a suitably equipped wheelchair at some stage, and the chair will probably have to be electric. If it is, God knows what the charge will be. He may need a suitably equivalent chair. If he cannot get a suitable chair in Australia, he can apply to get a suitable equivalent from overseas, duty free. The honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly) made an academic contribution which was not entirely relevant. As to the number of people who have applied in Queensland for chairs, the local industry has been particularly helpful in its application and in its ability to supply requests. Those people have been able to supply the market quite adequately.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to those who have contributed to the debate that they have miscued very markedly in terms of commercial problems in relation to Customs tariff validation and those problems that are associated with social security. If honourable members cannot pick that up at 2.15 in the morning, I really do not have much sympathy for their contributions to the debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Moore)-by leave-proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I merely want to place on record that now the Opposition has registered its protest on this matter, we hope that the Government will consider it and will make changes sooner rather than later in this International Year of Disabled Persons. It is only a matter of an industry policy Bill; it is also a social security Bill. Just as bounties are used in relation to the farming industry in order to reduce the cost of tractors to farmers rather than impose tariffs on tractors, so that could be done in relation to wheelchairs. I trust that the bounties will be applied to wheelchairs very soon and that a proposal will be brought down even before this Parliament meets for the Budget session.

—I would like to comment on the statement by the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) that if one cannot buy a suitable electric wheelchair in Australia for one's own use, one can import it duty free. That has not been my experience. I can cite the case of a very well known doctor who uses an Amigo wheelchair and who wrote to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and to the Commissioner of Taxation seeking permission to bring the chair to Australia duty free. It is not manufactured here. There is nothing suitable or equivalent-nothing anything like it. It is a mobile that can be used as a chair for getting around hospitals and hospital grounds. It is allowed to be taken on international aircraft, and is the only type of wheelchair that can be taken on such aircraft. This doctor paid duty on the chair. I would be interested if the Minister could look at the matter and report back to the House tomorrow on whether his statement was correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The position is that if the person who has the disability can get from his or her doctor a certificate to say that the wheelchair that is manufactured in Australia is not suitable for his or her particular complaint, that certificate, on presentation to the Bureau of Customs, will, as I understand it, be favourably received by the Bureau.
—Retrospective?
—No, not retrospective.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Equity Participation in New Investment Projects

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 25 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the article headed 'FIRB gets up a $500m natural resources shopping list' in the Australian Financial Review, 19 February 1981, page 30.

(2) If so, (a) what steps does the Foreign Investment Review Board take to work towards a high level of Australian equity participation in new investment projects and (b) do these steps include regular notification to Australian Stock Exchanges of projects requiring increased Australian equity participation; if so, what are the details.

(3) What foreign investment projects have been approved on second or subsequent applications, following direct FIRB involvement, to increase Australian equity participation, for each year from 1975-76 to 1979-80.

(4) With respect to Chapter 2, Foreign investment in industry sectors, of the FIRB Report 1980, pages 9 to 18, (a) what (i) are the names of the 127 manufacturing companies where payment for assets by foreign investors led to a reduction in Australian ownership in 1978-79, and (ii) was the percentage of Australian ownership before and after that payment in each case (page 9), (b) what (i) are the names of the 145 manufacturing companies where payment for assets by foreign investors led to a reduction in Australian ownership in 1979-80 and (ii) was the percentage of Australian ownership before and after that payment in each case (page 9); (c) what are the names of the (i) 67 businesses in 1978-79 and (ii) 76 businesses in 1979-80 where Australian control was lost through acquisition, giving in each case the name both before and after acquisition (page 9); (d) how many proposals in the manufacturing sector were approved subject to conditions in (i) 1978-79 and (ii) 1979-80, giving in each case (A) the names of the company or companies concerned, (B) the conditions that were applied, (C) whether the conditions have been met and (D) what changes have occurred where conditions have not been met, (page 9); (e) has the FIRB completed its review of the activities of some overseas-owned companies, especially in the food industry, which have made a considerable number of small business acquisitions; if so, (i) has the FIRB made a report to the Government; if so, when and (ii) will he make a statement to the Parliament regarding the companies involved, the reasons for the review and any Government action which has resulted from that review (page 10); (f) (i) what were the conditions established by the Government in July 1978, in order for its approval to the Iwasaki Sangyo Co. for its tourist project at Yeppoon, Queensland, to be granted, (ii) what form has the FIRB's monitoring of the project taken to date, (iii) for how much longer will the FIRB be required to monitor the project, (iv) which of the Government's conditions have not been met, in whole or part, and what action has the Government taken as a result, (v) has the Government reconsidered its 1979 decision not to allow further land acquisitions for the Iwasaki project; if so, has further land acquisition been approved; if that approval has been given, what is the area of extra acquisition and when was it acquired, (vi) what is the percentage of Australian equity in the Iwasaki project, as at 24 February 1981, and (vii) what is the nature of the Australian participation in other ways in the Iwasaki project (page 12); (g) what are the names of the United States of America firms which have lodged the 19 successful applications to invest in private hospitals in Australia and what are the locations of the hospitals which were the subject of those applications; (h) when were the applications referred to in part 4 (g) approved and what was the percentage of local equity in each of the companies concerned, as at 24 February 1981, (j) what are the names, before and after acquisition, of the 11 Australian-owned advertising agencies taken over in the last 2 years by foreign firms (page 13) and (k) what methods does the FIRB employ in seeking to establish that Australians have been given an opportunity to buy rural land when there is a proposal before the FIRB for the sale of that land to foreign persons (page 14).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) (a) The Foreign Investment Review Board discusses with the parties to foreign investment proposals the Australian equity participation requirements that may apply to the proposed investments under the foreign investment policy. Such discussions are an important means of ensuring that the proposed equity structures of projects will satisfy the relevant Australian participation requirements. The discussions are held as early as possible in the planning of projects so that the formulation of the proposal can be undertaken with a knowledge of the Government's policy objectives.

In the examination of individual proposals, the Board considers the proposals against the Government's objective to seek Australian participation to the extent appropriate to the particular circumstances of each proposal, and in the light of the specific guidelines for Australian involvement in new natural resource projects. In all proposals for the acquisition of a substantial interest in an existing Australian business, the board considers very carefully the opportunities that have been provided for Australian investors to sustain or increase the level of Australian participation in the enterprises.

(b) No. Arrangement by which wholly or partly overseas-owned companies seek increased Australian participation are a commercial matter to be undertaken by the companies concerned through commercial channels of their own choice. From time to time, Australian companies and institutions approach the FIRB to make known their interest in participating in natural resource development. If the foreign participants in projects requiring additional Australian equity participation so request, they are supplied with the names of those Australian companies and institutions (subject to their concurrence) which have indicated an interest in investing in natural resources.

(3) The FIRB processes referred to in 2 (a) frequently result in increases being made in the proposed level of Australian equity during the course of initial consideration of applications. Accordingly, only a small proportion of applications is rejected. Of the 45 proposals rejected between 1 April 1976 and 31 December 1980, 22 were declined, at least in part, because of insufficient provision for Australian equity. Four of these were later approved in the light of increased provision for Australian equity participation, including:
the acquisition by Brooke Bond Australia of Bushells;
a proposal by Iwasaki Sangyo Co. (Australia) Pty Ltd to establish a tourist development project at Yeppoon, Queensland; and
a proposal involving the acquisition by Robin Holdings Pty Ltd of Singapore of an interest in a property known as 'Merrimac', located on the Queensland Gold Coast.
Details of the other case have not been made public by the Government.

(4) (a), (b) and (c) Because of the commercial sensitivity attaching to much of the information provided to the Board in connection with foreign investment proposals, the Government and the Board treat all such information in strict confidence and do not as a matter of practice disclose details of individual proposals, except in special circumstances where the parties' consent is first obtained. It is not, therefore, possible to provide details of the sort that have been requested.
(d) See answer to 4 (a), (b) and (c). The following information on all manufacturing sector proposals conditionally approved in 1978-79 and 1979-80 is available:
NUMBERS AND TYPES OF CONDITIONS IMPOSED ON MANUFACTURING SECTOR PROPOSALS

Total 30 49
Note: The number of conditions exceeds the number of conditional approvals as more than one condition was attached to some of the proposals.
As appropriate, consultation with the parties to proposals that receive conditional approval is undertaken to ensure that the conditions are complied with.
(e) The FIRB brings such activities to the attention of the Government where these are relevant to the consideration of specific proposals.
(f) (i) I refer the honourable member to my Press release No. 70 of 30 July 1978.

(ii) The FIRB Executive has held regular discussions with representatives of the company. The company has also furnished the Board with copies of various studies carried out by consultants and other information concerning the development of the resort project.
(iii) As long as it is necessary.

(iv) The company undertook negotiations in late 1979 to acquire further land for the resort without prior approval. As indicated in my Press release No. 8 of 23 January 1980, the Government took action to prohibit additional land acquisitions by the company.
(v) No.
(vi) Nil. The company, however, has undertaken to invite Australians to participate as soon as it becomes profitable.

(vii) I refer the honourable member to conditions one and two listed in my 30 July 1978 press release. In this regard the company has indicated that the first set of accommodation units on the resort, which are now due for completion in the middle of this year, will be managed by Australians.

(g) I refer the honourable member to the answer given by my colleague, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, to Senate question No. 2024 which appeared on pages 536 and 537 of the Hansard of 4 March 1980. This answer gives information on the companies concerned and proposals by them which have received foreign investment policy approval.

(h) Information as to the dates on which the approvals were given is confidential. As at 24 February 1981, none of the companies concerned had introduced Australian equity into their overall Australian operations.
(j) See answer to 4 (a), (b) and (c).

(k) In the examination of proposals for foreign acquisition of rural land the FIRB seeks to ensure that Australians have had an opportunity to purchase the land if they wished to do so. The Board inquires whether and over what period of time the relevant property has been advertised for sale or listed with agents in the manner normally employed in the industry, and seeks information on any Australian bids for the land. In cases where the land has not been offered to Australians or the exposure to the market has been regarded as inadequate, the parties have been invited to advertise the property on the understanding that the Government would complete its examination of the proposal in the light of the outcome from the advertisement.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is there provision for subsidising medical equipment, such as wheelchairs, for disabled persons either by direct grants or by taxation concessions; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: As regards direct assistance to disabled persons, in the context of the 1980-81 Federal Budget it was announced that the Government would introduce a new program under which aids to daily living would be provided to disabled people not eligible under existing Government assistance programs. The new program is in recognition of the needs of disabled people, and is a Commonwealth initiative in the International Year of Disabled Persons.

Under the Program of Aids for Disabled People, a range of aids to daily living, including home modifications, wheelchairs, orthoses, oxygen, electrolarynxes, aids for incontinence, walking aids, and personal aids (eating and cooking utensils, toilet articles, etc) will be provided on medical prescription to eligible disabled people, without cost to the recipient. Assistance under this program is to be by way of the provision of aids only, and will not include subsidising the cost of medical equipment purchased by individual disabled people.
I understand that the Department of Health is currently developing administrative procedures with a view to introducing the new program later this year.

Turning now to taxation concessions for disabled persons, I note that medical and surgical appliances, including wheelchairs, prescribed by a legally qualified medical practitioner qualify as rebatable expenditure under the Income Tax Assessment Act. A rebate is not, however, allowable unless the total of all classes of rebatable expenditure, including life insurance premiums, superannuation, medical expenses, rates, education expenses and self-education expenses, exceeds $1,590. The rebate is allowable on the amount of expenditure over $1,590 at the standard tax rate of 32 cents in the dollar.
Item 42 (10) in the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act exempts from sales tax a range of medical equipment, including wheelchairs, used by disabled persons.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In approving infrastructure borrowing by the States through the Loan Council for power stations, what information is available to the Commonwealth to evaluate the economic viability of the proposed works.
(2) Does his Department undertake any assessment of the pricing policies of the various State instrumentalities.
(3) If not, how does the Commonwealth determine whether the proposed borrowing is consistent with Commonwealth policy on national resource allocation priorities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1), (2) and (3) The Loan Council has adopted a procedure of referring proposals submitted to it for consideration under the infrastructure borrowing program to a working party of Commonwealth and State Treasury officers for evaluation and report before taking decisions on them. The proposals are evaluated with regard to guidelines which have been agreed by the Loan Council. Reference to those guidelines is to be found in Budget Paper No 7 for 1980-81, page 33. The working party reports are confidential to the Loan Council.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a statement allegedly made by the Deputy Prime Minister and reported in the Australian Financial Review of 9 March 1981, in which the Deputy Prime Minister is reported to have said that in the last 2 years a number of resources companies had, amongst them, raised over $2 billion on the Australian capital market.
(2) If so, is this figure correct.
(3) If the figure is correct, what sum has been raised by (a) foreign-owned or controlled corporations and (b) Australian companies.
(4) What proportion of the funds has been raised (a) in the form of debt capital and (b) as equity capital.
(5) To what extent has the (a) level of local ownership of Australia's resource development been increased and (b) access of other borrowers to funds been restricted by this fund raising.
(6) Has the fund raising had any effect on the level of domestic interest rates; if so, what effect.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However, the report in the Australian Financial Review of 9 March 1981 quoted the Deputy Prime Minister as having said that the group of companies had, over the past two years, raised over $1 billion on the Australian capital market, not over $2 billion as stated in the honourable member's question.

(2) The figure mentioned by the Deputy Prime Minister refers to some resources companies, not to all resources companies. Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) data on new capital raisings by all companies listed on Australian Stock Exchanges show that new money raised by listed companies in 1979 and 1980 totalled $1.641 million and $3.006 million respectively, i.e. $4.647 million over the two-year period.

(3) All but one of the companies involved in the capital raisings referred to by the Deputy Prime Minister are predominantly Australian-owned companies. The exception, CRA Ltd, is a naturalising company for the purposes of the Government's foreign investment policy.

(4) Approximately four-fifths of the capital raisings to which the Deputy Prime Minister referred were in the form of equity capital. The remainder were debt capital raisings. The ABS data referred to in part (2) above show that of the $4.647 million of new capital raised by all listed companies over the two years to December 1980, $2.032 million or 44 per cent was in the form of share issues.

These data are published on an industry basis but do not enable figures to be derived on capital raising by resource companies as such. The data by industry show that 49 per cent of new capital raised by manufacturing industry was by share issues while 94 per cent of the 'other' industry group (which excludes the manufacturing, commerce, finance and property industry groups but includes primary production, mining and quarrying) was by share issues.

(5) (a) It is not possible to quantify the effect of particular capital raisings by selected companies on the overall level of Australian ownership of resource development. Nevertheless, the need to ensure an appropriate level of Australian equity participation in natural resource projects is recognised by the Australian equity participation guidelines in the Government's foreign investment policy. In the 18 months to December 1980, 9 of the 11 new natural resource development projects that were approved incorporated equity structures that satisfied the guideline level of Australian participation. The other two projects were required, as a condition of approval, to meet the guideline level before production commenced.

(b) In the present Australian context of a very high demand for finance coupled with monetary policies directed to restraining that demand within appropriate bounds, it is axiomatic that capital raisings by any one group of borrowers can restrict the fund raisings of other groups. It is not possible to measure the extent to which borrowers are being restricted or to identify clearly which groups are being restricted; it is possible, for example, that the companies referred to in this question were themselves restricted in their borrowing plans by the activities of other borrowers including governments and their authorities.

(6) If there is a significant increase in the demand for finance, for example, associated with strengthening investment and economic activities as is occurring in the Australian economy at present, then it is inevitable that there will be some upward pressure on interest rates. The upward pressure on interest rates is one indication of excess demand; it is also one mechanism by which funds are channelled to the more economic projects and resources allocated efficiently. Such pressures, however, are only one of several determinants of interest rates.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McMahon Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 25 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many tradesmen with qualifications acceptable in Australia have migrated to Australia under the Numerical Multifactor Assessment System (NUMAS) scheme since its inception in January 1979.
(2) What is the country of origin of each of these tradesmen.
(3) What is the numerical breakdown of these tradesmen by industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 12,753 skilled tradesmen entered Australia between January 1979 and December 1980. Before April 1979, migrants selected under NUMAS were not enumerated separately from those selected under pre-NUMAS criteria, many of whom continued to arrive well into 1980. Also, other tradesmen have entered under Family Reunion, Refugee and Special Eligibility categories, not subject to full NUMAS assessment. However of the number entering since April 1979, 6,289 were in the General Eligibility category of migrants and subject to full NUMAS assessment.
